PETITION.TITLE: In-vitro Fertilisation Patients: Medicare Funding
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable The President and members of the Senate in Parliament
The petition of the undersigned shows a request for Medicare benefits for in-vitro fertilisation for the medical treatment of infertile couples.

Your petitioners pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled grant Medicare benefits for in-vitro fertilisation, IVF, for the medical treatment of infertile couples. 1 in 10 Australian couples are infertile and unable to conceive and carry a baby to birth. Having a family is one of the most fundamental and rewarding aspects of life and benefits the community as a whole. IVF is an established and proven treatment for infertility. There are existing mechanisms to regulate and control IVF, including the National Health and Medical Research Council and the Reproductive Technology Accreditation Committee. Currently IVF patients pay up to $1500 per treatment cycle for IVF out of their own pockets. This means that some couples who need IVF to help them establish their own family do not have access. We request that Medicare Funding be granted for IVF for the treatment of infertility and your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Drugs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Senators in Parliament assembled; the humble petition of the undersigned citizens showeth:

That your petitioners deplore the Federal Government's decision to remove 53 Pharmaceutical drugs-including the best available for the treatment of high blood pressure, cancer, epilepsy, high cholesterol and uneven heartbeat-and place them, for cost saving reasons only, on a special list requiring Authority from a Canberra Bureaucrat, and;

That we believe a patient's doctor is clearly the best judge for medication needed for their particular illness and that it is therefore wrong and unfair to force that doctor to waste valuable time referring a case to a person in Canberra who has no personal knowledge of that case.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senators in Parliament assembled will call on the Government to immediately abandon the proposal and keep its election promise of high quality and universal health care for all Australians.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions and Fringe Benefits Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President of the Senate and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows:

We are gravely concerned at the Government's proposal to reduce significantly the pension and access to fringe benefits of persons who in good faith bought market linked insurance bonds, friendly society bonds, approved deposit funds, deferred annuities and unit trusts to protect their savings.

Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, amend the proposed legislation to ensure that it will not apply retrospectively and that provision is made to protect savings against inflation.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. Most retired people have placed money in managed or market linked investments as a hedge against inflation, rather than to avoid the income test on eligibility for the aged pension.
2. The capital growth on such investments should not therefore be regarded as income.

3. The decision by the Hawke Labor Government to regard the calculated annual capital growth of such investments as income for determining eligibility for pensions will cause many thousands of retirees to lose their pension thereby causing them extreme hardship.
4. The decision will be a further disincentive for people to save for their retirement, thereby increasing the longer term cost to the taxpayer of support for the aged.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate will reject any legislation giving effect to this decision.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sporting, Cultural and Community Groups: Sponsorship
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned:
(i) are alarmed that many sporting, cultural and community groups have been made to feel that they can attract sponsorship only from promoters of unhealthy products;
(ii) call for a National Health Promotion Foundation to be established through an increase in tobacco excise of 10 cents per packet; and

(iii) urge that the National Health Promotion Foundation provide national sporting, cultural and community groups with alternative sponsorship funding so that these groups can flourish without the taint of accepting money from tobacco companies and assisting in the promotion of their unhealthy products.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: The Last Temptation of Christ

The petition of the undersigned citizens of Tasmania respectfully showeth:
1. That we strongly object to the contents of the film `The Last Temptation of Christ'

And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade to reported comments of the former Premier of Western Australia and current Ambassador to Ireland and the Holy See, Mr Brian Burke. Mr Burke was reported in the Australian newspaper of saying, when he was asked to comment on the collapse of Rothwells Ltd:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . it would be easier . . . when next year's State election was safely won.
I have no intention of doing anything that could cause difficulty for the Government and the Premier, Mr Dowding, in particular.
Later he is quoted as saying:
I have every confidence in the quality of the Government and, in particular, the Premier.

I ask the Minister: Does he consider it appropriate for a serving Australian Ambassador to make comments such as this, which are of a highly political nature? Is the Minister considering taking any disciplinary action against Mr Burke for making such comments? I further ask: In the event of any inquiry being called into the Rothwells affair, can the Minister give an assurance that the Government will instruct Mr Burke to return to Australia to appear before any such inquiry to give evidence if called upon to do so?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure whether it is normally appropriate for ambassadors to respond in terms that might be construed as having a political content but I think it is probably understandable enough in the circumstances of the present case, when Mr Burke has been subject to some personal attacks arising out of those particular circumstances.
—What personal attacks?

—To the extent he personally has been the subject of a number of gibes by the honourable senator and other people in the Opposition forces directed against the conduct of government-rather misplaced gibes when one considers the performance of the Court Liberal Government in its own dealings over that particular period, not least in the context of the North West Shelf domestic gas project, which I well remember personally and which involved a contingent liability, not of the order of $100m, which is suggested to be the amount in issue here, but $7 billion as a result of a spectacularly misconceived contract entered into by Sir Charles Court and his particular generation of Ministers.

ANSWER.PARA: I make the point that there are occasions when people will naturally want to respond in kind when they are subject to personal attacks. I regard the circumstances of any possible inquiry as being entirely hypothetical and I do not propose to respond on that basis.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I note with amusement the Minister's reply, but I ask him: Is he saying that as far as he is concerned he knows of no rule which prevents a serving ambassador from entering into domestic political controversy? I further ask him: Is he aware of reports of letters over Mr Burke's signature being used for campaign purposes in Western Australia since Mr Burke has gone to Ireland? Is that also within the broad latitude that the Minister seems to be prepared to permit serving Australian ambassadors?
—I have nothing to add to my previous answer.

—Has the Minister representing the Treasurer seen an article in last Friday's West Australian headlined `Howard switch on gold tax'? Is it the case that the Government will postpone the legislation to remove the exemption from taxation of income from gold mining while it awaits any further representations in relation to this matter from the goldmining lobby, following Mr Howard's indication that he is willing to look at any economically rational case on the goldmining tax?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In regard to the last part of the question, there is of course absolutely no economically rational case for not putting the goldmining industry under the same tax regime as every other industry. In other words, there is absolutely no economically rational case for continuing to allow one industry-the only industry-to have this special easy ride which it has had for the last 60-odd years. I have seen Mr Howard's statement as reported in the West Australian newspaper which is in total contradiction to what Mr Howard said at an investment seminar in New York a month or so ago, when he said that it would be very hard to justify the continued exemption of one section of industry. At that time he was absolutely correct. Last week, under pressure from the goldmining industry and the Western Australian Liberal Party, he said:

ANSWER.PARA: I don't have a closed mind on the matter . . . I have said to representatives of the industry that if there is an economically rational case I am prepared to have a look at it. People should not assume that I have a closed mind. I don't like new taxes.

In the face of that comment, I find it rather difficult to understand why there is so much dissatisfaction with Mr Howard's leadership of the Liberal Party because he is quite willing to cave in to every pressure group that puts a bit of heat on him. He will agree with anyone who puts a bit of pressure on, so he should be the most popular leader in history. By contrast, the shadow Treasurer said in May of this year on this issue that the Opposition would not be making any recommendation to block the removal of the exemption. To my knowledge he has not deviated from that position. We now have Mr Howard bending with the wind and talking, not in terms of removing an exemption but in terms of a new tax, in other words, delving into newspeak. The Government has already had an inquiry into this matter. Every major goldmining project that has proceeded in the last few years or is now on the books has had factored into its economic viability assessment normal company tax at a rate of 49c, not 39c, in the dollar. These lobbyists-these Western Australian spivs-who have polluted the Australian political process for decades are wasting their time. The timetable will not be delayed. The legislation was introduced in the House of Representatives. It will be passed by the Senate before the end of this calendar year. The Australian Democrats, soft as they may be on a few things, at least have the stomach to stand up to those Western Australian spivs that have polluted Australian politics for decades. It does not matter what the Opposition does about this. The legislation will be passed and the issue will be off the Australian political agenda forever.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. The Minister would now be familiar with the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) dealings on the Oasis Hotel at Walgett where the property was recently given away to a company called Barwon Pty Ltd. Has the ADC given a bank guarantee to financiers on the property? What involvement have the directors of Barwon with the previous management company Gamilaria Pty Ltd, which went defunct while operating the hotel?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Brownhill asked me some particular questions concerning the Oasis Hotel at Walgett, particularly the ADC's relationship with the Barwon community. Rather than answer the particularity, I should point out the way in which the Government intends, from this point, to deal with the sorts of questions and allegations that have been made. As was made clear last week by both the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and the Prime Minister, the Government is adamant in its readiness to investigate fully all allegations of maladministration and impropriety in the administration of Aboriginal affairs. That undertaking is now fleshed out with more administrative machinery to ensure that there is no cover-up whatsoever and to enable the Parliament to be as fully informed as possible. I am now in a position to inform honourable senators that the Government has established mechanisms and a process for investigating allegations which have been made.

ANSWER.PARA: The allegations will be investigated in the first instance by the agencies appropriate to them as follows: the Auditor-General has already agreed to undertake a comprehensive audit of the Aboriginal Development Commission and will extend this, as appropriate, into the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. The Auditor-General is, of course, fully independent and has powers to conduct a very wide-ranging investigation, particularly in the area of financial administration. The Public Service Commissioner, who is also an independent statutory officer, will investigate those questions concerning personnel management in the Department. I might add that any staff classification issues will be investigated as is appropriate by the Department of Finance.

In addition, the Government recognises that certain matters may still require further examination in light of these specialised investigations. The Government has asked Mr Andrew Menzies, AM, OBE, a former Deputy Secretary of the Attorney-General's Department, to make such an inquiry if necessary. He has agreed to do so. I emphasise that the judgment of which matters, if any, would warrant such further examination will be exercised independently by Mr Menzies. Together, these investigations will clearly be able to comprehend all the various allegations made in the report of the Senate Estimates Committee, including the minority part of that report. The approach would be sufficiently broad to pick up other allegations.

On timing, it is expected that these investigations will be completed in time to enable a statement to be made early in the new year. The approach which is described represents the best means by which an expeditious, thorough investigation can be conducted. There is no need for the more complex and costly processes of a judicial inquiry. Some of the allegations which have been made-and I repeat `allegations'-may be relevant to the former Secretary of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Perkins. I wish to make it clear that Mr Perkins will be given every opportunity to put his views on the allegations against him and against the administration of his Department. Pending the outcome, Mr Perkins is an unattached Secretary and is receiving the salary and allowances of his previous office.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Why has there been no response to questions that have been put on notice to the Minister over the last year pertaining to the matters that are now raised in this place? Surely that smacks of something that was wanted to be hidden at that stage.
—Hundreds, if not thousands, of questions have been asked of this portfolio over the last several months.
—You do not bother answering any of them.

—That is completely untrue, as Senator Alston knows. When I was the Minister at the table during the Estimates Committee hearing I tried to ensure that honourable senators received answers as fully as possible from the officers. Many hundreds of answers were supplied in, I thought, a very speedy fashion in reply to the questions put by Senator Tambling and Senator Short to the portfolio about a week before the Estimates Committee met. Further undertakings have been given to provide them with further answers. I believe that many of those undertakings have been fulfilled. There has been a very conscious attempt to try to provide the Parliament with the answers which it properly seeks to have. Right from the start there has been no attempt on the part of this Government to cover up. Indeed, the fullest possible inquiry will now be undertaken by means of the mechanisms which I have indicated.

—I refer the Minister for Consumer Affairs to the recently released report of the National Forum on Credit Overcommitment. How extensive are the report's recommendations and is the Minister in a position to respond to them?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —In April this year the National Consumer Affairs Advisory Council held a forum on consumer credit. That forum played a rather crucial role in that it raised public awareness of issues concerning not only the extent of consumer overcommitment but also other parallel issues in terms of consumer protection. It also brought together quite a number of people involved in consumer credit from diverse areas. Together at one forum we had representatives of industry, government and consumer organisations. As a consequence, and because of the flow of information at that forum, I think a greater understanding of the problems of each group is now shared by the other groups. The report that Senator Childs refers to is the formal product of that forum.

ANSWER.PARA: Since the forum there have been a number of major developments in the consumer credit area, and already some of the recommendations of the Council have been acted upon. I think that also underscores the fact that the forum was a major success.

The major recommendation of the report is an advocation and very strong recommendation that governments in Australia adopt a process to bring about uniform credit laws. At a meeting of State and Federal Ministers held in Melbourne in July of this year we agreed that the concept of uniformity would proceed, that there would be core legislation to cover consumer lending in all areas apart from housing, and that this legislation would apply equally to all credit providers. The legislation is currently being drafted by the Victorian Law Reform Commission and, in a rather progressive step, it will be drafted in plain English. The laws, when finally completed-and I anticipate, given the fact that drafting is proceeding quite speedily, that the draft legislation will be available early next year-should benefit consumers and industry. They will benefit consumers by ensuring comprehensive consumer protection in all States and Territories, and they will benefit industry because they will give it a level playing field, certainty and consistency across the national market.

As well as the main recommendation for uniform credit laws, the Council also addressed rather extensively the problems of financial counsellors. The Council sees financial counsellors as playing a crucial role in assisting consumers who have been overcommitted in their credit obligations. As a consequence, the Council recommends increased funding. Once again underscoring the success of the forum, since the forum we have been able to bring together both credit providers as well as industry associations, together with consumer organisations, in a working group to discuss consumer financial counsellors. But also a major aspect of the reason that we have brought these three organisations together, including government, has been because of the willingness by industry organisations and groups to indicate a preparedness to provide funding for credit counsellors. That proposal of those organisations has been well worked out by the working group and if it is feasible this Government gladly welcomes it.

As well as that, there have been a number of other initiatives that are also part of the report's recommendations. Because of the greater understanding enhanced by the forum we have been able, over the last few months, to bring together by way of a credit reference committee, representatives of both industry and consumer organisations. I think governments have felt that for a long time individual organisations and a number of representative groups have acted in isolation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Put Mr Dowding and Mr Parker on it.

—Because of the initiatives of both the Australian Bankers Association and the Australian Finance Conference, Senator Chaney, and a willingness on their part to discuss matters with consumer organisations, we have been able to put together this group.

ANSWER.PARA: The fourth and most important part of the Council's recommendations goes to consumer credit education. To that effect, in cooperation with the State Government of South Australia, we have already published a booklet which has been especially geared towards, and which will be widely distributed amongst, younger consumers.

The Government is taking the Council's report seriously. We believe that the forum that was held earlier this year was very timely. It has been a catalyst to improve relationships between all the players in the field. I think it has played a very constructive role in the lead-up to rational policy development in this area.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. Over the last few days 8,000 people from all over Australia have attended conferences on the greenhouse effect. The overwhelming conclusion of these people has been that the pursuit of economic growth is the basic cause of this problem. Is the pursuit of growth of gross national product (GNP) consistent with a solution to the greenhouse effect and other global environmental problems, or is it a fundamental impediment to a solution to these problems? If growth of the gross national product is consistent with a solution to these problems, would the Minister explain their relatedness? If economic growth and a solution to the greenhouse effect are inconsistent, will the Minister advise his colleagues that a totally different economic modelling for Australia and, by extension, the whole industrial world, is required?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did read that about 8,000 people attended the conference in Melbourne. I do not know how they got there. If they flew, they were adding to the carbon dioxide pollution. If they drove they were also adding to the carbon dioxide pollution. If they rode a bike they were adding to carbon dioxide pollution, because they would be exhaling a bit more carbon dioxide than if they were lying at home reading a book. Likewise, if they walked there they would be adding to pollution. We should recognise that just about everything we do puts carbon dioxide into the atmosphere.
—Speak more calmly and you will reduce your contribution.

—That is probably right. If I did not have to sit in here listening to sanctimonious humbug, as I did for 2 1/2 hours last Wednesday afternoon, I would not add as much either. Senator Coulter has asked me questions about the Australian national accounts before, and this one indicates that he still does not understand the essential nature of gross domestic product (GDP) statistics. I assume he is talking about GDP instead of GNP, because GDP is the measure that is used in Australia. The level of GDP published by the Australian Bureau of Statistics is the Bureau's estimate of the quantity of goods and services produced in Australia over a period. It includes goods and services which are sold in market places and valued accordingly. It also includes goods and services which are not sold in the market place using internationally accepted principles and imputes to those a value.

ANSWER.PARA: The important point is that GDP includes goods and services, the production of which in some cases involves the emission of significant amounts of carbon dioxide and in others involves negligible amounts of carbon dioxide-that is, those services which are produced by human energy alone. Humans are not great transpirers of carbon dioxide. A given level of GDP would be consistent or compatible with a whole range of carbon dioxide emission levels. A given level of GDP growth could be compatible with either higher levels of carbon dioxide emission, no change levels of carbon dioxide emission, or lower levels of carbon dioxide emission. Likewise, negative growth GDP could occur side by side with increases of carbon dioxide emission.

If Senator Coulter wants to see GDP in Australia fall-and I notice that one of his Australian Democrat colleagues was advocating just that recently-he should realise that that would mean less employment or less productive employment-that is, a lowering of labour productivity, and either way it would mean a reduction in material living standards. Unless, of course, the Democrats want to pursue an alternative solution and reduce population as well, preferably very quickly. If they do, that would not solve the immediate problem. They will have to get rid of some of the people already here if they want to avoid a substantial reduction in average living standards, which would otherwise be the inescapable consequence of a reduction in GDP. I do not think I need say any more.

TALK.START.PARA: —If I may ask a supplementary question, is the Minister saying that growth of GDP represents an increase in wealth and therefore an increased ability to pay for environmental clean-up, an argument that is often heard? Is he aware that GDP measures the rate at which resources are used up, whether those resources are used for services or the consumption of material resources? Eventually they represent the consumption of material resources, in other words, the throughput, and therefore, by definition, must represent an increase in environmental damage. Secondly, is the Minister not aware that GDP counts as benefits the costs of addressing greenhouse and other environmental problems? If one counts costs as benefits and then claims that one is spending those benefits to address the costs, is this not doubly counting benefits-in other words, counting the same benefits twice, and is this not voodoo economics?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suggest that anybody who is interested in voodoo economics should make a habit of listening to Senator Coulter on a regular basis. The plain fact is that the energy input, if I may put it this way, for GDP output is not a fixed ratio; it is a highly variable ratio. For example, in the case of a painting, some energy might be consumed in weaving or growing the fibre for the canvas and in making the paint-whatever paints are made out of-and a bit of human energy would go into the brush strokes, with the result that some carbon dioxide is added to the atmosphere. If somebody wants to value that painting at $1m, that would be much less than, for example, $1m worth of new motor cars, or $1m worth of additional electricity.

ANSWER.PARA: There are some conceptual flaws, I believe, in the way GDP is measured, and I am not trying to minimise the possibility that carbon dioxide accumulation could be a problem. One way not of eliminating it but of reducing it which is technically feasible is to switch from fossil fired electricity production to nuclear electricity production. The Democrats give that the big thumbs down as well. But whatever the problems are, I am sure they will not be cured by an infinite number of new class orgies of the type that were conducted over the weekend about this question.

—Has the Minister for Local Government read the article in Choice magazine which claims that Australian standard heights for home swimming pool fences are inadequate? What protective measures does local government take to ensure swimming pool safety?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Australia has the unenviable record of having the highest rate of backyard swimming pool deaths for children under six. It is of great concern to local and State governments and, indeed, to the Australian Consumers Association. The article in the recent Choice magazine showed results of a number of tests relating to the height of swimming pool fences. At present the height is 1.2 metres. It is claimed that the average three-year-old can scale that height of fence if that three-year-old is determined enough to have access to the swimming pool. Of course, I think it is important to say, in talking about the height of swimming pool fences, that nothing can replace parental or adult supervision. It is very important to make that point very clearly.

ANSWER.PARA: Unfortunately, around Australia we have differing regulations, some of which rely totally on local government taking the initiative. Of course, many responsible local governments do take that initiative. For the benefit of honourable senators I would like to run through the variations around Australia. The building code of Australia, which is being prepared at the moment, will be looking at a national standard, and it would be hoped that the individual States will take up that recommendation. At the moment State regulations for swimming pool fences are discretionary in New South Wales. Although many local authorities make their own regulations which usually comply with the Australian standard, obviously there are considerable variations. Victoria has compulsory State regulations. The Building Control Act contains regulations which largely comply with the standard but there are limited concessions for private single dwellings. In Queensland again the standard is discretionary, although the Department of Local Government advises adoption of the standard if local authorities choose to make their own regulations. Both Western Australia and South Australia have compulsory regulations. Tasmania does not have regulations. Local authorities do not have power to make their own regulations and I think this is of particular concern. In the Northern Territory, local authorities may make their own regulations. Of course, in the Australian Capital Territory, the Australian Capital Territory Building Manual contains regulations which comply with the standard.

So, in answer to Senator Giles's question, I think Choice magazine has raised a very legitimate concern. It is timely that this issue should be raised. It is to be hoped that once uniform regulations are recommended, individual State governments will take up this question so that across the nation we will have standards which each State and each local authority will comply with.

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs to Mr Hand's statement last Friday that the major reason Mr Perkins had been sacked was because of the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) proposal to provide $300,000 to the Woden Town Club for the purchase of poker machines. I ask the Minister: Is it not a fact that only two to three days earlier the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs had announced the appointment of the Auditor-General to audit the financial affairs of the ADC because of the allegations that had been made, inter alia, about ADC grants and loans to the Woden Town Club? I further ask the Minister, therefore: Why was Mr Perkins sacked on Friday over the Woden Town Club before the Auditor-General has even had the opportunity to meaningfully commence his audit of the ADC, including the Woden Town Club proposal?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It will take a little time, but I think it is necessary for the Senate to understand the full circumstances in which the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs exercised his responsibilities and decided to remove Mr Perkins as Secretary of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. So therefore I will outline those, and I think that will help to indicate the special circumstances which led to this necessary decision. In the House of Representatives Mr Hand has made certain statements, but I will indicate two of them. On 1 November, in relation to the Woden Town Club, Mr Hand stated:

ANSWER.PARA: I am totally opposed to the club being given grant moneys. I would not give a poker machine club one cent of public money. I have told the ADC commissioners that.
On 3 November he said the following:

I think my position on the Woden Town Club is well and truly known. I should point out for the benefit of the House that the offer and the documentation of the offer that has been alluded to in the media by the Senate Estimates Committee has never formally been sent to the organisation.
The offer has now been withdrawn and the matter will be reconsidered at the next meeting of the commissioners.
That was and still is the situation.
It is important that the House understand the following details relating to the Woden Town Club.

On October 25 the Woden Town Club was notified by fax that the club would be offered additional financial support from the ADC. The fax said-if I can personify it-that the necessary documents would be forthcoming.

On October 26, Mr Andrew Jackomos, the Secretary of the Woden Town Club, told the Minister that this was the first day he had learnt of this supposed offer and he first learnt it when it was raised at the Senate Estimates hearing on the same day.
From this time onwards, until the morning of Friday, November 4, the Minister was assured by both Mr Jackomos and Mr Perkins that no action had been taken by the club on this faxed document.

October 31: ADC commission meeting held at the request of the Minister with Mr Perkins present. At that meeting the Minister expressed his opposition to this funding proposal for the club to the commissioners. The Minister then left the meeting having stated his position.

I have been informed that the ADC commissioners decided at that meeting to defer implementation of the previous funding decision and consider the matter again at the next meeting to be held in December. The Minister has also been informed that at that meeting the commissioners were informed that the Woden Town Club had not met to discuss the offer.

During last week and following that meeting of ADC commissioners, the Minister discussed the question of the funding arrangements by the ADC of the Woden Town Club with both the President of the Club, Mr Perkins, and the Secretary of the Club, Mr Jackomos. At no time during the course of those discussions did Mr Perkins inform the Minister that there had been a meeting of the Woden Town Club to discuss the matter of funding.

On November 3 at approximately 5.40 p.m. the Minister's office received a phone call from an ADC officer to say that two board members of the Woden Town Club had delivered a letter to the ADC in Canberra accepting the supposed offer of additional funding outlined in the faxed letter sent to the Secretary of the club on October 25.

At 10.15 p.m. on 3 November, the Minister finally managed to contact the Acting General Manager of the ADC, Mr Wyatt, and asked for confirmation of the message he had received earlier that evening. Mr Wyatt confirmed a letter had been received and agreed to the Minister's request to bring a copy of it to his office the next morning. At no stage until the afternoon of Thursday, 3 November, was there any hint that the Woden Town Club had met to consider any supposed offer of support, let alone respond in any positive way.

On 4 November at 8.45 a.m. Mr Wyatt brought a copy of the letter to the Minister's office. I table and seek leave to incorporate the letter from Mr Andrew Jackomos, Secretary of the Woden Town Club, addressed to the Acting General Manager of the ADC, dated 3 November 1988.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
3 November 1988
Mr C. Wyatt
Acting General Manager
Aboriginal Development Commission
Bonner House
WODEN ACT 2606
Dear Cedric
I refer to the letter of 25 October 1988 from the Acting Branch Manager-Sydney detailing the Commissioners offer to the Corporation.

The Governing Committee, at a properly constituted meeting on 27 October 1988, resolved to accept the Commissions offer of financial assistance. We believe that this now forms a legal and binding agreement between the Corporation and the Commission. Mr Perkins did not attend or take part in the discussions leading to the decision to accept the Commissions offer.

The Corporation seeks the immediate release of $150,000 loan advance to enable the payment of pressing creditors. With respect to the balance of the offer, the Corporation is prepared to negotiate `down' for presentation at the next Commission meeting.

We ask the Commission to consider that of the $811,300, provided through either grants, loans or guarantees, our $500,000 has been returned to the Commission through capital improvements to Bonner House. Of the $300,000 guaranteed for the purchase of the poker machines, an approximate $250,000 would be realised on resale.
The Commissions urgent release of the $150,000 is considered urgent with the bad press forcing creditors to take possible action.
Yours sincerely
Andrew Jackomos
SECRETARY

TALK.START.PARA: —The letter is from the Woden Town Club Secretary and its contents differed significantly from the Minister's belief as to what had been the arrangement between the ADC and the Club, a belief in no way challenged by Mr Jackomos or Mr Perkins at any time until the moment the Minister met with Mr Perkins on Friday, 4 November. At 9 a.m. on that Friday Mr Hand had a meeting with the Prime Minister's Principal Private Secretary to whom he gave a copy of the letter and to whom he expressed his deepest reservations as to its implications.

ANSWER.PARA: At 9.15 a.m. the Minister met with Mr Perkins and confronted him with the letter with its statements about accepting an offer and demanding further assistance for the Woden Town Club. The Minister told Mr Perkins that the letter posed enormous problems for their relationship. Mr Perkins, upon being told of the Minister's concern, did not offer any response other than to suggest withdrawing the letter. When the Minister pointed out the improprieties of this idea, Mr Perkins suggested that another letter might be written. Given these circumstances, the Minister indicated to Mr Perkins that he should resign from his position as Acting Commissioner of the ADC. The Minister determined that he could no longer work with Mr Perkins as his Secretary. He left Mr Perkins in no doubt as to that view. It had become clear to the Minister that Mr Perkins was not prepared to give appropriate priority to his position as Secretary to the Department. The Minister then left Mr Perkins in his office and proceeded to see the Prime Minister, where he put his case of not having a good enough basis for a working relationship with Mr Perkins. It was clear from the letter from the Club, of which Mr Perkins was the President, that the contents of the letter were inconsistent with what he had been told by Mr Perkins as President of the Club and as Secretary to the Department of Aboriginal Affairs.

The Minister now knows that Mr Perkins had discussed this matter with various people, in particular, on Thursday, 3 November, at the Woden Town Club because Mr Perkins told the Minister so himself. Despite this, and knowing the Minister's strong views on the subject and his statements in the Parliament, Mr Perkins had not informed the Minister until this time. The Minister judged that it was not plausible that Mr Perkins would not have known about the contents of the letter dated 3 November from the Club to the Commission and referring to a meeting of the Club on 27 October. Mr Perkins did not keep the Minister fully informed as would have been reasonably expected on a matter of major current interest and about which he was in a unique position to know. Nor did the Minister judge that Mr Perkins took adequate action, which he was in a unique position to take, to give effect to the Minister's clear position on the financial relationship between the Commission and the Woden Town Club.

Following the Minister's meeting with Mr Perkins, the Minister left his office to speak with the Prime Minister to report to the Prime Minister that because of this incident the Minister could no longer have a good working relationship with Mr Perkins. The established administrative procedures then followed. The Prime Minister set in motion the necessary Public Service actions which led to Mr Perkins discussing his future prospects with the appropriate people. I think that indicates the range of reasons and the sequence of events to do with the special working relationship between a Secretary to a Department and his Minister. It indicates, in a very full way, why Minister Hand made the decisions and recommendations which he did in relation to Mr Perkins. I have quoted to the Senate from a five-page document prepared in the first person for Mr Hand. I seek leave to table that statement and then if in my trying to put it in the third person I have failed--

TALK.START.PARA: —Can you incorporate it?
—Do you wish to incorporate it or table it?

—I shall incorporate it. I will, of course, check the Hansard to see that I have done the right transposing of first person to third person. I seek leave to incorporate the statement in Hansard and I will table it.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.

I have been informed that the ADC commissioners decided at that meeting, to defer implementation of the previous funding decision and consider the matter again at the next meeting to be held in December.

During last week and following that meeting of ADC commissioners I discussed the question of the funding arrangements by the ADC of the Woden Town Club with both the President of the club, Mr Perkins, and the Secretary of the club, Mr Jackomos. November 3: At approximately 5.40 p.m. my office received a phone call from an ADC officer to say that two board members of the Woden Town Club had delivered a letter to the ADC in Canberra accepting the supposed offer of additional funding outlined in the faxed letter sent to the secretary of the club on October 25.
At 10.15 p.m on November 3, I finally managed to contact the acting general manager of the ADC Mr Wyatt and asked for confirmation of the message I had received earlier that evening.
He confirmed a letter had been received and agreed to my request to bring a copy of it to my office the next morning.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I ask the Minister whether the details he has just given to the Senate are not inconsistent with the relevant answers given to the Senate Estimates Committee on 25 and 26 October not only by Mr Perkins but by the Minister as well?

—Is the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories aware of some unrest, particularly in New South Wales, regarding guidelines for primary school sporting arrangements under the sex discrimination legislation? Can the Minister advise the Senate of the Government's position and whether there is any change to practices and guidelines put in place over the last few years? Do the arrangements in place conform with the Aussie Sports program, set up by the Australian Sports Commission, under which boys and girls are encouraged to have wider participation in a number of sports with modified rules?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of some problems in New South Wales regarding arrangements for primary school sport and some potential problems with the implementation of the Commonwealth Sex Discrimination Act. In relation to sport the Commonwealth Act states:

ANSWER.PARA: Nothing in Division 1 or 2 renders it unlawful to exclude persons of one sex from participation in any competitive sporting activity in which the strength, stamina or physique of competitors is relevant.

However, it should be noted that that does not apply to children under the age of 12. That is because the intent of the law was that there should be equality for all children in sport. Obviously that has to extend to administration as well so that we stop the belief growing up that sport belongs to men. In 1986 the directors-general of education in each State got together to decide some common policy on this. They decided that, instead of there being separate boys and girls competitions, there should be an open competition and a girls competition, with the latter being a special measure to maintain positions for girls who may initially be disadvantaged in the open category.

That was okay, except that when individual directors-general went back to their States, they all had a different interpretation of what that meant. That being the case, the director-general in New South Wales implemented the strategy immediately, without consultation with teachers and with little in-service training. As a result, there has been a significant problem in New South Wales. The single-strategy approach of New South Wales differs markedly from the approach of almost all the other governments, which have taken a somewhat more multifaceted approach to handling the problem.

In the light of the problem experienced in New South Wales and some of the other States, I intend to approach the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission asking it to do the following: firstly, to liaise with State commissions to explore that multistrategy approach to which I referred earlier to bring about a gradual and sensitive change to the participation of children in sport; and, secondly, to recommend to the Australian School Sports Council that we seek to develop a nationally agreed plan for primary school sport. The Aussie school sports program has been very successful in increasing the participation rates of both girls and boys in sport around Australia. I hope that by this new measure we will be able to do even better.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF FOREIGN AFFAIRS AND TRADE

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the document from which Senator Macklin was quoting is now fully a year old and that the situation is no longer really as he describes it. It is the case that consistent with overall resource constraints, with which we are all familiar, there has been some net cutback in this area, but in fact there has been less than in many other vitally important areas of the Department. The fact that the numerical situation has been maintained as it has is a tribute to the importance with which the Government continues to regard this area.

ANSWER.PARA: No formal disposal facilities for hexachlorobenzene are known of in Australia. The honourable senator also raised the issue of pathology tests undertaken to detect chronic fatigue syndrome. Such committees consist of five medical practitioners who take evidence of a clinical nature and report to the Minister on their findings. A practitioner whose services to patients are considered by such a committee is not the subject of any charge but is required to explain that a reason exists for heavy costs on Medicare. It is usual for a medical adviser of the Health Insurance Commission to contact practitioners who could become the subject of referral to such a committee to acquaint them of the principles underlying Medicare and of the possibility of such services becoming subject to on inquiry.

Pathology services of a screening nature do not attract benefit under section 19 (3) of the Health Insurance Act, and the Health Insurance Commission must be satisfied that very large volumes of pathology tests are required for the management of the patient before such claims are approved.
