DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Sanders proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The serious threat to jobs and the National Estate posed by present logging practices and policies in Tasmania.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are discussing `the serious threat to jobs and the National Estate posed by present logging practices and policies in Tasmania'. The wording could just as well have referred to the present logging practices in most other areas of Australia or in fact the world. We are barely starting to realise the value of the forests of the world at a time when they are disappearing at an increasing rate. In fact, the forests of the world are being mined. It is a mining operation; it is not a forestry operation or a silviculture operation. We are seeing the exploitation of virgin native forests. The Forestry Commission of Tasmania-or anywhere else for that matter, but we are talking about Tasmania today-should take an inventory of any wood to be cut. It should identify the high value timbers. Tasmania especially has some wonderful furniture timbers such as blackwood, celery top pine and huon pine. These fine furniture timbers should be identified as the highest grade timbers. The eucalypt species which are suitable for furniture and saw logs should be identified. All wood should be graded as to its end use. Wood should be graded for use as furniture timber or for saw logs. The most inferior woods should be used as woodchips. That would be the rational way to do it. The highest grade timber should be extracted first and the woodchip timber should be taken last. But that is not the way it happens in Tasmania. It is not the way it happens in many parts of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Because of the economics of the situation in Tasmania, tree-fellers go in and flatten the forests. Because of the economics of the situation and the concession system, the best eucalypt logs go to the woodchippers. The remainder is often burned on the ground. Sometimes the small sawmillers are allowed to come in and salvage. But often they are not allowed to do this. As a matter of fact, many of them have now gone out of business. So the policies are destroying the jobs and the forests.

A new awareness of all this has happened in the last few months. A new alliance is being formed because of the realisation that the wood is almost gone. All that is left really is the wood in the National Estate areas and the wilderness areas.

The most extraordinary thing happened last week in Canberra that I have seen in my 20 years as an environmentalist. I do not know why the media did not take note of the coalition between Ken Bacon, the State Secretary of the Transport Workers Union in Tasmania; Mr Shaun Brooks, the spokesman for the log hauliers executive on the east coast; representatives of the east coast Chamber of Commerce in Tasmania; and Alec Marr, a representative of the Wilderness Society. They were making a plea to Senator Richardson, Senator Cook and anyone else who would listen, for the establishment of a World Heritage area in the south-west to stop a road which would serve another pulp mill. All the representatives of these various generally opposing forces were saying, `The State cannot tolerate another woodchip mill. We do not have the resource and jobs will suffer. Please, do not let Robin Gray ram this down our throats'. That was the message of this group. I hope that this heartfelt message will have an impact upon Senator Richardson, from whom we will hear later in this debate, because there is a realisation at last that commonsense may in fact prevail in Tasmania. This is not the first time that people in the industry have shown their concern. During the Helsham Commission of Inquiry into the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests a number of people made submissions and some of them were actually workers in the industry. I have a letter to Ray Groom, who is the Minister for Forests, which was subsequently, I think, in the Helsham evidence. It states:
Dear Sir,
I represent the Australian Newsprint Mills Treefellers, who as a group are responsible for the felling and manufacture of over 300,000 M3/annum of timber from the A.N.M.-
that is, Australian Newsprint Mills-
concession area.

We are certain that given correct harvesting procedures and pricing structures we can lift production levels of both saw and veneer logs by 50% or 30,000 m3/annual utilising the same amount of resource. I am sure the benefits of this would be immediately obvious to yourself. The situation of A.N.M. being responsible for the harvesting, segregation, and allocation of all timber from the concession is on a par with making Sir Lesley Colin Paterson responsible for security at a distillery.
This is not a greenie, this is a tree-feller; this is a man who represents tree-fellers. The letter continues:

We also believe that the delegations from the Tasmanian Timber Industry are not truly representative of the majority of people employed in the industry, but are dominated by self interest groups. The Tasmanian Logging Association (T.L.A.) for example is funded indirectly by companies by a . . . subsidy to their contractors which is then deducted and deposited in the T.L.A. coffers. Huon Forest Products (H.F.P.) would have to be the greatest example of crony-ism since the Marcos Regime in an effort to monopolise the last remaining large stands of sawlog between Messrs. Clennet, Risby, Kemp and A.N.M. without regard to traditional small sawmillers.
That is the secretary of the ANM tree-fellers group. I have a submission from John Greg Reynolds of Karanja, who is a contract tree-feller. He states:

This submission is made on behalf of 18 Contract Tree Fellers who work in the ANM concession. We are piece-workers and make a living from the quantity of timber we are able to produce. We are concerned that the incentive is on volume production rather than quality recovery. It is not worth our while to take the extra trouble to save quality sawlogs when we can make more money by concentrating on volume without regard to the content of the timber produced. Our main source of income is pulp quality timber. Our experience has shown that we can make more money by concentrating on pulp rather than taking the extra care and time to segregate other classes of timber. Sawlogs and minor species are only a by-product of pulp cutting on our job.
Tomorrow I am due to start in a stand of high-quality timber with up to six truck lengths in a stem.
That means that six truckloads of wood come from one tree. The submission continues:

It is very flat even going. I will have to fall all this timber at once over itself. This will result in unavoidable breakages of both pulp and mill timber. If this were cat logged much of this breakage could be avoided. The job I will be doing is cable logging which in my view should not be allowed on flat country like this where conventional logging would not seriously disturb the environment.
That submission is from a contract tree-feller. I have a submission from another man, Peter Barry Simpson of New Norfolk, who is also a contract tree-feller. He states:

Minor species are deliberately masked in the bush during our operations because of the excessive amount of time required to produce sawlogs and process the logs. With cable logging if you fall big timber first you smash the small stuff and also make some of it too dangerous to fall. If you fall and process the minor species and smaller timber first, it is lying on the ground cut and is likely to be smashed when you fall the big timber.

That is signed by P. B. Simpson. These people work in the industry and are concerned about what is going on in the industry. What does the industry do? What is it on about? It is on about making money. At the moment it wants to make money with a fourth woodchip mill-Huon Forest Products. Huon Forest Products ownership is: Australian Newsprint Mills, 60 per cent-incidentally, that is News Ltd; Risby, 20 per cent; Kemp, 5 per cent; B. G. Clennet, 5 per cent; W. A. Mackay, 5 per cent; and J. W. Porta, 5 per cent. Risby, Kemp, B. G. Clennet and Mackay were the four sawmillers who set up Triabunna woodchip mill and sold out to North Broken Hill at a massive profit, and now they are trying it again after destroying much of the forest. Because of the bad logging practices of ANM and the smashing of sawlogs in particular, the Premier, Robin Gray, was not game to give the whole of southern Tasmania over to ANM immediately, so these sawmiller partners may stay in the consortium for a few years and then sell out to ANM.

The man running Huon Forest Products is Steve Balcombe. Steve Balcombe started his career as a hydro-engineer. He was then in the Premier's Department at the time the Huon Forest Products deal was set up. ANM later hired him as a public relations officer and Huon Forest Products made him its general manager. He is now logging manager for ANM, but will also have control over logging operations at Huon Forest Products. He felt moved to write a memorandum to his directors on 16 February 1988. I will read part of it:

On Sunday, 14 February, DWF and I met with Ray Groom, John James and David Quinn over breakfast at the Imperial Hotel, Tokyo. I had requested the meeting with Groom in order to discuss on an informal basis the issues currently affecting our project.
Ray Groom, incidentally, is the Minister for Forests in the Tasmanian Government. The memorandum continues:
Groom indicated that tactics would have to be handled carefully and suggested that the Government would prefer if APM-
that is Australian Paper Manufacturers Ltd-
and HFP-
that is Huon Forest Products-

work out a deal independently for presentation to the State and then the Federal Government. He was concerned about his previous public statements, that additional wood was available to supply APM. He therefore felt that for political reasons any supply proposal would have to include-
this is for political reasons now-
a plantation component.

This was not because of the conservation of wood or anything else, but for political reasons. Honourable senators should look at the collusion. Here is Huon Forest Products getting together with the Minister for Forests and APM and working together to try to get more of the public forests and more of the public land under private control. The memorandum continues:
I asked him how he saw the whole business of APM, HFP, APPM's-
that is, the Associated Pulp and Paper Mills Ltd-

Northern Pulpmill and the Helsham business finishing up. He said that he genuinely expected to see both APM and HFP operational and that this was very much in the Government's interest politically in the South. This confirmed my earlier thoughts in this regard. He stressed the political importance of HFP being in operation before the next State election. I said that we knew that we were going to get there in the end but that our Shareholders were becoming increasingly concerned about the extent of the delays and their exposure in this project. Groom understood this and stressed that we must be patient and our perseverence will pay off in the end.

Here we have collusion at the highest level between the State Government and the representatives of the woodchippers, doing everything they can to give away the forests. This is not a forestry Minister trying to rationally use the resource; here is a man trying to give away the trees as rapidly as possible. Australian Newsprint Mills, incidentally, is one of the most wasteful operations in Tasmania. It burns over 50,000 tonnes of timber per year, and that is about 1,000 tonnes per week. The combined environment groups, in their final submission to the Helsham inquiry, estimated that ANM pulped at least 30,000 tonnes of category 1 sawlogs per year. In 1984, ANM pulped 95,000 tonnes of category 1 sawlogs, according to a Forestry Commission survey. Brian Gibson, who is the managing director of Australian Newsprint Mills, in a letter to the Hobart Mercury on 24 November 1983 stated:

To make ground wood pulp suitable for the manufacture of newsprint, ANM requires old growth eucalypts of the same quality used by sawmillers to produce scantling and framing grade timber. Since this grade of log is not in short supply in Tasmania as a whole, there is no subsequent loss to the sawmilling industry.
Since that time many small sawmillers have had to close down. Here is the admission that they use sawlogs, but a denial of the fact that it has any importance.

The Huon Forest Products project will actually cost jobs; it will take timber and it will cost jobs. The Triabunna Log Truck Drivers and Transport Union estimates that 324 jobs will be lost if this project goes ahead. Sixty-five per cent of the Southern Forests in the area recommended for World Heritage listing by the Australian Heritage Commission have been left out of the area protected by Cabinet. Huon Forest Products is designed specifically to destroy all the southern areas that are not in this Cabinet area.

Senator Richardson is looking at me with interest. I am sure we will hear his comments. Huon Forest Products is designed to take the forests that Cabinet has decided not to protect. If Huon Forest Products goes ahead, there is no way that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) can honour his promise to protect the National Estate. The proposed road over the Snowy Range through the area that the Prime Minister on national television promised secure protection for must be rejected. If it goes ahead, it will destroy that area. The Southern Forests are already being over-cut by 123,000 tonnes because APM has started up again. But the woodchip operations have not been stopped. Wesley Vale, the new pulp mill in the north, will use 1.8 million tonnes and cost $1 billion to build. That is about as much as Parliament House and all that plant down there will do is munch timber.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's not going to use extra resources.

—I hope that the honourable senator is right but I do not think that he is. If he believes that it will not use extra resources he is just deluding himself, because it will. Has anyone in this chamber ever seen the major timber companies not get what they want? They always get what they want at the expense of the small sawmillers and the forests. The likely scenario is as follows: Premier Robin Gray will build all the proposed projects-Huon Forest Products and Wesley Vale-and will keep Associated Pulp and Paper Mills in the south operating. He will keep the woodchip mills operating. This will result in massive over-cuts. In 10 years, the rotation lengths will be reduced from 90 to 60 years. This will give us enough pulpwood to keep going but will wipe out the sawmilling industry. This is what the sawmillers are concerned about.

SPEECH.PARA: I hear nattering over there from the Tasmanian troglodytes. If they want to, all they have to do is read the reports of the bush workers. They should get out into the bush and talk to the workers, but they are afraid. The Liberal Government in Tasmania is not going well. (Quorum formed) In the small time remaining I will quote Darryl Brown, a mountain river sawmiller, who has more sense than the Opposition. He says that people can no longer say they do not know; they can only say that they do not care. This demonstration by Senator Puplick of the calling of a quorum shows that the Opposition does not care. I will be very interested to hear Senator Richardson's remarks to see whether the Government cares.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course the Government cares. In particular, I care. Yes, I was looking at Senator Sanders several times during his contribution mainly because today he is wearing a clean shirt and tie, and a rather nice coat. I was very impressed. I would like to return to the matter of public importance of the day which is:

SPEECH.PARA: The serious threat to jobs and the National Estate posed by present logging practices and policies in Tasmania.

In fact, Senator Sanders did not speak about it. Largely, his speech has been about Huon Forest Products Pty Ltd and whether its plan ought to go ahead. I should begin by making a couple of comments on HFP. The discussions between the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook), me, Premier Gray, and his Forests Minister, Mr Groom, after Cabinet had made its decision in the Helsham Commission of Inquiry into the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests, to some extent concerned HFP. It was agreed between the four Ministers that the Tasmanian Government would have to satisfy the Commonwealth as to the adequacy of resources for HFP. At no point in time were the Tasmanians certain that all that resource existed. The calculations given to us at the time by the Premier of Tasmania were obviously still subject to some proving and checking. It is only in the last week that we have had some firm figures on that resource from the Tasmanian Government. It took three or four months to get these figures to us even in what is not yet a finalised form. I have not yet seen the evidence so I am unable to say just what it is.

The Premier informed us that to get the resource that HFP required at the time, many practices had to be improved. These included as an example, the enhanced recovery of small wood. Obviously, in the discussions that we had with the Tasmanian Government, the Cook-Groom package involved improving those practices. As Senator Sanders rightly mentioned, last week there was a very strange delegation from Tasmania which was different from the usual delegation of strange Tasmanians. This delegation comprised representatives of the Transport Workers Union of Australia, of forest workers, of owner-drivers who work for the companies by delivering the logs, as well as representatives of small business. They were united in their opposition to HFP because of the employment consequences in other places. That came as a surprise to me. They drew to my attention the fact-this has not been mentioned so far; it caused me great concern and certainly was not mentioned by either Premier Gray or Mr Groom in conversations I have had with them-that resources would have to be taken away from Tasmanian Pulp and Forest Holdings (TPFH) and Forest Resources to enable the HFP proposal to go ahead. I think that this is pretty worrisome. If HFP is to go ahead it ought to be able to stand on its own.

It disturbs me that there is now the prospect-I understand it has even been put in writing by the Tasmanian Government-that very substantial reductions in the quotas currently allowed for TPFH and Forest Resources would be taken away. I have yet to take this up with my colleague Senator Cook, but I will certainly be doing that in the next week because it causes me great concern. Nonetheless, the Commonwealth's undertaking on HFP only goes so far as to say that we will be prepared to grant approval for export licences provided it is demonstrated that the resource is there. At this stage that has certainly not been demonstrated. If one looks at what Senator Sanders was supposed to be talking about today, one sees that his actual words were `the serious threat to jobs and the National Estate posed by present logging practices and policies in Tasmania'. The very fact that after the Cabinet decision on the Helsham inquiry there have been such prolonged negotiations with the Tasmanian Government on the prospect of a further agreement on practices suggests that the Tasmanian Government and the industry who have both been involved in those discussions with Senator Cook, acknowledge that there have been problems in past practices.

Obviously, if one were to go through the records of the Helsham inquiry, the evidence that there were problems in past practices is there for all to see. There is a whole range of areas in which forest practice could have been improved and, indeed, should have been improved. The first one I would like to mention is this penchant which the industry has now for cable logging. The purpose of cable logging, as it was first explained to me, was simply to get into areas that were very difficult for access, and it was said that this new technique would provide the access. Yet we discover at the inquiry that one company, Australian Newsprint Mills Ltd, proposed to knock down 60 per cent of the southern forests by cable logging. That is not an area where it is all hard to get at. The fact is that cable logging did provide a cheaper way of doing it, but it really meant cheaper if the company was interested in pulp or chips. It has caused and does cause a great increase in waste.

There is no doubt that if we are to turn the industry over to cable logging in the way that was proposed for the southern forests by at least one company, we are going to increase the amount of waste and obviously decrease the amount of sawlogs, and that is, and must be, a very real consideration. The real scream about the Commonwealth's decision on the Helsham inquiry was what was going to happen to the sawlog industry and what was going to happen to the veneer industry. Yet the same people who are doing the screaming about those two industries are prepared to countenance forest practices which of themselves limit the viability of those industries-but not just the current viability. What they propose to advocate are practices which shorten their life span.

I love the terms used by the Tasmanian Forestry Commission. When it talks about its policy for old growth forests-for `old growth' read `natural forest'-what it proposes to do is liquidate them over 55 years. I love the term `liquidate'. It gives one some idea of the feelings of the Tasmanian Forestry Commission towards the last remaining natural forests in Tasmania. Is it any wonder that the Commonwealth was forced to move to make sure that some of those old growth forests have been protected? As I explained in response to a question here last week, if one looks at what that final response might be, one sees that there is still some time to go-although I hope it is only a matter of days now-before I can announce what the final boundaries of the area to be protected ought to be.

The first thing to look at with loss of jobs, if that is what Senator Sanders is complaining about, is that it is not a new thing. There have been thousands of jobs lost in the Tasmanian timber industry in the last two decades. They were not lost because greenies were lying down in front of bulldozers; they were not lost because the nasty Commonwealth came in and stopped people from logging forests. They were lost for two reasons. For a start, the move into woodchips meant fewer jobs. It was always going to mean fewer jobs, and that is how it has turned out. Secondly, improved efficiency in the forests meant that fewer people were needed there. Job numbers had dramatically declined over two decades, and the trend had not stopped. There was no sudden break in the trend, and if any Tasmanian senator can show it to me, I shall be fascinated. There has been no break in that trend; it continued over two decades. Whether or not the Commonwealth had taken the decision it did in respect of the Helsham inquiry, that trend would have continued further.

I believe that, having taken the decision we have taken and offering to the Tasmanians a very generous package to help not only in restructuring the industry but also in improving the practices of which we are now speaking, we can give some floor to employment in the industry. We can make sure that those people who have jobs in the industry are able to keep them, and that is a promise that they have not had before. As I said, jobs have been lost for year after year after year.

Let us look at the elements of the package Mr Groom, the Tasmanian Minister for Forests, and our own Minister for Resources have been looking at. It gives some idea of the real acknowledgment of the problems by both the Tasmanian Government and the industry itself. The industry package which Senator Cook has been looking at includes an upgrading of the forest practices code as its first element. It has got to be upgraded because the current forest practices code just is not good enough. There is also going to be consideration of a bounty for veneer logs to ensure that the stock of wood for the veneer industry is maintained. If one remembers Mr Whish-Wilson and the evidence he gave to the Helsham inquiry, he was able to show pretty conclusively-and I have not yet seen the evidence challenged-that one of the main reasons why there was a waste, and I might say a very significant waste, of veneer logs was that those people actually working in the forest were not paid enough to go to the trouble of separating the veneer logs from the rest. What it has meant is that it is not just rubbish that goes into the chip mills and pulp mills. There is no question that millable timber has been wasted in chip mills and pulp mills in the past, and it is that sort of waste that we have got to stop.

TALK.START.PARA: —The distant past.

—If it is in the distant past, why is it that one of the planks that Senator Cook and Mr Groom have been looking at is the stationing of inspectors at woodchip mills to make sure it does not happen now? The reason is that not even the industry says it never happens; only Senator Watson says that. It does happen from time to time. There is no question that it has got better over the past 12 months. Equally, there is no question that it still sometimes does occur, and it must be watched. Both the Government and the industry acknowledge it, so why cannot Senator Watson?

SPEECH.PARA: That is only one aspect of the agreement that Mr Groom and Senator Cook are looking at. They are also looking at the greater use of smallwood, as well they might. Premier Gray and the Tasmanian Government, having virtually ignored smallwood for years and years, are now faced with claiming that a significant percentage of the wood that will be used by HFP will come from extra smallwood recovery. The whole industry has had to gear itself up for that because finally-I might say, years too late-they have had to acknowledge what sort of waste has gone on before. Senator Cook and Mr Groom are also looking at the development of more flitch mills, obviously in the end for the same purpose-to make sure we cut down on the waste of millable timber, and it is waste that has been unnecessary and at times outrageous. Anyone who has been to Tasmania and watched what happens after a logging operation has been completed and looks at how much is burnt on the forest floor has to be appalled. One has only to talk to small sawmillers-it does not have to be selected ones-and they will tell one how much is wasted. They say they could make a living from what is wasted on the forest floor but they are prevented from doing so.

Senator Cook's package goes further than that. We have to look at that problem of cable logging; we are going to try to find a strict definition for the ways in which cable logging can be continued in Tasmania. If we get that then, hopefully, we can solve at least some of the problems. There needs to be very substantial encouragement for furniture design in Tasmania to make sure that the craft industries are built up. Again, that is part of the package that Senator Cook is looking at. We must check to make sure that inefficiency and waste are checked at every step along the production line of the forests. That is what we are about now.

TALK.START.PARA: —Three thousand five hundred Tasmanians are already employed in woodcraft.

—I cannot hear Senator Watson's interjection. I am sure that it was extremely interesting, but I am in the fortunate position of not being able to hear him. I note that Senator Sanders mentioned Wesley Vale and what should happen or will not happen there. The Commonwealth accepted the environmental impact statement (EIS) on resource for Wesley Vale-I am not sure whether it was prepared in 1984 or 1985. Therefore, the EIS process which has been agreed with the Tasmanian Government, and which takes place as we speak, was undertaken on the basis of looking at the environmental effects of the Wesley Vale Mill itself; not on resource effects, because there had already been an EIS on that point. I can only repeat to Senator Sanders what I have said publicly, which is that at the end of the period, which was extended by one week by Noranda, I will look at the public comments that we have received. I shall deal with those comments as they come in. My Department is conducting a review of the EIS as well. If I am convinced, at the end of the day, that the environmental safeguards are not good enough, I have the option of doing two things: that is, either recommending to my colleagues that extra conditions be placed upon any permission to go ahead or, alternatively, recommending to my colleagues that the development should not go ahead at all. That is what I shall do once I have had the opportunity to have a proper look at this.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to go into some of the areas of waste on the forest floor which were not referred to by Senator Sanders. The report of the Helsham Commission was critical, to say the least, of management by the Forestry Commission of Tasmania. It described the forestry administration as `a complex structure of higgledy-piggledy ad hoc institutional arrangements'. My observation of what is happening in Tasmania suggests that that is true. In looking at forest resource planning in Tasmania, the report went on to say that it involved a `maze of assumptions, uncertainties and judgments'. That is one of the real problems.

When we looked at the Helsham inquiry to try to get a proper Commonwealth response, it was virtually impossible to get accurate resource data because the Tasmanian Forestry Commission, which has been operating in Tasmania for years, was never able to provide the Commonwealth with that information, mainly because it did not have it itself and had to admit so each time we asked. If this was all so efficient and if the answers were all as easy as the Tasmanian Government and many Opposition senators have claimed in the last 12 months, why is it that not even the Tasmanian Forestry Commission can give us any answers? I suspect the reason is that the issues are so complex that an organisation even as big as the Tasmanian Forestry Commission has not had the time to go in and get the data because the pressure has been on it just to manage the cutting. So the planning base for the cutting has never been good enough. If one looks at the revisions of the Tasmanian Forestry Commission, particularly in the 1980s, it has to be resoundingly acknowledged that the practices of the 1960s and 1970s were just too hot-even for the Tasmanian Government. It has had to pull back in the 1980s.

This Government will try to ensure a real future for those in the industry. At all times we have attempted not just to promote employment growth in the economy generally but to make sure that we can achieve that. There will be special enhancements in the Cook-Groom package for plantation forestry, which has to be one of the big answers for Tasmania. I would have liked to have gone into plantation forestry a little deeper, but my time is up. All I can say is that there has been waste. However, let us not look at the past and the waste that we have seen. Let us hope that Senator Cook and Mr Groom come up with a package that ensures that that waste does not go into the future and that jobs can be maintained.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has before it a matter of public importance in these terms:

SPEECH.PARA: The serious threat to jobs and the National Estate posed by present logging practices and policies in Tasmania.

During his address Senator Sanders ranged widely over a large number of matters concerning the forestry industries, not just those in Tasmania but indeed around the whole of Australia. But it was not until the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) spoke that there was very much focus on actual logging practices and policies which are the alleged basis of Senator Sanders's matter of public importance.

I want to start by making some comments on the Minister's speech and then saying something about the forest products industry in general, as well as something specifically about the practices undertaken in Tasmania at the moment. I do not believe that the purport of Senator Sanders's matter of public importance was addressed in his opening speech. It was an attempt, once again, to revive a large number of claims about the political situation in Tasmania, the appalling behaviour which he always attributes to the Tasmanian State Government, and a general whinge about the lack of success which his party has had in changing the nature of the debate in Australia, which has now got back to a more substantial debate about the benefits which can be derived for Australia as a nation by the proper application of intelligent principles of forestry management and economic analysis to the timber industry in Australia.

However, it was even more difficult to work out which side of the debate Senator Richardson was on. By the time that he had concluded speaking only a number of small points of particular relevance had been addressed. The most important of them was, quite clearly, for the Minister to indicate that he does note regard the Wesley Vale development as a foregone conclusion. For all of the great trumpeting which we had from the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) just a couple of weeks ago, Senator Richardson was saying suddenly, that, at the end of the day, a significant development, the largest investment in manufacturing industry that has ever been planned in Australia-a billion dollar investment about which everybody could be very happy because it would provide income, jobs and some certainty-may not go ahead. He said, `If I am not satisfied, it may not go ahead'. Despite the fact that there is to be no chance for examination of this immediate proposal through a contemporary environmental impact statement-we are to rely on figures produced for a 1985 study, which I raised with the Minister during the Estimates committee hearings-and despite all of the hype given to this proposal by the Prime Minister and the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, the Minister for the Environment now says, `Perhaps Wesley Vale will not go ahead anyway'.

There are two other points arising from Senator Richardson's speech to which I wish to allude. One was his criticism of the Forest Practices Code, as it is formally called in Tasmania, which he sought to denigrate to a very large extent during this debate while at the same time attempting to have two bob each way by admitting that there have been some substantial improvements in the operation of the timber industry in Tasmania in the last 12 months. The other was simply that he ignored the work which has already been done, and the developments which have already been made, within the craft industries of Tasmania related to forest products. In fact, some 3,500 people in that State are involved in what one might call wood craft operations, and that is likely to increase substantially in the next couple of years.

I would now like to say something about the Australian forest products industry in general and I will try to put this within some overall context. The forest product industry straddles both the rural and manufacturing sectors and involves a degree of downstream processing in some areas of the exploitation of the nation's timber resources. The industry is highly concentrated, in the sense that it has a small number of large establishments supplying a diverse range of products which encompass sawn timber, wood panels, woodchips, wood pulp and some paper products. Although ownership is very much concentrated among the large operators, it is also an industry which has an enormous amount of diversity, including regional diversity. For instance, there is a thriving sandalwood industry in Western Australia. Obviously, that tends not to be perceived in the same fashion as forest product industries are perceived in other parts of the country or when we are dealing with other timber resources.

The sale of forest products in 1986-87 was in the vicinity of $3 billion, just over one per cent of the total output of the Australian economy. As honourable senators would know, there are a large number of alternative plans floating around in terms of public discussion. We have had a document from the Australian Conservation Foundation, which I think is called The Wood or the Trees. That document proposes a series of developments for the maintenance of forest products and the timber industry in Australia. We have had the Forestry and Forest Products Industry Council (FAFPIC) plan calling for $11 billion of capital investment in the industry over the period to 2030, which is also very much tied up with the Wesley Vale development. A number of studies have been undertaken in Australia, including the study by a Finnish company whose name, if I recall it correctly, is Jakko-Porry, which analysed the international competitiveness of the Australian forest products industry, and found that it was in fact very good in terms of international comparisons.

We have heard a number of claims about the extent of the impact of forest products on the deficit, in terms of claiming that between $1.3 billion and $1.6 billion is the shortfall compared with timber and forest product exports from Australia balanced against imports of various forest products, primarily imports of paper, and the necessity of doing something about reducing that element of the trade deficit. It was estimated in a publication by the ANZ Bank in April 1988 that the `industry currently provides jobs for around 250,000 persons directly and indirectly', and that if the FAFPIC proposal were to go ahead, that could rise by perhaps 50 per cent. The statistics of the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) on this matter show that direct employment in forest industries in 1984-85 was calculated by the ABS at 107,900. So we are not talking about a small industry. It is very often believed, when one is talking about the forest product industry, that it is a small industry and that it is not in the big league of Australian primary products or the manufacturing sector, yet it is. For instance, if we look at an article which appeared in the Business Review Weekly on 21 October 1988, we can see the potential which in alluded to there for international markets in eucalypt pulp, again with some clear indication that this is an area where there is a capacity for an expansion of our activities and for considerable economic benefit to Australia.

I turn to the immediacy of the co-called forest practices code, which was promulgated in a document put out by the Forestry Commission of Tasmania in March 1987. That code seeks to provide a regime which, in the Commission's words, `is important to care for environmental values during harvesting operations'. It goes on:

The Forest Practices Code provides a set of standards to protect environmental values during forest operations. The Code is designed to take a practical approach to the protection of the following environmental values; soils, water quality and flow, site productivity, flora and fauna, landscape, archeology, karst.
It goes on to indicate:
The Code contains policies and practices which have been developed as a result of ongoing research and practical experience over many years.

There have been a large number of studies in Tasmania about the future development of the timber industry in that State-for example, the study undertaken by the late Senator Everett and Dr Gentle, which drew attention to the importance of private forestry in Australia and the importance of forestry to Tasmania in general. It stated:
In a state where one in seven Tasmanians depend on forest-based economic activity for employment, the private forests contribute significantly to the economic welfare of Tasmanians.

In a study done by Professor Peter Pearse, the Chairman of the Forest Economics and Policy Research Unit at the University of British Columbia in Vancouver, Canada, which was produced in September 1987, Professor Pearse makes this point: `. . . the opportunities for development in forestry and the forest industry in the State appear to be very promising'. He goes on to say that he believes that the opportunities are not being fully exploited, and one of the reasons is that forestry on private lands is being, in his words, `artificially suppressed'. So one can see that in Tasmania there is considerable scope for the expansion of forest activities in terms of creating employment, in terms of economic return and in terms of the benefit which will accrue not only to the Tasmanian economy but to the national economy as a whole.

I believe that, as with any operation, it is always possible to do better. The Forestry Commission of Tasmania has, over the last five or six years, I think, attempted to lift its act substantially. When I look at, for instance, the document entitled Visual Management System produced in November 1983, I think it would now not be accepted as in any sense the state of the art in forestry practices a mere five years later. If we look at the management plan for the Douglas Apsley region, which came out in December 1987, we can see substantial improvements over that earlier document, the Visual Management System. In the most recent document which I have seen from the Tasmanian Forestry Commission, dated October 1988, entitled Draft Management Plan for Tree Ferns in Tasmania's Crown Forests, I think once again we can see that there has been a continual attempt by the Forestry Commission in Tasmania to upgrade the amount of research and to upgrade the degree of regulation and control which it exercises over the State's forest resources.

I believe the Tasmanian Government, through the Forestry Commission, has attempted to manage its forests in the most economic and environmentally effective method. I do not in any sense resile from the comment Senator Richardson made that there is scope for improvement. Of course there is scope for improvement. But I believe that to date the basis upon which Senator Sanders has drawn this matter of public importance has not been in any sense adequately established. I believe it is possible for logging and forestry practices in Tasmania to continue to be upgraded in a way which is not a serious threat to jobs and the National Estate, but which provides adequate protection for the National Estate and considerable capacity for expanding employment. Through expanding employment we will be able to improve the living standards of the people of Tasmania and, indeed, all the people of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad that Senator Puplick finished by referring to some of the documents which have recently been published in Tasmania relating to the aesthetic and various other characteristics of forestry management because this indicates, as he said, a rapid evolution of that thinking. However, it was distressing that Senator Puplick drew from that point that that very short term view was in any way valid when dealing with matters relating to forestry management and the important biological and aesthetic values which relate to the preservation of those forests.

SPEECH.PARA: It is worth reminding ourselves that we are dealing with a resource which has been around for a very long time. We are dealing with values which were not only important in our own evolution but which will be important throughout the continuing existence of human life on this planet, if we do not damage the planet too much. The period which people like Senator Puplick take as the norm, the period of rapid industrial development which has occurred over the last 150 to 200 years, is a most abnormal period in human evolution and development. It is distressing that Senator Puplick has no sense of a longer term history. Human beings have been around for perhaps six million years, some 400,000 generations. Through most of that time we were gatherers and hunters and we lived in forests. Those are the conditions to which we are biologically adapted and still are adapted. We have been settled in cities for about 400 generations; we have been industrial men and women for about eight generations. That is far too little time to become biologically adapted to these changed circumstances. To suggest that the guideposts that we should use in our management of the environment should be taken from this extremely short period in our history is to misunderstand totally the true nature of biology.

The second point I wish to dwell on for a moment is that in recent times we have become aware of significant changes in environment. This will mean that many of the areas we have set aside for the preservation of genetic diversity will be in the wrong place. Many of our national parks will not be able to continue to preserve those species of plants and animals for which they were set aside. Therefore, it becomes necessary to manage not just the national parks as areas of protection for genetic diversity, but also the whole landscape so that species of animals and plants will be able to migrate as the weather changes. That suggests a totally different view from the view that came from both Senator Richardson and Senator Puplick.

Mention was made of the loss of jobs, and yet we find that no less a person than Mr Shaun Brooks, from the log hauliers, certainly not a greenie, said that with this Wesley Vale development the number of jobs in his area will drop by 324, yet the replacement will be only 75 jobs. Therefore, the number of jobs consequent on this sort of development will not increase, but rather will decrease according to those intimately associated with those employments.

There has been considerable overcutting of the forests of Tasmania in the past, a subject which has already been alluded to. One would have hoped that in view of that there would have been a program for reducing the amount of forest that is cut and increasing the value added to those logs which are cut. But that is not what we see when we contemplate the development of a woodchip mill. One cannot imagine a less value added activity in relation to forestry than simply taking trees out of forests and turning them into chips for export.

I believe that the Minister for Resources, Senator Cook, has a copy of the submission from Premier Gray in which he proposes to increase the quota for chip exports from Tasmania-and this despite the fact that only three years ago there was an environmental impact statement (EIS) into Tasmania's woodchipping and at that stage the limits which the forests could bear were set. I believe that Premier Gray now says that that EIS, only three years on, is out of date. We have seen a substantial loss of the availability of saw logs. In 1970 one million cubic metres of saw logs were cut; by 1985 that figure was down to 875,000 cubic metres.

The matter of the type of logs which can be grown is dealt with by Professor Kirkpatrick, the new head of geography at the University of Tasmania. He draws attention to the impact of woodchipping on the ability to grow mature trees for saw logs. Professor Kirkpatrick says that he fears the remaining private forests will be decimated and the time for forest regeneration cut drastically. He draws attention to the fact that it takes some 80 years for saw logs to be produced, but only about 40 years for maximum growth for pulp. He said on this topic:
If there is an increased flow of wood, then almost certainly there will be a shortening of the rotation of forests, with the inevitable result that in 80 years we will have no saw logs.

There is no doubt that the Tasmanian Government is intent on increasing the cut of Tasmanian forests. For instance, the Launceston Examiner, not a paper remarkable for its pro-environmental stance, said in a recent article:
Senator Cook confirmed he had received an informal approach from the Tasmanian Government to increase the State's export quota, currently 2.9 million tonnes a year.
The article continues:

Of the State's 2.9 million tonne export quota 1.8 million is expected to be taken by the proposed new Wesley Vale mill which leaves 1.1 million tonnes to be shared between Forest Resources and APPM at Long Reach, Tasmanian Pulp and Forest Holdings and HFP.
However, the allocation of 500,000 tonnes of this remainder to HFP would seriously threaten the viability of Forest Resources and TPFH.

There is no doubt from the material that is coming out that there has been a substantial desire by the Tasmanian Government to increase the cut, despite the fact that these matters were well researched in an environmental impact statement only three years ago.

Finally, I wish to deal briefly with a report from two law professors of the University of Oregon who are currently visiting Australia, John Bonine and Michael Axline. They have commented extensively on the inadequacy of the environmental impact statement which has been prepared for the Wesley Vale development-a development which, as has been mentioned several times, involves proposed expenditure of $1,000m. These two American professors of environmental law point out that there will be substantial flows of dioxin-and I think they are referring specifically to the 2,3,7,8 TCDD dioxin, which is known to be extremely toxic-coming from this mill as a consequence of the use of chlorine as a sterilant in the preparation of the pulp. They go on in their report to criticise the environmental impact statement. They say:

Sentence after sentence in the EIS on toxic effects is simply lifted or paraphrased, without quotation marks, from an advocacy article which appeared in `Scientific American' Magazine in 1986 that argued that dioxin was not a long-term threat. The writer of that article was not a toxicologist but someone who had long worked for an organisation that was funded 60 per cent by the chemical industry.

The EIS shades even the facts taken from that article. For example, the article admits that TCDD dioxin is probably the most toxic synthetic chemical known to man, `if its acute toxicity to the guinea pig, and even the rat and the mouse, is the criterion'. (the hamster is an exception in this regard.)

The EIS uses part of the sentence referring to guinea pigs, asserts that guinea pigs are `unusually' susceptible, and omits the reference to tests in rats and mice. The EIS therefore leaves the erroneous impression that the guinea pigs tests are an aberration.

More disturbing still is the EIS's treatment of evidence on cancer, birth defects, and the like. These should be the primary focus of analysis in the EIS. The EIS mentions such effects in passing, but only to argue that `nobody knows' whether animal experiments are transferable to humans, and that `the evidence available to date suggests they are not'.

As I hope most honourable senators would know, that is complete nonsense. We regularly use animals in all tests for toxicity and we relate the results of those tests directly to humans. The professors say:
Such statements are absurd.

The EIS also makes no mention of what other nations in the world are doing about pulp mill dioxins. While the Government of Tasmania pursues this Canadian-owned pulp mill project, Sweden, the world's largest pulp producer, plans `to eliminate the discharge of chlorine (the source of dioxins) entirely' from existing pulp mills, according to its Minister for the Environment. In the United States, the US Environmental Protection Agency aims `to eliminate the presence of dioxin in discharges from pulp and paper mills to the waters of the United States', according to a 1988 policy statement.

So the EIS in relation to the Wesley Vale development is being put out for public review, with only 20 copies of the EIS being made available and the period for comment being extended for only a single week. The professors state:
The Government apparently intends to remove all legal appeal rights on the EIS and adopt `fast-track' legislation to set the project in place before the public can ferret out the facts.

That is not at all unusual. We find that practice occurring with governments all around Australia at present. It is certainly occurring in my home State of South Australia, where the State Government has adopted fast track methods with respect to developments in national parks, urban developments and the like. The two American professors point out that this form of dioxin is an extremely toxic material, and the whole lie of their argument is that the environmental impact statement pays extremely scant attention to it.

So we have in the proposed development of the Wesley Vale pulp mill a proposal which poses very significant environmental hazards for the Tasmanian environment and the Tasmanian people. It almost certainly involves an increase in the cutting of forests, despite the fact that the size of the sustainable cut has previously been set at a much lower figure. Large numbers of people across a wide spectrum of areas are objecting. The trade union people, the local people, the hauliers and the environmental groups in Tasmanian oppose this development and, in addition, we have considerable evidence that this development will lead not to an increase in jobs but to a very substantial decrease in employment in that State.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aulich Sen T.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to discuss the matter of public importance proposed by the Australian Democrats in relation to the present logging practices and policies in Tasmania, which the Democrats have described as a `serious threat to jobs and the National Estate'. It is worthwhile beginning by making clear my personal view about Federal Labor Government policy in this area, to put on record the fact that I believe this Government has done more than any other government in the history of this Commonwealth not only to protect the environment in Tasmania but also to ensure that there are adequate resources available, for example, in the forestry industry, to meet the needs of the future. It has been an intelligent approach, taken within the limits of our constitutional powers. We have not done it lightly.

SPEECH.PARA: When the Federal Government has interfered or intervened in the Tasmanian situation, it has done it in many cases in the full knowledge that there would be an electoral backlash in that State. We existed from 1975 to the last election without one Tasmanian House of Representatives seat in the hands of the Australian Labor Party. We knew that the policies adopted with regard to the Franklin dam and the forests in Tasmania could be misconstrued and used politically against us. We knew that the political cost in House of Representatives elections would be particularly great, and it is only recently that the Tasmanian public has come to accept that this Federal Labor Government may well be right in the way it approaches not only the environmental issue but also the question of how best to utilise our natural resources in Tasmania, whether they be potential resources for hydro-electric power or the timber industry in that State.

The Tasmanian Government, on the other hand, under Premier Gray, has not taken a similar intelligent or sensitive approach to the environment and resource usage. It has not even been working in the interests of the majority of people who work in or invest in that industry. On too many occasions Tasmanian governments, regardless of political persuasion, have taken decisions which have not been in the long term interests of that island. We can go right back to the Lake Pedder controversy. Not only was a very beautiful area flooded, lost to humankind forever, but also a significant timber resource was flooded without planning.

TALK.START.PARA: —You can blame the State Government for that.

—Yes. I am not playing political favourites here in any way at all. I believe that all State governments in Tasmania over the years have in many ways been negligent in their responsibilities in the resource and environment area. Lake Pedder was the first example of desecration of the environment and a misuse of resources. The fact that the Hydro-Electric Commission can flood a lake without proper consultation with the Forestry Commission and timber interests and the fact that millions of super feet of Huon pine, the best wood in the world, could be flooded, gives an indication of just how poor the planning was in that time.
—It was a Labor government, wasn't it?

—I have already said that it was a Labor government. That is why I said I am not playing political favourites. The environment and natural resources and the jobs of Tasmanians come before the future of any political party in our State. It is about time we in this chamber thought about that instead of playing party politics. The issue is much bigger than that.

SPEECH.PARA: The Franklin Dam was another resource that the Hydro-Electric Commission wanted to misuse. The Gray Government was overridden, eventually in the High Court of Australia, by the Federal Labor Party. The Federal Labor Party again lost votes because of the stand it took on that issue. The Hydro-Electric Commission has now admitted that not one megawatt of the energy that would have been generated out of that scheme would have been sold. In other words, there was and is no demand for the energy that would have been produced by the proposed scheme. So, again, the Federal Labor Government in this case was vindicated in taking a hard stand in the interests not only of Tasmanians but of all Australians.

Premier Gray has been involved in a number of deals with regard to the allocation of forest resources in Tasmania. I will not name them at this stage because some are part of considerations that are before this Federal Government at the moment. It is fairly obvious to me and to most reasonably aware onlookers that the Gray Government is playing political favourites in the allocation of forest resources in Tasmania. That issue will be examined by this Government when proposals come before it. One would assume, in fact, I have confidence, that the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Senator Richardson, will give appropriate advice to Cabinet and Cabinet will take appropriate action about those proposals coming before us from Premier Gray.

Normally, one does not relish the idea of Canberra being the fount of all wisdom. The Tasmanian Government simply has not lived up to its responsbilities not only in this area but, as I indicated before, also in the area of the production of energy in Tasmania. Significant criticisms have been made of the way the Tasmanian Government has handled its forests. For example, the Helsham Lemonthyme and Southern Forests Commission of Inquiry heard evidence that indicated that there had been a significant waste of timber resource in that State, that large quantities of felled timber had been left on the forest floor to rot or be burned and that a significant quantity of saw log quality timber had been used as pulp wood despite the claims of the Tasmanian Government that the industry is `saw log driven'. This has been a contentious issue for many years. It was aired in the Tasmanian Legislative Council Select Committee on State Forestry in 1985. Things are still not getting better down there. A number of the Commonwealth industry incentives flowing from the Helsham inquiry address these issues. We are looking forward to them.

The practice of cable logging in conditions which do not warrant it may lead to the smashing of saw log quality timber, rendering it useful only for pulp. Many people who have been working in the industry have testified to that gross neglectful practice. The Tasmanian Government needs to come clean on whether it intends the industry to be geared to the highest value-added processes. As a first step, it would seem that a total review of current logging practices is necessary. This Government is not denying that. We are doing what we can, within our constitutional rights and powers, to ensure that that does happen. The Helsham inquiry also noted:

If the Forestry Commission were directed to sell the current quantities of timber at the best royalties it could get, the rates it could get for the same volumes of sales would be substantially greater for all categories of timbers.

If one looks at most of the reports that have been written about the forestry industry in Tasmania and forest practices, one will see that there is a great deal missing by way of intelligent management. That is because on the whole, particularly since the Gray Government has been in office, there has been significant intervention in that process of making decisions about the allocation and utilisation of resources. That intervention has come primarily from Premier Gray over the top of the Commission which was established to ensure, firstly, that the environment was protected; secondly, that those natural resources were used in the most effective way for the benefit of all Tasmanians and for all Australians; and, thirdly, that the Commission was set up to pay its own way.

On the whole, none of those three requirements have been met by the activities of the Forestry Commission-not because of the way the Commission operates per se but because of the political interference that has existed over the years under all State governments, but most certainly under the Gray Government. That has been a complaint made not only by environmentalists and Federal Labor Party politicians but also by many management groups in the industry. They see favourites being played through the political processes. We cannot develop a forestry industry and protect our environment in that situation.

The record in Tasmania is not a good one. The Federal Government does not intervene willy-nilly or wantonly in these issues. We know that community attitudes right around Australia are changing. Ordinary people both within the industry and outside it, and in Tasmania and on the mainland, recognise that something has to be done. That something is to plan in the long term. It is to ensure that we get the best out of that wonderful resource that Tasmania has been blessed with and at the same time to protect that environment which is unique. That is the reason why I live in Tasmania. It is the reason why many people have come back to Tasmania after living overseas at different times, particularly people who have had career opportunities elsewhere. They choose to live in Tasmania for particular reasons related to the environment and the lifestyle there.

We are not intervening unilaterally. We are intervening as a Federal Government in cooperation, where possible, with elements of industry in Tasmania and, in particular, with the State Government. The forest accord which was negotiated between Senator Cook and the Tasmanian Minister for Forests, Ray Groom, is one example. The dam compensation money-the $300m or so-which was used to offset supposed losses from the High Court of Australia decision about the Franklin dam, was agreed between the two governments.

Of course, the other group that is rarely mentioned is the group represented in the trade union movement, that is, the workers in the industry. They are perfectly aware of the abuses which go on in Tasmanian forests. They are perfectly aware of the favouritism which is played by the State Liberal Government. They are perfectly aware that their jobs have been going down the chute steadily over the past decade through misallocation of resources, underutilisation of our resource and poor planning in the long term. They are perfectly aware that, when the woodchip industry in Tasmania was established in the late 1960s and the contracts signed for them, the Forestry Commission-that was the one commission that had responsibility for this particular area-had no accurate idea of what sort of resource we were selling to the Japanese and to others.

It is a national disgrace that a commission that had that responsibility could suddenly turn around nearly a decade after those agreements were signed and say, `We have a problem. We have discovered now that the resources are not going to meet the contracts that we signed'. As everyone knows, already there has been one major reallocation-or, more particularly, a reduction in allocations to the various companies. If that particular failure of the Forestry Commission-and of the Government at the time to persuade it in the appropriate way-is so obvious, then surely we should be learning from our mistakes at that time and making sure that we do not repeat them. This Federal Government is determined that it will not repeat those mistakes. Senator Richardson is not known as a man who is naive about where votes flow or what the numbers are about in politics. Yet he is determined to ensure that, despite temporary setbacks in terms of our electoral position in Tasmania that have occurred over the past decade, we as a Federal Government will continue to push this issue so that the Tasmanian Government finally reflects changing community attitudes and finally starts to consider what the future is all about in this area.

We are not talking about just forestry practice here. Senator Sanders is perfectly capable of pushing his own political barrow in this area. The Australian Democrats have to survive as a political party. They cannot give credit to a Labor Government which has stood up courageously and lost seats for an issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have openly praised them.

—Senator Sanders has openly praised us, but he has never praised us quite enough because at the end of the day as a political issue and as a political tactic the Australian Democrats must be purer than us. SPEECH.PARA: What we are looking at here is the whole ecosystem in Tasmania. That is what is going to be under threat if we do not plan appropriately-not just jobs in the future. The whole ecosystem needs study and care in handling. The people in the forests need incentives to encourage a proper utilisation of that resource in the interests of all Australians, let alone those people in Tasmania who are directly affected in that particular job area.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn now to some of the future developments that are happening and the actual investment in money terms rather than in job terms. I note that the Australian Democrats have departed from the chamber. I might add that when a quorum was called on Senator Sanders only two of them turned up to support him. With due credit to the Government, at least the Tasmanian senators are here to listen.

Getting back to the subject, these projects will improve Australia's annual trade balance by an estimated $550m per annum, not to mention $1.5 billion of investment in Tasmania.
