When all this work is being undertaken at the Wesley Vale mill we will have 800 jobs on average for these years; at Boyer we will have 300 jobs on average for two years; and at Huon Forest Projects, Whale Point, we will have 200 jobs for 12 months or so. Because of these projects in the pipeline the lift in employment in Tasmania is very significant. I think even the Tasmanian senators on the other side of the House would have to agree with that. For the Democrats to bring this matter of public importance on today to try to make out that the Government's policy in Tasmania is costing jobs is absolutely ridiculous. As I said before, it is typical of the attacks that particularly Senator Sanders has been making on Tasmania over the last few weeks.

As far as the threat to the National Estate is concerned, if anybody needed any evidence about what is happening in Tasmania, he has only to look at the history of what has been going on over the last few years. We have had 11 public inquiries into forestry matters in Tasmania. I note that Senator Sanders has returned to the chamber. As Senator Puplick stated earlier, those 11 public inquiries resulted in the first comprehensive forest practices code, and it is acknowledged as one of the best codes in Australia. Every hectare of Crown forest logged is replaced with forest and the State forest is managed as a sustainable long term resource. We do not need to talk about the Helsham Commission of Inquiry into the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests. I think all Tasmanians know about that. The fact of the matter is that the people concerned said that they were going to abide by the umpire's decision and when the umpire gave his decision that did not suit the Government, so henceforth we have had the Minister procrastinating about what he really is going to do.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with the arrangement, I will be brief in my comments. Here we are, a gaggle of Tasmanian senators arguing about forestry yet again. Something like 18 months ago I commented that Tasmanians and perhaps all Australians were sick of the forestry argument being front-page news. I suspect that that is still true, perhaps even more so. I find it sometimes embarrassing that the situation in Tasmania and the activities of the State Government there continue to be exposed, because the situation ought to be better.

SPEECH.PARA: I am pleased that the Federal Ministers-the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson), and the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook)-are trying to bring about a more sane and balanced timber industry in Tasmania. Each of those Ministers has probably spent as much time in Tasmania in the last year or so as they have at their own homes, negotiating in Tasmania, consulting and trying to get a suitable outcome to the whole argument about the use of Tasmanian resources. I think it is important that that effort should be recognised. I reject the allegations that there is some blundering Federal interference. There are Federal responsibilities which those Ministers are trying to carry out in a very effective way. At the same time we emphasise that the timber industry is important to Tasmania. No-one is suggesting that it will or should disappear. Just because one questions some of the practices of that industry, of course it does not mean that there is some total opposition to the industry, as has been alleged in the past. But unfortunately there are sections of the industry and the Tasmanian Government which cannot help themselves and repeatedly bring embarrassment to the State.

Mr Gray may have softened his image a little recently, but he still has a `develop at all costs' mentality rather than the more balanced outlook that we would prefer. Senator Puplick, in his remarks, might have tried to put a gloss on the Federal Opposition's policies, but I am afraid it does not hide the overall lack of concern on that side of the chamber for some of these important environmental issues which are difficult to sort out. We saw in Sydney at the weekend the view that the New South Wales Liberal Party had of Senator Puplick on environmental issues by dropping him down its Senate ticket for the next election. I emphasise that the Commonwealth has rights, responsibilities and obligations under the Constitution and under Federal laws to intervene where appropriate in State activities. We cannot just have a situation where intervention in State matters is welcomed provided it is on issues that those opposite support.

To deal with some of the problems with the timber industry in this matter of public importance that Senator Sanders has raised, it is clear that the timber industry must clean up its act and behave more responsibly in using the resources. Management practices must be improved. To argue that they have improved in recent years compared to how they were in past years does not answer the problem. That is no answer to the suggestion that there are still problems in forest practices. The Helsham Commission of Inquiry into the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests was critical of the industry's forest practices. It said that too many saw logs were being chipped; that there was inadequate inspection and supervision which led to wasteful practices in the forests; that the system of payment to log fellers encouraged them to go for only the larger trees; that smaller trees were not collected and were often burned; that the minor species-those beautiful timbers of blackwood, huon pine and sassafras and so on-were also being burned; and that, therefore, the furniture industry and the craft industry were not getting as much of those species as they should.

Everyone in this building should appreciate-now, even if they did not before-the beautiful Tasmanian timbers that can provide so much value and employment in Tasmania because Tasmania has produced so much of the beautiful furniture for the new Parliament House. There has been overcutting and soil degradation because of some of the forestry practices. There has been an exaggeration of the requirements of the industry for timber resources. Even the industry itself has, from time to time, admitted that it could improve its practices. The concession system is partly to blame for this. There is talk that that perhaps ought to be changed as well. Even if there has been a comparatively improved record in recent years compared to the even more appalling forestry practices in the past, there is still a long way to go in improving the situation and modifying the loss of jobs that there has been over the years in the Tasmanian timber industry.

Great doubt remains as to whether the resource is sufficient for a sustainable yield to provide timber for all these promised investments that Senator Calvert outlined. There is no guarantee of the sorts of numbers of jobs that he is claiming in those investments, even if they go ahead. There has been a lot of puff and exaggeration about many of these projects. It reminds me of the promised expansion of industry in Tasmania, the new investments, the jobs and so forth at the time of the argument about the damming of the Franklin River. People said that if that river were not dammed there would be so much greater unemployment. They said, `If it is, there will be this industry expansion and the other industry expansion and won't it all be wonderful'. There has been no indication of the need for that power.

We also heard the wild assertions from Senator Calvert about the multiplier being used for the indirect employment from some of these new proposals. There has been a lot of scaremongering of forestry industry workers over the years by the Tasmanian Government. I am now pleased to see that many of them see through that propaganda and are more realistic about the situation. That is one thing that can be said about the current forestry debate compared to how it was 18 months or more ago when the Helsham inquiry was set up.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Walters is not in the chamber today.

—I think it is wonderful that she is not. I would not want to encourage anything from that direction. We have the problem that the Gray Government and the Federal Opposition have a perpetual and predictable opposition to even the mildest suggestion of Federal involvement in Tasmania. They cry centralism, socialism and all the rest of it. But the fact is that the Federal Government has a responsibility to involve itself where its constitutional responsibilities lie. The Federal Government has to approve exports. We cannot close our eyes to the environmental involvement of the industries concerned with those exports.

SPEECH.PARA: I will refer very briefly to a couple of the projects that have been talked about. Wesley Vale for instance, ought to be welcomed as an increase in the downstream process; that is, of producing pulp rather than chips. One has yet to be convinced that it will replace chipping; that is, it can be suggested that it might involve using more of the timber resource. Apart from that issue of whether there is enough resource and how it will be reorganised within the State, there is also the question of the location and the process. I was pleased to hear Senator Richardson emphasise that if he were not convinced about environmental issues he would recommend non-approval by the Federal Government or at the very least impose conditions on the project which, of course, depending on those conditions, may make it uneconomical.

I must confess I have not seen the environmental impact statement, but I have seen many comments about its inadequacies. Senator Coulter, in particular, made some comments about the dioxins that will be produced. Obviously, there is a lot of local concern about the Huon Forest Products Pty Ltd project from other areas such as Triabunna and the transport workers. There are worries about environmental resource and jobs. In conclusion, to allow Senator Watson time to make his comments, I emphasise that the forest practice is not just a Tasmanian domestic affair. This Government should not countenance the sort of overcutting and waste which has occurred. I am afraid that Senator Watson, Senator Calvert and others will just have to put up with the proper involvement of the Federal Government in Tasmanian forest practice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Coates for allowing me some time to participate in this debate. In the limited time available, I wish to refute the misleading and extravagant claims made by Senator Sanders and Senator Coulter of the Australian Democrats. When an important matter such as this matter of public importance is raised by a party, one would think that the party could be well represented in the chamber. In fact, in large sections of this debate, not even one member of the Democrats was in this chamber. If this matter were of importance, one would think that Senator Sanders would have at least addressed the serious threat to jobs. Only Senator Coulter seemed to put any store on that. True, it was in the matter of public importance, but why did Senator Sanders not address the issue of the matter of public importance? In fact, it is in the first line and he hardly addressed it. Only one of the Democrats speakers drew a passing reference to it. Had Senator Sanders posed this question about 12 years ago, it might have had some relevance.

SPEECH.PARA: However, he has again failed to bring himself up to date. He seems to be quite unaware-perhaps deliberately-of the progress made not only by the Tasmanian Government and by the Forestry Commission but also by the companies themselves. Only last week one company-Forest Resources-opened a new research station in Winkleigh in northern Tasmania. Things are happening all the time. There is quite a deal of progress in minimising environmental damage as a result of logging operations. One looks at the Forest Practices Act proclaimed in 1987. The Democrats failed to mention this. They failed to mention a number of other initiatives which are designed to improve forest practices and minimise damage to the environment. Senator Sanders suggests that the present logging practices and policies in Tasmania lead to a serious threat to jobs in the National Estate. That was in his matter of public importance but not in his speech. My response to this is that the present practices and policies referred to pose a threat to neither the jobs nor the National Estate.

In fact, we concede that over the past few years there has been a drop in the numbers employed in the forest operations. I strongly reject the suggestion that this is the result of the present policies and practices in Tasmania. The majority of job losses are a direct result of rationalisation and the application of high technology, machinery and modern practices. I believe that the present logging practices and policies do not threaten the National Estate. Many initiatives have been taken, not only by the State Government but also by the Federal Government, to overcome and improve the situation. Certainly in the distant past logging practices and policies may have caused some problems, and I accept that criticism, but I commend the State Government for what it has done in making progress towards improving forest practices and policies, and also because it acted quite responsibly in pushing for a higher royalty rate in its negotiations for the Wesley Vale project, even though that delayed the announcement of the scheme. This was a responsible attitude to ensure that the highest possible royalty rates were obtained from this major development in our State.

The concern of Senator Sanders about the loss of jobs-and I must say it is a new found concern; it was not evident a few years ago-indicates that even he would not have been in agreement with rapid changes in logging practices and policies as a consequence of a reduction in the work force. What we are seeing in Tasmania is a progressive and gradual evolution in practices and policies with minimum disruption to the industry. If we look at the structure at the present time, it is clear that there can be no taking of timber from private land for chipping purposes unless that adheres to a strict management plan. In fact, no woodchip company now is allowed to accept timber from private forestry unless that area is regenerated. It is said that in a few years' time the whole of the resource is going to come from replaced species and not from new Crown reserves.

If one reads the Helsham report carefully one will note that there are a number of forestry companies that take 100 per cent of their resources from regenerated timber. Considering the size of the State, 47 per cent of the island is forested and 23 per cent of the forests are privately owned, compared with only about 4 per cent of the Australian continent which is forested. This means that over one-third of the total available wood resource is in private forests. The Forestry Commission is aiming to achieve a sustainable level of timber harvest by endeavouring to bring about an improvement in utilisation and reafforestation on private land.

For example, Forest Resources was obliged to reafforest 2,000 hectares per year prior to 1986. From 1986 onwards the export chip companies have been required to reafforest five hectares for every 1,000 tonnes logged on private land. This is in line with the policy that no woodchip logs may be cut from private land unless there is an undertaking that that land will be reafforested in line with a strict and responsible management plan. That puts an end, surely, to the claim by Senator Sanders about irresponsible policies. The Government has attempted to remove disincentives and obstacles to private forestry practices. It has adopted a very responsible position. A private forestry council has been established with statutory power to appoint special committees, and the council provides various incentives for private forestry development comprising loans and grants. A separate division has been established within the Forestry Commission, called the Private Forestry Division, to administer the legislation and to promote the development of private forests.

Although Senator Sanders suggests the majority of wood cut in Tasmania goes to pulping and woodchipping operations, may I highlight a significant woodcraft industry in addition to the furniture manufacturing industry which is also dependent on timber. Woodcraft has developed over the last 20 years into the largest sector of Tasmania's prestige craft economy. There are almost 70 full time and probably about 200 part time woodcraft workers in Tasmania in addition to the 3,500 people whose hobby is woodcraft, and they sell some of their work. In fact, a highly commended course has started at the Tasmanian State Institute of Technology under Mr Tim Hull, and this is a further manifestation of progress in the education area for woodcraft skills.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT COMMITTEE ON THE NATIONAL CRIME AUTHORITY: AN INITIAL EVALUATION

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I have to say that I found the response of the Government somewhat disappointing. It did seem to me to be somewhat superficial. The two principal recommendations that were made by the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority concerned, firstly, the question of investigative teams to ensure that greater recognition was given to involvement by experienced police officers, and the response of the Government was that it would pay close attention to that recommendation. That does not advance us much further. The second recommendation concerned our advice that a senior and respected serving or former serving police officer should be included as a member of the authority. What the Government said in relation to that recommendation was that it would bear in mind the Committee's recommendations. So we really do not know whether or not the Government is accepting the recommendations that were made by the Committee, and that is disappointing.

The report by the Committee on its initial evaluation of the National Crime Authority (NCA) has been an interesting exercise. It has been particularly interesting for me, as was the response I received when I spoke on the initial report in, I thought, very moderate and reasoned terms. I spoke of the difficulties that were experienced by the NCA, particularly in dealing with certain of the police forces in Australia, especially in Queensland, where the liaison officer had already been shown to be corrupt; and of experiences that may have occurred in the past with New South Wales. I said that, regrettably, South Australia was not exempt from this situation. I had in mind that at the time there was the pending trial of the former chief of the Drug Squad in South Australia, Detective Moyes. Details of that matter were under suppression in South Australia, and I was not going to say anything that would prejudice the consideration of that case. But in reply to my simply speaking in such reasoned and concerned terms, I was subject to an incredible tirade of abuse, firstly from the State Government and then from the police association; even the Police Commissioner called a press conference, and that was particularly disappointing. The newspaper editorials then entered the fray. My hands were tied behind my back because I was not going to say anything that would be irresponsible and could put that trial into question.

What the Government and its colleagues was saying was, `Put up or shut up'. That was disappointing when the Government and the police force of South Australia knew all that I knew and therefore had the total information before them. I thought their handling of that matter was intolerable. We should be able to expect more of the South Australian Government. From then on, as you would know, Mr Acting Deputy President, we have had enormous difficulty in getting the Government of South Australia to face up to its responsibility in relation to organised crime and official corruption in South Australia. Firstly, the Government proposed to introduce an anti-corruption body within the police force, some outside influence which was clearly going to be ineffective. Then the Government said that it would set up an office of the NCA, as I had advocated from the beginning, and that was pleasing in the first instance. But then it seems from what the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate), who I am pleased to see is in the chamber, said in the Estimates Committee that the Government was looking at a downgraded version of the NCA that would be headed up by senior counsel rather than a member of the Authority. Finally the Government said it would be headed by a member of the Authority and that the Government would provide it with staff and resources.

I am pleased to hear that, but still the State Government is not bringing us fully into the picture. It will not tell State Parliament what references it will be given, and it will be effective only if it is given adequate resources. I find it a matter of great regret that the South Australian Government has had to be dragged kicking and screaming to the situation that has now been reached. An NCA office in South Australia can be very useful as a deterrent to organised crime and in countering official corruption as it has facilitated organised crime in South Australia. The Committee will continue with its responsibility of investigating the NCA's handling of the Grassby matter and the Harvey matter which arose in South Australia. It is important that we are able to assure the Senate that the NCA is carrying out its functions in the best interests of law enforcement in Australia.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT COMMITTEE ON THE NATIONAL CRIME AUTHORITY: WITNESS PROTECTION

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The Government seems to have approached the recommendations of the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority on this matter much more positively than it did the Committee's evaluation report. The Government accepts that the Australian Federal Police should assume the national witness protection role, which the Committee has recommended, and I am pleased that it has been prepared to accept that recommendation. The matter of witness protection is a difficult one. Sensitivities are involved and generally it involves the protection of accomplices-the protection of criminals. Therefore, not surprisingly, some in the community find concern with it. However, it has been shown to be one of the effective tools-perhaps one of the few effective tools-in combating serious crime in this country. The Committee came to that conclusion and felt that it was important to develop a proper protection regime in Australia that could be coordinated throughout Australia and which could better facilitate this country's law enforcement bodies.

I said when the Committee report was put down that we were most impressed with the Australian Federal Police officers for the way in which they approached this task. It was not only a dangerous task but also, as I indicated, it meant protection of those whom they had been trained in the past to apprehend. Psychologically that is not an easy thing for a police officer to do. However, they recognised that in doing so they were being part of a chain that would help reduce the unacceptable level of organised crime and official corruption which exists in this country. I am pleased that the Government has accepted the recommendation. I am pleased that the Government, therefore, has been prepared to endorse the work being done by the Australian Federal Police in this area.

I hope that this will be only a start and that the Government will properly recognise that what is necessary now is to put into being laws in both the Commonwealth and the States that will adequately protect such witnesses when their work for the state is done and they cease to be required as witnesses. Obviously, in our society it is inhumane to throw them back into an environment where they will be subjected to either death or physical violence. Once society uses these people in this way to help reduce crime, obviously we have some responsibility to look after their interests and that responsibility is generally in the form of giving them a new identity. To do that effectively requires complex changes to both Commonwealth and State law. I hope that we will see the Commonwealth and the States cooperating during the next year or two to ensure that changes are effected that will enable changes of identity to work effectively. Therefore, the whole witness protection scheme throughout Australia might become not only more effective but also a continuing inducement for those who are prepared to come forward and give evidence to do so in order to break up organised crime rings.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government's response to the report of the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority on witness protection is welcomed in some ways but, in other ways, I think that it has misread some of the report itself. Certainly, the Government accepted our main recommendation, which was the establishment of a witness protection unit under a coordinated method whereby the Australian Federal Police would provide the logistic works-the basic exercises-and State police forces could then avail themselves of the facilities offered by the Australian Federal Police. To enable all that to occur, the Committee recommended that a liaison committee be established. The Government did not accept that proposal for a liaison committee. However, the more I read of the Government's response the more I thought that what it was recommending was very similar to a liaison committee.

SPEECH.PARA: I am particularly concerned that the Government did not seem to address itself to what is, in fact, a prime legislative problem for the Commonwealth and the States. Talking within this parliamentary context, Federal Police officers, who are doing the bulk of this work-they have to do the bulk of the work with regard to the National Crime Authority-are operating under a great deal of difficulty in the witness protection area, mainly because the legislation with which they are concerned is legislation not governing the Federal Police but governing matters such as taxation and social security.

I do not want to say that Australian Federal Police officers are operating illegally, but certainly the Committee found, in terms of the evidence given to it, that those police are operating under a great deal of strain and stress in getting their work coordinated with the requirements of social security and taxation legislation. I believe that it is not good enough to wait until the States get their acts in order on this. Indeed, some of the States that gave evidence to the Committee did not seem to have a great deal of interest in this area. In fact, at least one State said that it did not have any concern because it never had any witnesses to protect. That particular State probably rued the day that it put in that submission because it has a number of people to protect now. Nevertheless, the Commonwealth has serious people to protect, not only in terms of the witnesses who came before the Committee but also in terms of subsequent successful operations by the Australian Federal Police.

If police forces under Commonwealth executive government control are to go about their business in a proper and regulated fashion, I believe that, as a matter of urgency, we must bring the laws into line with the activities those police have to carry out. If people want to know what the details of those are they are canvassed extensively in the Committee's report. They go to the heart of the operations of the Federal Police force so that our people can carry on the work which I think every member of the Committee found very impressive. We were impressed by all the Australian Federal Police personnel whom we met and by their dedication to this particularly difficult task. I do not believe that this Parliament should simply sit on its hands and allow that task to remain as difficult as it is when, in fact, it is within our legislative purview to lighten their load and enable them to engage in activities which would make the knowledge of those witnesses to the general public a lot less easy to get hold of. The two major areas which were brought to our attention time and time again were taxation and social security law. I hope that the Commonwealth will take this on as a matter of urgency and that an amending Bill will see the light of day very rapidly. I am sure that, if it does, this Parliament will want to give it a swift passage.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

Australian Capital Territory (Self-Government) Bill 1988

Mr President, for fifty-eight years self-government for the Australian Capital Territory has been an issue which has inspired considerable debate. The Australian Capital Territory (Self-Government) Bill 1988 now before the House will establish the A.C.T. as a body politic, with the legislative and executive powers and responsibilities of the States and the Northern Territory. This Bill represents the most significant transfer of power, on a population basis, since Papua New Guinea became independent. It will allow 270,000 people the same democratic rights and social responsibilities as their fellow Australians.

The A.C.T. and the City of Canberra have well and truly come of age. Canberra is the nation's capital-it is the home of many of the symbols of our nationhood-the National Gallery, the High Court, the National Library and of course this magnificent building-the home of the nation's Parliament. But, and this is often overlooked, it is also home for 270,000 people.

270,000 people live in the Australian Capital Territory. They go about the day-to-day business of their lives, working at their jobs, paying their taxes, making decisions about which school their children will go to, which doctor or hospital will care for them when they are ill-just like every other Australian. However, unlike every other person in this country-where `a fair go' is the creed by which we live-they cannot elect a member of their own community to their own government. They have no say in the decisions which affect their everyday lives.

What an extraordinary admission in a country so committed to democratic ideals, and why? Are these people somehow different from other Australians? Are they second-class citizens in some way? Do they not understand, or have opinions on, the issues that confront them daily? Can they not be trusted with their own destiny? The answer to all these questions is very simple-the only difference between these people and the rest of Australia is that they live in the Australian Capital Territory!

Is it not something of an irony, that because this is the `National Capital', the symbol of Australian democracy, it has proven too hard for us to grant its citizens that most fundamental of democratic rights-the right to look after their own affairs?

Canberra has long been regarded as a company town, with its economy inextricably tied to the public sector. Times have changed and the Territory has grown. It is now a mature City/State which can no longer look to the Commonwealth alone for the economic security of its citizens.
The development of Canberra as the national capital is now virtually complete. The development of a diversified economy, incorporating a vibrant private sector is this community's right and need.

The basis is there. Canberra already has a burgeoning tourism industry with the potential for bigger and better things. There is in place a tertiary education sector ready to make Canberra a centre of intellectual excellence and to support the development of modern, high technology industries. The ideas and the drive for Canberra's future should come from the people of this Territory. They need their own elected government to make the laws, establish the framework and provide the creative spark that will change the focus of Canberra's development to make sure that the future needs of the community are best met.
This Bill is the logical and inevitable political conclusion to the process of economic and administrative evolution which has taken place.

The administration of the Territory has been radically altered since the first serious attempts to achieve self-government a few years ago. There are no longer twelve Commonwealth departments involved in territorial matters. Functions have been consolidated in a single Administration complete with a stand-alone A.C.T. Budget.

These changes were introduced to ensure the smooth and orderly transition to self-government. The management of the Territory has now been arranged into a system that can and should be handed over to local political representatives.

The Territory is unique, virtually all its residents live in the one city-Canberra. It needs a form of government that acknowledges its unique nature and this is what is being proposed-one level of government appropriate to the City/State of the A.C.T. It needs a form of government that also recognises its situation as the nation's capital. This proposal has been designed to ensure that the Commonwealth will look after the national aspects and the A.C.T. the territorial and local aspects-in a manner that protects the interests of both.

In establishing an A.C.T. government, the Australian Capital Territory will be a body politic under the Crown. It will consist of a legislative arm and an executive arm to exercise powers as set out in the Bill.
The dual nature of the Territory-home to both its residents and the nation's capital-will be reflected in the financial arrangements put in place by this Bill.
The A.C.T. will have the same legislative and executive powers and responsibilities over finances as the States and the Northern Territory.

The A.C.T. will be treated by the Commonwealth on the same financial basis as the States and the Northern Territory-fairness and equity will be assured. The A.C.T. will be given protections consistent with those given the States and the Northern Territory, whilst the impact of the location of the nation's capital within its boundaries will be recognised.

The Commonwealth Grants Commission Act 1973 will be amended to recognise the A.C.T.'s financial autonomy and national capital aspects, as well as to allow for direct access by the A.C.T. to the Grants Commission, at the A.C.T.'s request.

Commonwealth funding to the A.C.T. will fully recognise the effects of Canberra's role as the national capital and seat of Commonwealth government on such things as the standards and costs of works and services. This Bill explicitly provides that these special circumstances be taken into account.

The Commonwealth will retain responsibility for financing its functions within the Territory and the Bill provides that the A.C.T. will not be liable for the cost of administering any function retained by the Commonwealth. The Commonwealth will provide additional assistance to the A.C.T. for any further functions transferred from the Commonwealth in future years.

The Government is concerned to see that the transfer of financial power from the Commonwealth to the A.C.T., and the transition to Commonwealth, State and local government financial arrangements, is smooth, non-disruptive and fair. Commonwealth funding to the A.C.T. will be guaranteed in real terms for the first two years of self-government. This guarantee also applied to the 1988-89 A.C.T. Budget to protect the A.C.T. from the funding reductions felt by the States and the Northern Territory and to maintain the base level of funding in the lead up to self-government.

Funding has also been provided in this year's Budget to cover the additional recurrent costs to run the A.C.T. government, as well as the first Assembly election. As was done in the Northern Territory, the Government will also consider a grant to cover necessary establishment costs-such as those needed for a parliamentary library, a Treasury computer system and a building to house the Assembly and Executive.

After the guarantee period, funding will be the subject of negotiation with the Executive to smooth the transition to processes consistent with Commonwealth, State and local government financial arrangements.

These arrangements will complete the ongoing process of bringing A.C.T. finances into line with the rest of Australia-a process which began in 1985-86. Throughout, the Government has taken into account the reports of the Commonwealth Grants Commission into A.C.T. finances.

In terms of the financial impact on the Commonwealth, the Bill will not involve additional Commonwealth expenditures other than the one-off establishment assistance. Savings will accrue to the Commonwealth through separation of responsibilities of A.C.T. administration from the Commonwealth system. In the longer term, the arrangements will allow Commonwealth funding to the A.C.T. on a basis more directly comparable to that to the States.
I will now address individual parts of the Bill.
Part I provides for the usual preliminary matters of commencement and interpretation. Jervis Bay Territory is a separate Commonwealth Territory and is not affected by this Bill.

Part II establishes the Legislative Assembly and covers the range of procedural matters necessary for the conduct of the Assembly's business. The Assembly will consist of 17 members elected at large for a fixed term of four years. The number of members may be varied by regulation at the request of the Assembly.

At its first meeting, the Assembly will elect a Presiding Officer and a Chief Minister. The Chief Minister will appoint three other Ministers and these four people will form the Australian Capital Territory Executive. The function of the Executive will be to govern the Territory with respect to the matters outlined in Schedule 4 of the Bill.

Schedule 4 gives the Executive power over virtually all matters affecting the Territory. The Commonwealth will, until 1 July 1990, retain within the Attorney-General's portfolio the establishment of courts, the provision of police services and the control of legal practitioners, companies and securities. This arrangement will allow the A.C.T. a settling-in period before assuming responsibilities which are currently outside the province of the A.C.T. Administration.

The Government is disposed to have the Executive enter into an agency arrangement with the Australian Federal Police to provide police services to the Territory. The Government will decide by 1 July 1990 whether courts will transfer to the A.C.T. The national function of classifying materials for censorship purposes will be retained by the Commonwealth.

As I have said before, the Territory is home to the nation's capital-this fact cannot be ignored. The Commonwealth will continue to have the ultimate responsibility for ensuring the Territory's good government. Consequently, this Part includes a provision for the Governor-General to dissolve the Assembly and appoint a Commissioner if the Assembly is incapable of performing its functions, or is conducting its affairs in a grossly improper manner. In this eventuality, a general election must be held within 90 days.
Part III details the powers of the Assembly.

The Assembly will have the power to make laws for the peace, order and good government of the Territory. Most Ordinance law in place in the Territory will become Assembly law on commencing day. The Governor-General will, as occurs in the Northern Territory, have the power to disallow any Assembly law within six months of the law being made. Commonwealth law will prevail over Assembly law.

Protections such as these are essential in the national capital. They are, of course, instruments of last resort and it is the Government's intention to resolve any potential conflict with the A.C.T. by consultation and negotiation.

In addition to the powers and functions I described previously, the Assembly will have the power to entrench the manner and form of making particular laws by submitting an entrenching law to a referendum. Its purpose is to extend to the people of the Territory, who are not party to the Australia Act, the general provisions of that Act, which allow the States to entrench laws relating to the constitution, powers and procedures of their Parliaments.

Part IV details the role and functions of the Executive. As I indicated earlier, the Chief Minister will appoint three Ministers. As with the number of members, the number of Ministers may be varied by regulation at the request of the Assembly.
Part IV also provides for a general election if a resolution of no confidence in the Chief Minister is passed and a new Chief Minister is not elected within 30 days.

Part V will permit the A.C.T. to implement its own administration, management and staffing arrangements. The Chief Minister will appoint a Head of Administration who will be the principal adviser to the Executive and generally have prime responsibility, under the Chief Minister, for the administrative functions of the body politic. The Chief Minister may also appoint Associate Heads of Administration as necessary to support the other Ministers in the exercise of their responsibilities.
The Assembly will have the power to enact its own staffing laws and the Head of Administration may employ staff in accordance with such legislation.

Financial provisions are covered in Part VI. The A.C.T. will have an autonomous Treasury. As I explained earlier, the A.C.T. will be treated on the same basis as the States and the Northern Territory in terms of its financial relationship with the Commonwealth. However, the special circumstances arising from the existence within the Territory of the national capital and the seat of government of the Commonwealth will be taken into account.

The Commonwealth may lend money to the A.C.T. or to a Territory authority. The A.C.T. may, with the approval of the Commonwealth Treasurer, borrow money from agencies other than the Commonwealth. Any such borrowings may be guaranteed by the Commonwealth and the A.C.T. may use its assets as security.

Part VII allows for members of the Assembly to be elected under the provisions of the Australian Capital Territory (Electoral) Bill 1988. Part VII also sets out the necessary qualifications of candidates and the processes for filling casual vacancies.

Part VIII attends to miscellaneous provisions and constitutional guarantees. The A.C.T. will be brought into line with the States and the Northern Territory by applying provisions similar to section 92 of the Constitution, guaranteeing free trade. This will not bind the Commonwealth.

Transitional provisions will be included in consequential legislation to ensure the smooth transfer of powers and functions to the incoming government. Until the A.C.T. enacts its own staffing law, the consequential legislation will provide for staff of the A.C.T. Administration to be employed under the Public Service Act 1922 and other relevant Commonwealth legislation and awards. It will also provide for consultation to take place between the Executive, the Commonwealth and Peak Union Councils before the terms and conditions of employment of staff who are to be employed under the A.C.T.'s own staffing law are determined.

In addition to the consultative processes to be provided for in the consequential legislation, Part VIII of this, the Self-Government Bill, provides for consultations to occur on an ongoing basis between the Commonwealth and the A.C.T. on public sector industrial and staffing matters. These provisions are designed to protect the rights and entitlements of Administration staff and also to ensure that the A.C.T. will take account of the effect of its decisions on the Commonwealth's interests as the major employer in the Territory.

Part VIII also allows for the Remuneration Tribunal to determine the salaries and allowances of Assembly members, Ministers, the Presiding Officer, the Head of Administration and any Associate Heads of Administration.

It will be clear that this legislation is both comprehensive and well-conceived. It provides for fully responsible government for the people of the Territory, in its most democratic, practical and economic form.
It safeguards the Commonwealth's interests in the national capital.
It provides for an efficient and effective administration.
It puts the A.C.T. on a proper financial basis.
It ensures that the residents of the Territory will be properly and effectively represented in the management of their affairs. It is a milestone in the democratic processes of this country.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill and commend the Bill to the Senate.
Australian Capital Territory (Electoral) Bill 1988

This Bill provides for a system to elect the Legislative Assembly for the Australian Capital Territory. This, Mr President, is the Government's third attempt at introducing an electoral system for the Territory.

In 1986 this Government first moved to introduce self-government for the Territory. The proposal then, as now, allowed for a government comprising a single House of Legislature-a People's House. The electoral system proposed-single member electorates-was the same as that used to elect members to every People's House in all English speaking democracies-including, of course, Australia. To propose that this Territory also elect its representatives from single electorates in the same way as other mainland Australians was therefore not novel or controversial, yet this proposition was not supported.

The Government, committed then as now to self- government for the Territory, compromised. It proposed an amalgam of Australian electoral systems-around half of the members to be elected from single member electorates using House of Representatives rules, with the balance elected at large using Senate rules. This, of course, represented a significant shift from the principle that the people of the Territory should be treated just like other Australians when it comes to electing their representatives. However, this proposal too was not acceptable.

The Australian Capital Territory (Self-Government) Bill 1988 is already before the Senate. In proposing self-government for the Territory, the Government has once again demonstrated its commitment to democracy for all.

Facing the rejection of existing Australian electoral systems, the Government has turned to an electoral system used commonly throughout the non-English speaking Western democracies to elect People's Houses. This system, known as the d'Hondt system, provides for direct proportional representation. The hallmark of this system is also a concern for both democracy and stable government. It is once again a compromise, but it is a compromise we are prepared to make in an effort to give the people of the Territory the same democratic rights as their fellow Australians. It will be unique to Australia, but this Territory-a City/State-is also unique in Australia.

The objective of any electoral system for a People's House is twofold-to accurately reflect the electoral wishes of the people in the composition of their government and, of great importance, to provide for stable government.

Some with vested interests have advocated that the Hare Clark system of proportional representation be used to elect the Assembly. This Government makes no apology for rejecting a system that is specifically designed for a House of Review. Under its rules, seats may be literally decided by chance on the preferences of voters who may well have had no idea-or wish-that their vote would elect particular candidates.

For example, to decide some seats in the last A.C.T. House of Assembly elections using these rules, votes had to be distributed more than 20 times. In the last Senate elections, a candidate with less than 1.5 per cent of the primary vote was elected. Yet others with more than double this primary vote were not.
This may be acceptable in a House of Review, but it could create instability in a People's House where such members may hold the balance of power.

The d'Hondt system, is a People's House system. It is very familiar to and respected by the democracies of Europe. It has been used for many years in countries such as Austria, Belgium, Finland, West Germany and the Netherlands, all of which enjoy the reputation of being democratic, stable and prosperous states.

Under this system, all contestants are elected as accurately as possible in accordance with the proportion of votes received. The system is completely neutral between contestants and satisfies the stability side of the equation by ensuring that the party or parties with a majority of votes will command a majority of the seats.

There is nothing mystical or complex about this system. A very simple mathematical calculation ensures the direct and accurate reflection of the voters' intention in the composition of the House. It does no more or less than make sure that, as closely as mathematically possible, each and every member in the House is supported by the same number of voters. It is immune from gerrymander. Every vote has equal value and in fact it is the most direct system of proportional representation that one can get.

In terms of the financial impact on the Commonwealth, the Bill will not involve additional Commonwealth expenditure other than that already provided for the first Assembly election, the estimated cost of which is $620,000.
I will now turn my attention to a brief description of the main features of the Bill.
The cornerstone of the Bill is the application of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918, suitably modified, to Assembly elections. The Bill divides the Commonwealth Electoral Act into three categories:
the first category consists of those provisions which are modified by Schedule 1 to the Bill and provide the detailed nuts and bolts for the conduct of Assembly elections;
the second category consists of those provisions which provide the overall framework for Assembly elections and are applied generally; and
the third category consists of disapplied provisions which have no relevance to Assembly elections.

Most of the modifications to the Commonwealth Electoral Act arise because of the introduction of the d'Hondt electoral system. The d'Hondt system enables electors to vote for an independent candidate, a pre-determined list of party candidates or indicate the order in which they wish candidates of the party of their choice to be elected. Once seats have been distributed among parties and independents using the d'Hondt mathematical calculation, seats won by a party are allocated to its candidates by distributing votes in the same way as in Senate elections.

Australian Capital Territory (Planning and Land Management) Bill 1988
Mr President, the Australian Capital Territory Planning and Land Management Bill 1988 heralds a new era in the planning and development of the A.C.T.

This Bill reflects the findings of Mr Block's report on the ongoing role of the NCDC in the context of moves to self-government. It, together with the A.C.T. (Self-Government) Bill 1988, establishes a framework for funding and administering national capital concerns separately from municipal and territorial concerns.

Canberra is a magnificent place. We all acknowledge the expertise and creativity that has gone into making Canberra what it is today-a national capital unequalled in the world for its natural and man-made beauty.

Since 1957, the architect of this city has been the National Capital Development Commission. The Commission was created at a time when it appeared that Walter Burley Griffin's vision for Canberra may not be fulfilled. The Commission took up the challenge and today Canberra is a vibrant reflection of our nation-a City/State in which the whole nation can take pride. The Commission can be proud of the fact that it has taken Canberra from the `bush capital' of the 1950's to the national capital of the 1980's. Its efforts mean that the development of Canberra as the nation's capital is virtually complete.

There are a few national projects yet to be built, such as the National Museum. However, the important and exciting task ahead is for Canberra to develop and grow as a community. The task is to see that it provides in a balanced way for all the diversified economic and social needs of its citizens.

With maturity comes responsibility. Under new financial arrangements that are already in place, A.C.T. citizens will pay for territorial planning and development activities like the rest of us. Fairness and equity requires that there now be an accompanying and unambiguous division between national and local responsibilities. This Bill achieves this.

The Commonwealth will accept administrative and financial responsibility to maintain and enhance the character of the Territory as the national capital. The A.C.T. will accept the normal State-type administrative and financial responsibility to plan and develop the Territory.
The Government will abolish the NCDC and set up a new national planning body, the National Capital Planning Authority, directly responsible to the Commonwealth Minister.

This new Authority will prepare a National Capital Plan which will define the policies, aesthetic principles and any development requirements required to maintain and enhance the character of the National Capital.

The A.C.T. will be responsible for the normal range of State-type planning and development matters. A Territorial planning authority will be set up. It will be responsible for developing and managing a Territory Plan not inconsistent with the National Capital Plan. It will also be able to set out the detailed planning, design and development conditions for all land in the Territory except designated national capital areas.
The Bill requires of both governments parliamentary scrutiny, public consultation and review processes to ensure openness. There will be no scope for corruption.

Ownership of the land will remain with the Commonwealth. The A.C.T. will be responsible for the orderly development of land to meet the needs of the community. Therefore, land other than that reserved by the Commonwealth for its purposes will be managed by the A.C.T. on behalf of the Commonwealth.

These new arrangements will take time to put in place. Any hiatus in A.C.T. planning and development must be avoided. This Bill therefore introduces appropriate interim measures to allow for the smooth and orderly introduction of the new arrangements.

The financial impact of these changes on the Commonwealth will be positive. The integration of NCDC functions into the A.C.T. Administration and the Department of Administrative Services, together with the creation of the National Capital Planning Authority, will result in savings. These savings are estimated at some 120 staff yielding $6.6m per year. Initial integration of NCDC functions has provided a saving of about 80 positions this year. A further saving of about 40 positions is expected to be brought to account in 1989. In undertaking these changes, the Government has been and will continue to be concerned to fully protect the interests of NCDC staff.
I will now address the various Parts of the Bill.
Part I provides for the usual preliminary matters of commencement and interpretation.
Part II establishes the National Capital Planning Authority, prescribes its powers and functions and makes it subject to general ministerial direction.
Part III prescribes the object of the National Capital Plan and outlines what matters the Authority may include when preparing a draft Plan.

The purpose of the Plan is to ensure that the Commonwealth's national capital interests in the Territory are fully protected, without otherwise involving the Commonwealth in matters that should be the prerogative of the Canberra community.

The legislation requires public notification, consideration of representations, and consultations between the Commonwealth and A.C.T. governments before the Plan is brought into effect. The Minister's approval to the Plan is subject to parliamentary disallowance provisions. A process of ministerial certification will be used to protect the draft plan where this is required before normal approval processes have been completed.

Part IV requires the Assembly to establish a Territory planning authority to prepare and administer a Territory Plan. This Plan will provide the people of the Territory with an attractive, safe and efficient environment in which to live, work and have their recreation. The Bill outlines the parameters of the Plan and ensures that it cannot operate inconsistently with the National Capital Plan.

Importantly, this Part requires the Assembly to make laws for the procedure to make the Plan, as well as requirements for public notification, consideration of representations, and consultations between the Commonwealth and ACT governments before the Plan is brought into effect.

The Assembly is also required to ensure by law that there are just and timely processes in place to review appropriate planning, design and development decisions. These reviews will be conducted without unnecessary formality.

Part V provides for the management of land in the A.C.T. It confers on the Commonwealth the right to specify at any time which areas of land it requires for its use or intended use. This land will be called National Land.

All other land will be called Territory Land and will be managed by the A.C.T. Executive on the Commonwealth's behalf. The existing leasehold system will be retained and only the Commonwealth will be able to vary it.
The A.C.T. will be liable for any acts or omissions in its management of Territory Land, as will the Commonwealth in respect of National Land.

Provisions are included to define the relationship which will exist between the two governments in respect of financial aspects of land management. These are required to allow Commonwealth/State financial arrangements to be introduced.

Part VI sets out the constitution of the National Planning Authority. It confers the responsibility to determine remuneration for Authority members on the Remuneration Tribunal and covers appointments to the Authority, obligations imposed on Authority members. It also sets out requirements for meetings of the Authority and permits the appointment of advisory committees.

Part VII sets out that a Chief Executive will manage the affairs of the Authority under its general directions and that its staff will be employed under the Public Service Act. The Authority may engage consultants and is required to present to the Minister a report annually on its operations, which will be tabled in both Houses of this Parliament.

Part VIII provides that the A.C.T. will be indemnified by the Commonwealth for any claims made against it in respect of any matter arising from the Commonwealth's management, actions or inactions before self-government or concerning National Land.
Part IX repeals existing National Capital Development Commission legislation.

Part X sets out transitional provisions that are necessary for the first 12 months after self-government. They will cover the period before the A.C.T. Executive and the A.C.T. planning authority have been established, as well as allow the first National Capital Plan to be brought into effect. During this period, relevant National Capital Development Commission policies will continue in effect. The provisions of this Act regarding the respective roles of the Commonwealth and the A.C.T. to manage and vary planning policies will generally apply.
This Bill is further evidence of the Government's commitment to giving the people of the Territory the same rights and responsibilities as their fellow Australians.
The new arrangements will create an unambiguous separation of responsibility for National Capital planning from Territory planning and development.
They ensure that the interests of the Commonwealth in, and the character of, the Territory as the nation's capital are protected.
They guarantee that the Commonwealth will not be required to take financial responsibility for other than its national capital interests.
They allow the people of the Territory to control the day-to-day planning and development of their home.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill and commend the Bill to the Senate.
A.C.T. Self-Government (Consequential Provisions) Bill 1988
Mr President, this Bill represents the final part of the package of legislation introduced by the Government to establish self-government for the Australian Capital Territory.

The Bill makes provision for necessary transitional and consequential matters arising from the establishment of the ACT as a body politic by the Australian Capital Territory (Self-Government) Bill 1988.

Its object is to ensure that the normal business of government and existing rights enjoyed by residents and transferred staff continue during the transfer of functions from the Commonwealth to the ACT. The Government will ensure that the transfer of power to ACT residents and its elected government is smooth and with as little disruption as possible to their everyday lives.

The Commonwealth is particularly concerned to look after the interests of staff who are to be transferred to the employment of the ACT. Provisions in this Bill ensure the preservation of existing conditions of service under various Commonwealth legislation including conditions relating to workers' compensation, long service leave, maternity leave, superannuation and grievance appeals. The ACT will be free, of course, to make its own provisions for its employees but before it may do so, consultations must take place with the Commonwealth and relevant unions.
The Bill makes a number of interim arrangements relating to administrative law.

The Bill also provides for the transfer to the ACT of rights, assets and contracts of the Commonwealth which relate to transferred functions. Specific provision is made to transfer to the ACT Commonwealth moneys applied in the Territory for territorial purposes and to protect appropriately the financial interests of the Commonwealth.
The provisions of this Bill will, in themselves, have no financial impact on the Commonwealth other than in the context of proposed financial arrangements between the Commonwealth and the ACT.
I will now address the various parts of the Bill.
Part I deals with commencement and interpretative matters.
Part II details the various transitional matters I have mentioned before and allows any further necessary consequential and transitional matters to be dealt with by the regulations or ACT Ordinance.
Part III contains a number of Schedules which effect modifications and amendments to various Commonwealth legislation.

Schedules 1 to 4 contain modifications to Commonwealth employment legislation in its application to staff transferred to the employment of the Territory. The modifications recognise that such staff will be answerable to Territory Ministers and the ACT Legislative Assembly.

By and large, amendments detailed in Schedule 5 ensure that, for the purposes of the application of various Commonwealth Acts, the ACT is treated in the same manner as are the States and the Northern Territory.
Schedule 5 also contains amendments to place the government of Jervis Bay on the same footing as other Commonwealth Territories which do not have self-government.

Mr President, as I have said in relation to the introduction of the Australian Capital Territory (Self-Government) Bill, the transfer of functions from the Commonwealth to the ACT represents a challenge for the people of the ACT. For the first time, they will have a real say in how they are governed. I am confident they will exercise the rights and accept the obligations which other Australians who live outside the ACT take for granted.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill and commend the Bill to the Senate.
