TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Last Friday, when we commenced debating these four Bills, the Australian Capital Territory (Self-Government) Bill and cognate Bills in the Senate, I had, by one of those fortunes which occur to all honourable senators from time to time, commenced my remarks I think approximately seven minutes before the adjournment of that particular segment of our business was called, in order to move to Question Time at 11.55 a.m., and I was forced at that time to interrupt my remarks, which I now wish to resume. I was in the course of making some general remarks about the Government's taxation policies and, in particular, the capacity of the Government to give real tax cuts, as it has promised it will, as from 1 July next year, real tax cuts moreover of a significant magnitude, and given on a basis which could be called responsible in terms of their impact upon the economy as it may be seen to be at that time.

SPEECH.PARA: I had noted in my remarks last Friday that any tax cuts in 1989-90 of less than about $2 billion in magnitude could not be described as real tax cuts because that will be about the magnitude of the degree of bracket creep which the so-called progressive personal income tax system will deliver to the Government's revenues in the course of the financial year 1989-90. It follows from that that any tax cut of less than that magnitude, or about that magnitude, will result in an increase in the real burden of taxes in our next financial year. I think it is important to get that benchmark established before we start talking about tax cuts, so that we all know what we are actually talking about when we talk about real tax cuts. Anything less than about about $2 billion will not, in that sense, be a real tax cut.

I do not know, over and above that datum point, what the Government would regard as a significant tax cut. What would it be in 1989-90? Would a figure-I use it here purely for illustrative purposes-of, say, $3 billion in 1989-90 be regarded as a significant tax cut? In other words, to achieve a significant real tax cut, would the Government have to cut taxes next financial year by about $5 billion in nominal terms? I make it clear that there is every indication on present budgetary prospects that the size of the Budget surplus will not, unless something very unexpected happens between now and the delivery of the Budget, of itself prevent a tax cut of that magnitude. But that, of course, is not the point. Government's do not look, and have not looked for many years at their Budgets in that purely accounting sense, important though it is.

The key point that the Government will have to ask itself as it comes to make these decisions, as it approaches 1 July next near, is: Will we be able to give a tax cut of that magnitude, say-to use my illustrative figure-of $5 billion, or a real cut of $3 billion, responsibly? That question then raises the test of what is meant by that word `responsibly' in economic terms. Of course, one answer is that the Government will need to be able to give any tax cut that it finds it is able in the end to give in a manner or on a basis which will not cause our balance of payments deficit to blow out even faster than it is already blowing out, thus causing our foreign debt to mount even faster than it is already mounting and/or causing us to sell off various assets to foreigners even faster than we are now selling them. Apropos that aspect of the matter, I think we shall next week receive another instalment of the balance of payments deficit saga when we receive the monthly balance of payments current account figures for October.

I remind honourable senators that already in the first three months of this financial year we have recorded a balance of payments deficit of $3,844m, which compares with the forecast deficit for the year as a whole as laid down by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) at the time of the Budget of $9,500m. It is clear, at least to anyone who is prepared to see, that unless a miracle should occur, there is now no longer any chance of the Budget-time forecast for balance of payments being achieved. What we do not know, and I certainly do not pretend to forecast, is what the balance of payments deficit for 1988-89 will be. We can be virtually certain that it will be more than the Treasurer's forecast of $9.5 billion, but as yet we cannot be sure how much greater it will be than that figure. But even, I note in passing, the Treasurer's own forecast of a $9.5 billion annual deficit would be tantamount to roughly equivalent of 3 per cent of our national product. That is a high figure even by so-called traditional standards.

Yet we must acknowledge at this stage of our country's fortunes that so-called traditional standards are no longer relevant. When those so-called traditional standards were being formed or experienced, our net foreign debt amounted to between 5 to 10 per cent of national product. As at the last count, at 30 June last, our net debt amounted to 30 per cent of our national product. It is quite clear that a deficit one may think one can sustain when debts amount to 5 per cent or even 10 per cent of annual national product is quite inappropriate once the debts have become three or six times that level in proportionate terms. I note that even the Treasurer's original forecast of a balance of payments deficit of $9.5 billion was simply not acceptable as a basis for the operation of policy. We simply cannot afford that kind of smug acceptance of even a $9.5 billion balance of payments deficit. And we certainly cannot afford and will not be able to afford what no doubt will be the equally smug acceptance of whatever the even greater deficit will be by the time we come to know what it is at the end of this year.

If we are to talk about a responsible and real tax cut, it is clear that the Government cannot give one on 1 July next year as things stand. The Government cannot give a responsible real tax cut, although of course it may be prepared to give an irresponsible one-and only time will tell. Why cannot the Government in those circumstances give a responsible real tax cut? Because to do so will be to place a significant additional amount of real purchasing power in the hands of consumers. Consumers naturally, and I am in no way criticising them for this, will go out and spend a high proportion of it-let us say, 90 per cent of it, for the sake of argument. A proportion of that in turn, of the total addition to their demand on the economy, will then find its way into demand at the margin for additional imports, thereby making our balance of payments position even worse than it already appears likely to be.

That is the nub of the Government's prospective problem in this area-a problem of which, until very recently, it did not appear to be keenly aware. It is fair to add that since the Budget was brought down, and particularly while the Treasurer, Mr Keating, was overseas, one or two senior Ministers-I have in mind the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button, and the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh-began to express some responsible reservations about certain aspects of the game plan to which the Treasurer had, so to speak, committed the Government in the Budget Speech. It is rather unfortunate, as I have observed elsewhere, that those senior Ministers are reported to have been gagged from speaking about these matters, which are now to be the sole preserve of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer, because to date at least we have not had a great deal of sense from either of those gentlemen. We must hope for an improvement in that respect.

I should add, again without dwelling on the point, that the problem to which I point would be made even more acute for the Government-and hence for all of us, because we are all sufferers when the Government gets things wrong-if, in the distribution of any tax cuts the Government should finally give, it directs those tax cuts principally towards lower and middle income earners, as several Ministers in the Government, including the Minister for Finance, have indicated should be done. Whatever might be thought about the so-called equity, or some other word of that kind, of such a policy angle to the tax cuts, the fact is that the more such tax cuts are skewed towards lower income earners and even middle income earners, the greater proportion of them will be spent and the smaller proportion of them will be saved. Hence, the greater the impact will be on total demand for goods and services and hence, in turn, on demand for imports of goods and services. In the end, that is the bottom line to all these matters to which we keep on having to return.

All this is on the assumption that the world outside our borders in the overseas economies holds together-not merely during the remainder of the current financial year 1988-89, but also into the 1989-90 financial year. The economic effects of these proposed tax cuts will begin to be felt in 1989-90 and will begin to impact on the balance of payments. That is therefore the year in which the economic background will be of particular significance for these proposed tax cuts.

We have to ask ourselves, without at the moment being able to answer the question, but looking ahead so far as we can, the question, as we approach 1989-90-which is only eight months away, let us say in May next year or thereabouts, which I presume would be the latest date by which the Treasurer would be able to announce the actual tax schedule, if he is to make tax cuts-`What will be the situation of the world in prospect by that time?' Will we find ourselves by May next beginning to look down the barrel of an economic gun in terms of the international economy-an economic gun in the form of an approaching, or even by then an actual, deterioration in our international terms of trade as world economic growth perhaps begins to slow down? I cannot and do not pretend to predict what will be the conditions in the world economy at that time. But anyone who has paid any attention at all to world economic developments in the past year or so must continue to have in mind a large question mark, particularly after the American presidential elections are out of the way, as to where the world economy will then proceed to go during the next year or so. I simply ask: How will the Government in those circumstances, should they come to prevail, be able responsibly-again, I emphasise that word-to give tax cuts, even insignificant ones, let alone significant and real ones?

My only point in concluding this element of my remarks is that I believe that the Government is being less than responsible in its discussion of these matters with the electorate in not drawing problems or possible problems of this kind to the attention of the public so that if we should come to such a pass in six months time or so we will not have a vastly disappointed public on our hands, and one which will therefore perhaps be less responsible itself in its reactions to such an outcome.

I had hoped to say something about two particular aspects of these Bills, but my time is drawing to a close and I may reserve those remarks for the committee stage. I will simply state the elements in question. I wish in the committee stage to refer first to the extraordinary retrospectivity of certain aspects of Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1988, in particular clauses 38 and 43. Those two clauses in particular have been the subject of what I think it is fair to described as severely adverse comment by the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills in its twelfth report. There will be more to be said on that aspect in the committee stage.

Secondly, I want to contrast the retrospectivity in those clauses of the Bill with the non-retrospectivity of clause 46, which addresses a problem that has arisen in the treatment for capital gains tax purposes of certain forms of assets transferred from one spouse to another as a result, for example, of an order by the Family Court of Australia following the break-up of a marriage. Unlike clauses 38 and 43, clause 46 does not have a retrospective effect, so such transfers made between the time when the capital gains tax became law and the effective date of this Bill, will be caught for capital gains tax. There is no intention, it seems, on the Government's part to amend what seems to be a glaring injustice as a result. While the Opposition does not normally favour retrospectivity, where, as in this case, the retrospectivity would confer benefits on our citizens and correct an injustice in the process we are certainly in favour of that kind of retrospectivity. There will certainly be discussion of this clause in the committee stage, and I shall reserve any further remarks on the matter for that time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) and Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4). I wish to comment on two areas in particular. Both these Bills incorporate a whole list of changes, many of which are minor. Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3), in making amendments to the capital gains and fringe benefits taxes, reminds us of two notable firsts from the supposed world's greatest Treasurer. One is a tax on enterprise and capital accumulation; the other remains a tax not simply on benefits but on necessary work expenses. I draw that distinction quite clearly in relation to the fringe benefits tax because most aspects of this tax are very much work related.

SPEECH.PARA: The provision of roll-over relief from capital gains tax does not alter the essential fact that this Labor Government levies capital gains tax at 49 per cent, which is, I might add, one of the highest rates in the world. An underlying hostility to the concept of a capital profit has blinded this Government to the overseas experience that greater returns to revenue are achieved by levying tax at a far lower rate, but the Treasurer (Mr Keating) is very much a tax junkie and will find any excuse to levy new and additional taxes.

The fringe benefits tax, which is fundamentally flawed by the cynically expedient method of billing the employer rather than the beneficiary, continues to cost the mining industry in Western Australia $20m annually. Unfortunately, the effects of this are still being felt dramatically in the mining towns, particularly in the Pilbara and the goldfields. Further concessions to extend the 50 per cent discount of the tax on remote area holiday travel and to exempt free travel granted to employees on compassionate grounds only highlight the fact that this Labor Government has never grasped the realities of employment in mining and related industries.

I suggest that the Treasurer needs to come to Western Australia and particularly the Pilbara, as it is so far away and is such an isolated community, before he starts looking at the imposition and extension of taxes such as this. It is simply not reasonable for employees to meet their own travel and housing expenses when they work in such an inhospitable area as the Pilbara. When I say `inhospitable' I do not mean the people; the area is a very difficult one in which to work. The people, fortunately, are among the most delightful people that one could wish to meet, because they have a great sense of community spirit. But this tax has positively discouraged the growth and survival of towns in remote regions of Western Australia. The Opposition continues to deplore the fact that the fringe benefits tax applies to non-profit organisations, such as independent schools that require staff to reside on the premises for essential supervisory duties.

Another area that I want to touch on concerns the National Trust of Australia. The National Trust still does not know whether it is to be billed as much as $150,000 for fringe benefits tax. We would have the absurd situation in Western Australia of the Federal Government giving the Trust $50,000 in direct grants and then claiming back $20,000 in fringe benefits tax. On the one hand the Treasurer stated in his press release No. 115 that `unfavourable circumstances' affecting the rental value of a Trust curator's accommodation would result in `extremely moderate' tax liability. On the other hand, however, the Australian Taxation Office in its ruling MT2025 of 21 October 1986 stated that the National Trust was liable for FBT with a maximum discount of 10 to 20 per cent. Last year the Trust, when attempting to clarify its position, was told that ruling MT2025 stood, in contradiction of the Treasurer's very own press release.

In September last year, the Commissioner of Taxation finally responded to a letter of August 1986-it took him some 13 months to respond-indicating that the Trust might be released from its liability for FBT on the grounds of hardship. I need hardly remind the Senate, however, that indications and assurances can be very different matters. It is a matter of great regret that this Labor Government has not taken the opportunity to give positive effect to the Treasurer's press release, which originally promised the National Trust a measure of elementary justice. The Trust is still waiting for a real answer and has even been advised that the supposed fringe benefit be cashed out in the hands of the Trust's caretakers, who are pensioners and who would lose vital income if this occurred. All this seems absolutely and utterly insane because all the toing-and-froing that is going on is creating such an environment of uncertainty. Unless the Treasurer bestirs himself and keeps his word to the National Trust, the substantial fringe benefits tax liability will result in the closure of at least four Trust properties, two of them in Western Australia. How absurd it is to have a Federal Labor Government that postures as being the saviour of the environment and legislating for sweeping control of land use while still threatening to levy an unjust and crippling tax on Australia's most effective conservation body. It is interesting that the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson), who is the Minister responsible for this area, is in the chamber at the moment. I appeal to him to look very seriously at this problem of the National Trust. It is experiencing a grave problem not just in Western Australia but in various areas throughout Australia.

Whilst the Opposition, for the most part, does not oppose the measures in these two taxation laws amendment Bills, it is greatly concerned about the blatant retrospective liability imposed in clauses 13 and 24 of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1988 dealing with the taxation of non-cash business benefits. It is outrageous-to put it mildly-that this liability is being imposed 3 1/2 years after the issue of a short press release by the Treasurer. Moreover, it is not a liability that affects only the corporate sector, which has a greater awareness of taxation changes. What is being created in this Bill is a tax liability applying to thousands of ordinary Australians who have been in the business of sales after February 1985 and who, in that time, may have received holidays, cars, electrical appliances, or whatever, as non-cash rewards.

These are people who were mentioned regularly in debates in the other chamber, such as Avon ladies. I also know of a number of other people in sales fields who over a period have received many benefits as a reward for hard work. But, as we all know, this Government is hell-bent on ensuring that hard work is not rewarded in any way, shape or form; so those people will be presented with both an administrative nightmare and a major financial liability that they may well lack the resources to meet. I am told by the Government that they are supposed to be grateful that they do not face an additional tax penalty for late payment. The whole concept is just so unfair. For it to be 3 1/2 years retrospective is unbelievable.

On several occasions I have drawn attention to the slackness and inherent undesirability of having legislation give effect to the Treasurer's press releases months, and on many occasions, years after they were issued. We have proceeded from the use of announcements to strike down tax avoidance to a general system of government by press release. Mr Eric Risstrom struck a responsive chord when he suggested that these press releases should become inoperative if no legislation is presented within nine months of issue. I am sure that there are many sales people in Australia today who would be very much in agreement with what Mr Risstrom has said on this issue. If they are going to be hit with tax Bills going back 3 1/2 years, I do not think that is particularly desirable for them. The imposition of a retrospective tax liability on ordinary workers 3 1/2 years after a press release is, to my mind, a massive injustice. The liability should apply only from the introduction of this Bill on 31 August.

The other area that I want to canvass relates to the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill 1988. This mechanical Bill that raises exemption thresholds for the Medicare levy in line with the realities of inflation provides us with the opportunity to discuss many aspects of what could only be described as a very much failed Medicare system that is progressively delivering a lower standard of health service for the Australian people. Unfortunately, I suppose that only those who have relatives, family or friends anywhere along the line who have had illnesses for quite some time or who themselves have had the misfortune to be ill really understand the pitfalls of Medicare. The Government is delivering a system that is progressively lowering the standard of health services to all Australian people. It was to avoid future debates of this kind that this Government last year unsuccessfully sought to legislate for all future years so that the actual Bills would become necessary only for changes in the rate of the levy.

The Opposition does not oppose these rises in the thresholds. However, I note that, while the Government has not yet chosen to break its last promise to retain the Medicare levy at 1 1/4 per cent of income, it has, in a small way, widened the scope of the levy. This has come about as a consequence of dividend imputation. The imputed tax credits over the 1987-88 year are grossed as taxpayer income and the Medicare levy is applied to an artificially higher total income. Compared with so many other actions of this big taxing government, this extra bite of Medicare applying to people who generally, of course, do not vote for the Government is a fairly minor irritation. It is, however, symptomatic of a government that is desperate to grab every last dollar to fund the Medicare monster which is growing arms and legs all over the place day by day.

Once more, it has to be stated that the Medicare levy-estimated to raise $2.3 billion this financial year, which, I might add, is in the vicinity of an 11 per cent rise-does not go anywhere near covering the cost of Medicare. It does not remotely cover the total health expenditure budget of $10.8 billion. More pertinently, it falls well short of the $3.7 billion projected spending on medical benefits. The levy is raising only $2.3 billion and the expenditure is five or six times more than that. To meet this cost the levy would need to be in the vicinity of 2.1 per cent of income. For the Australian taxpayer the distinction is academic, as the cost ultimately falls on our own pockets through general revenue. Whilst supposedly we have only a 1 1/4 per cent levy, we are all still paying more and more for this Medicare monster that is just running out of control.

During the past year it has been made very clear that the Government strategy to restrain the inevitable open-ended costs of this particular socialised health scheme has been to ration services. In other words, artificial barriers have been created so that patients get inferior and less expensive treatment. We all know that that is very much against the wish of medical practitioners and pharmacists, and certainly of members of Parliament on the Opposition benches. Rationing services in the way in which the Government is doing is certainly doing nothing but ensuring that people's lives are being put at risk.

The classic example of this rationing was the recent example of the maintaining of drugs on the special authority list, not because they were possibly dangerous but because they were expensive. In its own words, the Government was trying to encourage doctors to think twice before they prescribed the more expensive drugs. It is all very well to say, `Think twice and prescribe cheaper drugs'; but, if they do not do the job in the way in which the more expensive drugs do, what is the net benefit of that? We are just going to have more and more people who are less and less well. Sufferers from high cholesterol and high blood pressure are being pressured through their medical advisers to accept drugs that are cheap but less effective.

Without retreading the ground of a previous debate that my colleague Senator Puplick led, I reiterate that it is disgraceful that access to drugs controlling life threatening conditions that may cause heart attacks and strokes is discouraged when cheaper drugs are simply not as effective. That is a very worrying concern for so many people who desperately need these drugs and are now fearful that because of this further cost cutting exercise they are going to be prescribed drugs that are cheaper but less effective. No less an authority than Professor John Shaw, Professor of Clinical Pharmacology at Sydney University, stated in August that the restriction on the ACE-inhibitors controlling high blood pressure would place some patients at the unnecessary risk of death. The National Heart Foundation's surveys have found that 30 per cent of women and 50 per cent of men with high blood pressure were receiving no treatment.

Dietary change alone cannot always solve the problem. It is quite ridiculous to expect that people would take cheap drugs with unpleasant side effects when they are discouraged from using drugs of proven effectiveness purely and simply on a cost basis. Indeed, one readily available cheaper drug, clofibrate, is associated with a 10 per cent increase in the death rate. I think that indicates what a great tragedy this whole thing is. These cheaper drugs will increase the death rate. It is one thing perhaps to remove Medicare cover from foreign students and Australians travelling abroad, but another to ration services in a manner that threatens the health of Australians.

The point was well made in an editorial in the Australian Financial Review of 11 July that the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) and the Australian Labor Party were `slowly but surely destroying' socialised medicine in the sense that it is, of course, the poorer members of our community who suffer in the cost squeeze. Many other members of the community will be able to afford to go out and buy more expensive drugs while waiting for the bureaucratic system to mince its way through the mountain of paperwork.

This Government ignores the lessons that Britain provides where a national health service maintained with little change by successive governments fails to meet demand while costing more and more. The present Conservative Government, accused of neglecting the system, has in fact increased real health funding by 31 per cent in its term of office. Yet, the number of beds in 1974 to 1984 has decreased annually by 6,100 while employee numbers have risen by 14,300 in proportion. While it grieves me to say it, I suppose this is one area where Thatcherism has not worked, basically because it has not been applied. But it is a salutary example of the morass into which Australia is plunging because of the deliberate policy of this Hawke Labor Government. The upside of that aspect is, of course, that the British Prime Minister is very much aware of this problem and in fact is doing something about it even now. The central fallacy of Medicare is as clear today as it ever was. If one fosters the belief that hospital treatment is there at public expense, more Australians will rely exclusively on public hospitals and the waiting lists will be lengthened, so often to the detriment of those who have no alternative but to rely on the public system. So once again, we come back to the point that it is those who can least afford it who are in fact being hit the hardest.

While there were initial post-Budget press reports of an extra $3 billion for hospitals, the reality is that $1.9 billion has been transferred from the area of States Grants. So it is just a classic case of robbing Peter to pay Paul. Hospital services and benefits amount to $3,625m in 1988-89 compared with $3,468m last year, an absolute minuscule rise of 4.5 per cent-a rise, I might add, that does not even keep pace with the rate of inflation.

Let there be no mistake that the public hospital waiting lists are a constant Medicare problem. There are 20,000 people on the Victorian waiting lists and the number of those waiting elective surgery has doubled in the last five years. In September it was estimated that 8,000 Western Australians were waiting for elective surgery with 6,455 of them on the formal waiting lists of the three major hospitals-Royal Perth Hospital; the Gairdner or Queen Elizabeth II Medical Centre, whichever people wish to know it as; and the Fremantle Hospital. Of those, 1,000 await general surgery, 1,500 are orthopaedic patients, 1,200 are ear, nose and throat patients and 900 require ophthalmology. None of these requirements is cosmetic or anything but essential to the patient involved. People are being put through an enormous amount of stress and distress as their conditions worsen. In fact, the taxpayer is being asked to fork out more money to care for many of these patients as their conditions worsen.

In fact there have been some disturbing reports of pensioners awaiting cataract surgery for as long as three years. Last year the case was reported of a 79-year-old pensioner in Western Australia paying $440 in private hospital bills for a cataract operation. This patient had been assessed for public treatment two years before but was unable to wait longer because of a need to care for a disabled wife. This is yet another example of where those who can least afford to pay are being asked to do so. In July it was reported that the New South Wales State Government was tackling this problem by encouraging the greater use of private hospitals and restoring the situation so that at least two-thirds of privately insured patients are treated in public hospitals. This really emphasises the point that the consequence of the continuing use of Medicare has been the underuse of private hospitals because private insurance is priced out of the reach of more and more Australians.

In some cases public hospitals encourage private patients. There have been examples of Victorian public hospital administrators actively seeking to increase the number of private patients because of the greater remuneration received. That is indicative of the whole system. The public hospitals simply are not getting enough funding and therefore they have to go out and pinch the private patients to ensure that they get that funding. Between January 1986 and December 1987 the proportion of privately insured patients in public hospitals rose from 19 per cent to an unofficial figure of 28 per cent.

What in the meantime is happening to all those public patients who are on the waiting list? We all know that they are either dying or their conditions are becoming further exacerbated by the wait. It hardly needs to be said that this extra pressure on the public hospital system is detrimental to those who cannot afford private insurance but who, as Senator Peter Baume pointed out at the Australian and New Zealand Association for the Advancement of Science Conference in July, are more likely to suffer serious illness.

We should all be concerned at the fact that the pressure on Australian public hospitals, with the lack of elective surgery that this has created, is having a serious effect on the capacity of teaching hospitals to fulfil this part of their function. Trainee surgeons may see plenty of road accident victims, but what else are they seeing? One may say that they are not now getting exposure to even the basics, down to varicose veins. As a result, the time needed to qualify as a specialist has lengthened with surgical specialities being the worst affected. The qualification time for the Royal Australian College of Surgeons faculty of anaesthetists has increased from four to five years.

It is, of course, inevitable that when Australians are paying 1 1/4 per cent of their income as a Medicare levy, many younger people in particular will be tempted to drop private health insurance and risk not getting ill. On top of this, the Labor Government has taken deliberate actions in the name of cost cutting that have the end result of pricing yet more Australians out of private health insurance and out of the private hospital system.

This Government has reduced its contribution to the reinsurance pool of the health funds covering the chronically ill by 99 per cent. It has removed the day bed subsidy of $140m for private hospitals. It has cut the Medicare rebate for private hospital treatment to 75 per cent of the schedule fee. So while the levy is going up, the returns are coming down. The effect of this, of course, is to make premiums more expensive or increase direct patient costs. For example, earlier this year the cost of advanced surgery with a private room at Perth's major private hospital, the St John of God Hospital in Subiaco, was $383 a day of which $35 was not covered by the rebate.

The Labor Party, for the sake of total health care, should throw away its ideological blinkers and its ingrained idea that private insurance is just for the rich and recognise that private hospitals and private insurance play an essential role in keeping the health system afloat.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for dinner, I was talking about the Medicare fiasco and the Medicare monster in part of the debate on these taxation Bills. I just wish to continue on some of the concerns that I have about this. They are, namely, that in 1986-87 it was estimated that the total cost of health care in Australia was met by the Medicare levy contributing 16 per cent; by Federal Government general taxation giving 38 per cent; by State Government revenues, a further 34 per cent; while the remaining 12 per cent was met by the health funds. As I say, this is just a monster that is getting out of all control. It should worry this Government that between December 1985 and March 1988 the proportion of Australians with private cover fell from 49 per cent to 47 per cent. While that might not sound a big reduction, it is in fact quite an enormous reduction which simply means that more and more people are in the position of relying on the public sector. We should all take heed of the warning by the chief executive of the Voluntary Health Insurance Association, Mr Russell Schneider: that if all those contributors over 65 years of age left the private funds and relied wholly and solely on Medicare, not only would they be foolish, but then the Australian taxpayer would have to find another $1 billion for the health bill. These older Australians represent 10 per cent of contributors to private funds, but comprise 40 per cent of beneficiaries.

SPEECH.PARA: The health insurance industry cannot keep, in effect, supplementing Federal Government health spending, unless a sizeable proportion of younger and healthier Australians maintain private cover. But where is the incentive for them to do so? The incentive just simply is not there and this Government refuses to provide incentives. Week by week almost we are finding that the private health insurance companies are being forced by this Government to put up their rates and, therefore, putting them out of the reach of so many more young Australians. It would seem to be an unwritten rule in this Labor Government that when in doubt over health matters, bash doctors. For months and months we have heard not only the Minister, Dr non-medical Blewett, but also the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, bash doctors ad infinitum. I would like to see the day when they need one.

Doctors are constantly reviled for daring to exceed the scheduled fee, and the recent proposal by the Australian Medical Association for a new fee schedule based on content rather than time was given a public bucketing by the Minister. That is how much he cares about the content and the quality of health care. The doctors do care about it; it is just a great shame that the Minister does not care about it. Even if the Department is now prepared to consider seriously a well reasoned proposal, it is sad that the Minister reacted critically, almost as a reflex action, instead of first considering the proposal and then reacting. If the general practitioner is to act as a `gatekeeper' in deciding to refer patients to more expensive treatments, he should have every inducement to provide quality rather than quantity in consulting procedure. This is what the patients want and expect and this is what the doctors want to provide without interference from a Minister who could not care less. Continually we get from the Government the propagation of the myth of the rich doctor, with a total lack of concern and comprehension of the problems that are faced by the medical profession. There are very few rich and wealthy general practitioners. They are simply trying to do a job for their patients.

The Australian Labor Party ignores the fact that since 1984 the schedule fee has increased by 14 per cent compared with an inflation cumulative increase of 36 per cent; yet it still wants to bash doctors and say that they are all wealthy. In New South Wales, for example, an out of hours home visit by a doctor costs $50, compared with $140 for a senior ambulance officer or a plumber, and $260 for an air-conditioning service man. While I find that the services provided by ambulance officers, plumbers and so forth are very valuable, I would not consider that most of them are given in life-threatening situations-other than the ambulance officer, of course. But it is interesting that the ambulance officer does get paid a darn sight more than the doctor. A GP earns $14 per hour less than a primary teacher or deck hand, $3 less than a college of advanced education teacher, and $6 less than a mining engineer. The cost of staff overheads can reduce a doctor's earnings from $153,000 to less than $63,000-before tax, not after tax. A survey of 200 GPs early in 1987 showed that one-third received less than $30,000.
My time is fast running out. I just conclude by saying that Medicare may be popular with those Australians fortunate enough to avoid serious illness in their family, but that is as far as it goes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bills before the Senate tonight in a cognate debate include the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1988, Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1988, Income Tax Amendment Bill 1988 and the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill 1988. These pieces of legislation cover a range of things of varying complexity, but I think that what is probably most important about them is not so much what they contain, but what they fail to contain as far as increasing equity with regard to tax payment and services received by the community are concerned and, secondly, what they do by way of presumably unintended consequences. I notice that not only will we be looking at some clauses for amendment in these Bills, but so will the Opposition. I see on my desk today that the Government itself is amending part of its legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: The Income Tax Amendment Bill 1988 amends the Income Tax Act of 1986 to formally impose at the rates declared by the Income Tax (Rates) Act of 1986 the tax payable for the coming financial year. It does so with regard to individuals and trustees generally, trustees of superannuation funds and ineligible approved deposit funds in particular, and also relates to companies, registered organisations, corporate unit trusts, public trading trusts and certain other trusts. However, nowhere in any of this year's tax legislation do we find cuts in tax for ordinary Australians despite cuts to company tax and despite a drop of over 20 per cent in the disposable income for those people who earn average weekly earnings or less over the last five years.

This Government's record, for all it talks about the need for equity, is not a good one in the taxation area. As we have seen in the tax Bills debate last week, the Government has seen fit to increase taxes over the last few years on items bought by ordinary Australian families on a regular basis. Milk and fruit juice, for example, were taxed in previous Budgets. Take-away food containers, Glad Wrap, thick shake mixers and flavoured soy milk have been taxed in this Budget, all with the support of an Opposition which claims that it does not want to interfere with the Labor Government's Budget by amending this legislation in any way at all, but has in the past indicated that it is perfectly happy to do things such as opposing capital gains tax and fringe benefits taxes which, of course, only assisted the wealthier taxpayers to pay less tax, or the failure to have those things in place meant that those groups were able to pay less tax than many in the community on less incomes.

I acknowledge that the Government in its early years in this place did move in that area of inequity. I acknowledge too that contrary to its concerns about impeding government's budgetary processes and revenue raising measures in the early years the Liberal-National Party Opposition was prepared to oppose or attempt to amend those pieces of legislation-namely, on the fringe benefits tax and on the capital gains tax. But things have changed considerably since then and, quite frankly, a lot of people are fed up with listening to Senator Walsh say that Australia cannot afford tax cuts-that is, ordinary Australian wage and salary earners cannot afford tax cuts-because, he says, we have to dampen consumption expenditure, which places the burden on ordinary Australian families and individuals in that area, and this despite the fact that it is the wealthiest Australians, surely, who have the greatest tendency to spend money on luxury imports.

While the Government is not prepared to cut taxation to individuals, it certainly has been happy to cut back taxation to companies. The only taxpayers who received any significant sort of tax cuts were those on top pay as you earn tax. In 1987 the highest marginal tax rates were reduced from 60c to 49c in the dollar. That was overdue. It is ridiculous when people in this country can lose over half the money that they earn at the top end of their earnings. We need to remember that it is at the top end of their earnings; that marginal tax rates apply at the margins. Perhaps that is not too well understood in the community. People used to complain that they were paying 60c in the dollar as if they paid it from dollar one.

Indeed, I have vivid memories of being interviewed by a journalist for an Adelaide newspaper who wanted to talk about tax reform generally. When I discussed things such as the capital gains tax and the fringe benefits tax legislation in terms of general tax reform pointing out that if the Government raised more revenue it would, one hoped-at least in those days-raise the tax free threshold and drop the marginal tax rates. The journalist came back with the extraordinary question of what did I mean by tax free threshold marginal tax rates. Here was a man in his middle twenties who presumably had been earning money from which tax had been deducted for five or six years but did not have the faintest idea how the tax system worked and was writing a major feature piece on tax reform for an Australian newspaper. That ignorance in some sections of the community about exactly where there are tax inequities and where there are not filters through to, or back from-I am not quite sure of the direction of the arrows-the community in general.

There are many very large companies in Australia which pay little or no tax while pensioners lose their tax rebates once their combined income of pension and other earnings is, I think, a little over $10,000. Ordinary Australian families on average weekly earnings and less are certainly paying far more than many Australian companies. Yet this fact is also not known. The Australian Financial Review might run a story about Alan Bond's company earning $354m in 1987-88 and paying no tax because of use of tax havens, negative gearing, transfer pricing and so on, but certainly the average Australians are not being told that. They are therefore not in a position to make any sort of comparison between what they earn and pay tax on and what companies earn and pay tax on. I might add that I do not shed tears of blood or even salt water for people such as Alan Bond who owns the Bond group of companies when they claim that they pay rates and charges of one sort or another and are contributing that way. There is not an Australian family in this country which does not also pay rates and taxes at State and local government level. For that inequity to persist under this Labor Government is one of the greatest indictments that can be directed at it.

I wish to say very little of the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill 1988 at the moment. It simply imposes the Medicare levy for the financial year commencing 1 July 1988. More importantly, it will increase the level of the income threshold below which the levy is not payable. This will increase from $8,980 to $9,560. The income thresholds above which the Medicare levy becomes payable are higher now than in the previous financial year. The only point I want to raise is to question exactly how the new recommended Australian Medical Association (AMA) fee charges will impact on Australian families. I do not doubt at all that there are some fairly significant inequities in the schedule fee system, but whether what the AMA is proposing will rectify these or just introduce another series of anomalies is anybody's guess.

We know that there is a serious financial incentive propelling members of the medical profession to see as many patients per day as they can because there is no financial benefit in spending time with patients. A recent study has indicated that many female doctors are significantly worse off than their male colleagues because it is to female general practitioners that many women are now taking themselves and their children for health care. As most people are aware, it is not possible to deal with stress related illnesses or the general health care of a family, particularly children, in a five or 10-minute consultation. Female doctors, who are more prepared it seems than their male colleagues to see women and their children for those 25-minute visits that are necessary, find that they are significantly financially worse off. Certainly, the Government needs to do something other than simply charge by time but I am not sure that the AMA's idea of having the doctor assess the complexity or difficulty of the problem and charge accordingly is the right way to go about it.

The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) has some of the greatest complexities of the legislation before us tonight. It also has a number of either unintended consequences or omissions. It extends roll-over relief; that is, there is a deferral of tax liability on capital gains tax on certain transactions including assets transferred from one spouse to another following a marriage breakdown. Therein lies a problem because there is a sort of gap in the middle of all this with rules applying to breakdowns of marriage prior to one period and following another period but not applying in the middle. I will say something more about this later.

Other amendments include changes to the substantiation laws and further concessions to the fringe benefits tax legislation. I do not want to go into those. They are fairly straightforward. However, the problems that I want to deal with relate to those roll-over provisions. By and large this legislation indicates that the Government did not get its capital gains tax and fringe benefits tax right in the first place. It needs to do what the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) was castigating me for suggesting we do in the sales tax legislation the other day, namely tinker around the edges. We have before us an acknowledgment by the government essentially that the original legislation was sloppy or at least not properly thought through. There is no doubt at all in my mind that an injustice has resulted. That injustice needs to be corrected. This legislation certainly does not go far enough with regard to assets transferred from one spouse to another following divorce. The roll-over relief arguably should have been available from 20 September 1985. To put this in perspective, I would like to quote from a letter that was sent to me and, I presume, to a number of other honourable senators from a lady who was caught up in this. She writes:

When capital gains were first included in taxable income in 1985, rollover provisions were enacted for direct transfer of assets from one spouse to another spouse in a marriage breakdown where the transfers were made pursuant to an order of a Family Court or pursuant to a maintenance agreement approved by that Court.

The rollover provision did not however extend to assets owned indirectly by the `transferor' spouse by means of a trust or company, even though these assets were the subject of many transfer agreements and court orders.
The amendment proposed by clause 46 of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1988-
that is, the Bill before us tonight-

will apply to indirect asset transfers of this type which occur after 28 January 1988. The effect of the rollover relief to be provided by this clause, is that if the transferred asset was acquired by the company or trustee before 20 September 1985, the spouse receiving the asset will also be treated as if he or she had acquired the asset before that date.
She says then:

I am writing to seek your help to persuade the Government to apply the amendment proposed by clause 46 of the No. 3 Bill to indirect assets transfers of this type resulting from marriage breakdowns, not merely to such transfers after 28 January 1988 but to all transfers of this kind after 20 September 1985, the date when the capital gains tax was first introduced.

If clause 46 is enacted in its present form, she says-and I agree with her-it will be clearly discriminatory. This will be the case because a number of good Australian citizens, including the lady who wrote this letter, who pay their fair share of Australian taxes just happen to have acquired assets from these kinds of indirect transfers of property resulting from the unfortunate breakdown of their marriages between 20 September 1985 and 28 January 1988. The letter continues:

We, the unfortunate citizens, will be subject to a capital gains tax in the event if we now decide to, essentially for family or personal reasons, sell the assets acquired. However, those fortunate citizens whose marriage breakdown occur after the 28 January 1988 will enjoy a tax free gain in the same circumstances.

As she points out, there is absolutely no justification for this gap in the middle of people being picked up and treated in the way in which groups both prior to that date in 1985 and subsequent to the date in 1988 are being treated.

There is a further problem with regard to roll-over relief from capital gains for land converted from a Crown lease to freehold, and the particular case that has been drawn to my attention relates to E. L. Yencken Pty Ltd and results from some negotiations over land in South Melbourne currently being leased from the Crown and the fact that the Victorian Government is not offering the whole site that the company currently occupies under a Crown lease but part of it and an adjoining piece of land in substitution. We believe there should be an amendment to this system which does not compel the Commissioner of Taxation to exempt from capital gains tax a roll-over of Crown lease land converted to freehold when there is a substantial difference between the land leased and the land subsequently bought, but gives the Commissioner the option of granting the exemption from capital gains tax. This could be done by including in the legislation other relevant circumstances that the Commissioner in exercising his or her discretion must have regard to.

This brings me to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4), a sort of hotchpotch of whatever the Government left out of previous legislation in this area. It gives effect to concessional changes to the application of fringe benefits tax with regard to remote area housing, and a number of proposals announced in the May economic statement of this year are put into effect in this Bill. These include changes to depreciation, prepaid expenses, termination of section 26aaa and the pensioner rebate. The Bill also gives effect to a number of issues relating to non-cash business benefits, and this is where the major problem occurs. The Government issued a press release on 4 February 1985 announcing that it would tax non-cash benefits that are in the nature of income. The Government got around to introducing the legislation which is now before the Senate in November of 1988.

The Australian Democrats and, I think, other members on this side of the House have warned the Government before about this increasing tendency to legislate by press release. Every time it happens we say, `This is appalling. It should not happen this way. It is causing confusion in the industries concerned'. The last lot related to the insurance industry, which was in total confusion for months on end. Each time we say, `Don't do it again'. This time we on this side of the House have just about had it.

Three and a half years later the Government gets around to putting into legislation something it promised would come into effect by way of non-cash business benefits. When I saw that provision I thought that perhaps it was a complicated piece of legislation; maybe the gurus up there in the drafting office or the Treasurer's office or the Taxation Office or wherever it is these things are done have really had to extend their little grey cells at some length to come up with this proposal. But that is not the case. The provision covers about a page and a half in the Bill and can hardly be justified as being excessively complex to draft. Incidentally, the gobbledegook that goes with the Bill by way of what is laughingly called an explanatory memorandum is of no help at all.

As a consequence, as the Leader of the Australian Democrats I recently sent letters to both the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) about this problem of legislating by press release and made suggestions as to the guidelines. What we did, unashamedly, was to pick up the guidelines issued by the Law Council of Australia, changing them in only one respect, and that was recommending that a maximum of three months may elapse between the press release and the legislation if the Government wants support from the Australian Democrats for future pieces of legislation by press release. The Law Council of Australia suggested one month but in this case more than 3 1/2 years have elapsed. In that time the Government has undertaken tax reform of an extensive and complex type; introduced a fringe benefit tax operative from 1 July 1986, which did not cover this issue, despite the press release of 5 February 1985; and fiddled around at the margins in other areas. So we recommended that the Government have a close look at the letter from the Law Council of Australia and the recommendations, bearing in mind that we-the Australian Democrats and, I hope, the Opposition-support those guidelines. We are prepared to give the Government three months after the date of the announcement for introducing the legislation.

It is totally unrealistic to expect all sorts of people, not just major companies who can afford the services of lawyers and accountants, to fight their way through this legislation and the explanatory memorandum. Ordinary Australians are often picked up by this provision, and indeed, one of the groups of people that have been most concerned, if not actually frightened out of their wits by this legislation, are the women who sell Avon, Nutrimetics, presumably Tupperware and similar products, they will quite possibly be picked up by this measure.

As I said a minute ago, as if it were not bad enough that this has taken 3 1/2 years to get to us, there are very real problems of understanding the gobbledegook in the explanatory memorandum. Page 41 of the explanatory memorandum deals with some of the most important areas of clause 13, the non-cash business benefits clause. We then get to the question of arm's length value. The explanatory memorandum states:

By paragraph 21a (2) (a) the amount to be included as assessable income is the arm's length value of the non-cash benefit less any amount contributed by the recipient in acquiring the benefit. In calculating the arm's length value of a benefit, paragraph 21A (2) (b) operates to disregard any conditions or limitations that might otherwise preclude the placing of a monetary value on the benefit.
It goes on to say:

arms length value', in relation to a non-cash business benefit, is defined to mean the amount the recipient of the benefit would have paid to the provider for the benefit in a relationship where the recipient and provider were strangers to each other and who bore no special duty, obligation or relation to each other. In cases where a value cannot be placed on the benefit by the use of this test, the Commissioner is entitled to assign a reasonable amount as being the arm's length value of the benefit.

`non-cash business benefit' is defined to mean benefits provided after 4 February 1985 in the form of property or services in any business relationship. As the new section 21a only applies to benefits that are income according to ordinary concepts, benefits received in a personal or private capacity would not constitute non-cash benefits for purposes of this section. A Christmas gift by a retailer to a customer would be an example of a private benefit.
I interpolate to ask why. The answer to that rhetorical question is that the Australian Commissioner of Taxation said so. Presumably, Easter bonuses get picked up, but Christmas ones do not.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't interpolate, Senator. I was just getting the hang of it. I have lost my train of thought.
—I am terribly sorry that I have lost the Minister's train of thought. The explanatory memorandum goes on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: This would not usually have an income character-
that is, Christmas gifts-
because it would not be likely to be the product-of an income-earning activity and is not provided on a periodic basis.

I do not know whether that is put together in that way because accountants and lawyers in major companies have wangled their way around various other commonly used English terms so that they do not mean what we always thought they did mean, but I am not sure that I understand what, if anything, any of that means. Although the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate), as a lawyer, probably does, I, as a mere ordinary member of Parliament do not.

The Government has taken almost four years from the date of the announcement to come up with not only the legislation but also this explanation of the legislation which will affect, among others, about 25,000 Avon sales agents, 98 per cent of whom are women and 98 per cent of whom earn below $5,100 which, as I am sure everybody in the chamber, including Senator Tate, realises, is the tax free threshold. What exactly are they going to be asked to pay tax on-salt and pepper shakers and whatever other bonuses are provided to them? How are Avon representatives-I do not mean this in any demeaning way, because I suspect that it applies even to company directors or they would not employ tax accountants and tax lawyers-and ordinary people engaged in these activities going to know or understand the contents of a press release issued in February 1985 and know their obligations under it?

TALK.START.PARA: —And how will they value the salt and pepper shakers?

—Exactly. Senator Messner asks how they will value salt and pepper shakers. One wonders exactly who will make that assessment. I get very angry about this sort of thing. We are hitting ordinary people trying to stretch family budgets that have been hard hit by government actions in other areas. The disposable income of ordinary Australian families has dropped by 20 per cent in real terms. So we have women who believe that they should be at home when their children are at home and, once they are at school, they use the daytime hours to go out there working for Nutrimetics, Avon, Tupperware or whatever.

SPEECH.PARA: At the same time, companies such as the Bond Corporation-the twenty-fifth largest company listed on the Australian Stock Exchange, with interests in brewing, property resources and the media-are paying no tax this year or next year. In fact, next year we will probably give that company something back by way of a little present for being able to find the most ingenious ways of getting out of paying company tax. That is not the only company which is limiting its contribution to Consolidated Revenue and, in the meantime, using transfer pricing, negative gearing, foreign-financed takeovers in particular, South Pacific tax havens and so on. We are depleting, through the actions of such companies, Consolidated Revenue to such an extent that we have governments seriously cutting back on expenditure in health, housing and education. Qintex Australia Ltd pays 0.11 per cent in tax and the Adelaide Steamship Co. Ltd pays 0.43 per cent. The Bond Corporation was listed as paying 0.97 per cent, but I saw in an article in the Australian Financial Review that it will not pay anything at all. That hardly justifies Senator Messner's assertion that this is a high taxing government. It certainly is not in the area of company taxation. Until the Government does something about negative gearing, this situation will continue.

The Australian Taxation Office has to come to terms with transfer pricing and negative gearing, particularly when it is associated with foreign-financed loans. Maybe that way we will get around to some sort of equity. (Extension of time granted) What all of this amounts to is that the Government has some very strange priorities. On the one hand, it allows some companies to get away year after year with paying less than a cent in the dollar tax and, on the other hand, it chases after Avon ladies on very small incomes, asking them to accept that the Government, in the interests of equity, has to tax token awards.

There are a couple of other areas where it appears that the Government is getting carried away by its own enthusiasm and in the wrong direction. I understand that the Tax Office is currently considering taxing the Australian Federation of University Women-South Australia Inc., on its earnings from hiring out academic wear, despite the fact that the proceeds of these earnings are used to award bursaries and prizes to men and women. It is not a large money making concern and the Tax Office admits that it is a borderline case. But these women are very worried that they will lose a lot of the capacity to provide the sorts of scholarships to men and women wanting to go on with university study that they have provided in the past. They keep a stock of academic wear which they hire to graduates and graduands at reasonable rates for formal ceremonies. The money they have raised so far during 1988 has been about $1,400. It is invested and the interest earned is used for awards. I would have thought that that was the sort of thing from which the Government should not be taking an incentive.

The other matter I want to raise deals with the treatment of prepaid expenses which extend over 13 months from the date of payment. An accountant has written to us-and I presume to the Government and probably the Opposition-because he believes that the change will adversely affect his clients; namely, those truckies who are members of the Transport Workers Union of Australia. He argues that the problem occurs when a prime mover or trailer is traded in on a new prime mover and the sale consideration of the old equipment is used as an up-front rental payment on the new prime mover lease. Under the present legislation capital gains tax is payable on the profit on sale of the old prime mover, but a tax deduction is allowed in full on the up-front rental payment derived from the sale of the old equipment at the time of the commencement of the lease. The proposed legislation will tax the capital gains at the time of the trade in and allow only the proportion of the up-front rental as relates to the expired period of the lease, divided by the full term in any one year, less the amount already claimed on the lease in previous years. In other words, instead of paying little or no capital gains tax on the sale of the old prime mover, the owner-driver will now have to pay a substantial amount of capital gains tax because he-it is almost always a man-cannot get the full deduction for the up-front rental payment in the same year. Many owner-drivers, therefore, will not be able to afford to upgrade into new trucks. This will make the industry less efficient.

That is just another example of governments changing tax laws and increasing problems. Sometimes, with the best intentions in the world, there are unintended consequences. I ask the Government to consider either amending its own legislation or supporting amendments moved on this side of the House in order to correct some of the worst anomalies and the more damaging unintended consequences and, in particular, to consider low income earners who are supplementing family incomes, universities that are trying to provide a benefit to potential students, owner-drivers and people who divorced in the period between 1985 and 1988 and to make the system far more equitable for them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Sen J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to be able to follow the Leader of the Australian Democrats, Senator Haines, this evening who, for once, happens to be on our side in outlining and slamming the Government's tax policies. SPEECH.PARA: I wish particularly to address the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) this evening. This Bill seeks to put into effect proposed amendments to the Income Tax Assessment Act, the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Act and the Taxation Administration Act. These amending Bills will add to the existing encyclopaedia of tax laws in this country that have undoubtedly tired the most diligent of accountants and tax lawyers. To see the tax Act today really makes a lie of the very boastful claim of this Government that it has streamlined and simplified the tax laws of this country because it is forever changing them and bringing in amendments to this House to cover up its utter incompetence in this field, and the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) knows it. I can see him smirking.

We have an example of one of those amendments this evening in the amendments to non-cash business benefits. This Bill seeks to implement a proposal-as all the other speakers have said in this House-that was announced on 4 February 1985-some 3 1/2 years ago. The Government's administrative incompetence has now reached the stage where it is making a mockery of the law. That accusation is backed up by the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. A report of that Committee says:

The Committee again questions how a person may be expected to know the content of a law when the terms of that law are not publicly available, but may only be ascertained from a reading of Ministerial media announcements, or, in this case, a draft bill which was modified in content before its presentation to the Parliament.

The Committee drew subclause 53 (19) of the Bill to the attention of the Senate as, due to its retrospective effect, it `may be considered to unduly trespass on personal rights and liberties'. Is the Minister concerned about that report from the Scrutiny of Bills Committee? I also ask the Minister to take strong heed of the Law Council of Australia's condemnation of this legislation by press release. The Law Council, like the Committee, has repeatedly urged the Government, and particularly the Treasurer (Mr Keating), to stop using media releases to usurp the legislative role of Parliament in a way that makes a mockery of the rule of law. To this end the Opposition has moved an amendment that backs up the Scrutiny of Bills Committee and the Law Council of Australia. That amendment reads:

condemns the Government for its practice of `government by press release' which can cause otherwise legitimate legislation to be called into question because of the unacceptable retrospectivity thus introduced.

Honestly, how can any business possibly operate under this type of administration? We have already witnessed the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) bringing into the Parliament a shemozzle under the name of corporations package. So bumbling was it that it needed up to 280 amendments only four months after it was introduced into this House. So poor was the drafting of that package of legislation, so uneasy did the Senate feel about, that it shunted it off to a committee even after the 280 amendments had been dealt with. The Attorney-General's announcement of his pending retirement from politics really means that he has dropped his bundle, all at the expense of the taxpayers. Now the business community must endure another incompetent drafting exercise by this Government, because that press release in 1985 did not provide sufficient details on what the make-up of the legislation might contain, and it left business absolutely in the lurch. Clearly the Opposition is saying that the legislation should not be retrospective but should apply only to the benefits provided on or after the day of its introduction.

It is also worth noting that one of the most significant amendments before the Senate discriminates against the productive and enterprising sector of small business, that is, the termination of the general accelerated depreciation concessions allowing write-off of most plant and equipment over three or five years, and the special five year depreciation arrangements for storage facilities for hay, grain, fodder and for primary production plant and equipment. This change to the depreciation provisions comes on top of the abolition of the investment allowance only some 12 months ago. The Government's feeble argument is that these changes are due simply to the fact that it is levelling the playing field and that it has offset these changes against the reduction in the company tax from 49c in the dollar to 39c. But the facts are that unincorporated small businesses, which make up half of small business, are not included in this levelling of the playing field because they do not pay those company rates. They are not incorporated so they cannot take advantage of the 39 per cent company tax rate.

Further, does the Government really believe that the family farmers, who contribute so much to the welfare of this nation and who are going to lose from the abolition of this so-called depreciation concession, pay a company tax rate of 39c in the dollar? Obviously the Government's argument has no legs to it at all. What it is doing, and what we have seen it do over the last six years, is once again hitting out at that sector, the farmers and the small business people, because they do not fit into its corporate state strategy. Yet ironically it is this sector that is holding up the economy today, that keeps the economy afloat.

So I utterly reject the claim that we hear so much from the other side of the House, that the Government is continually levelling the playing field. What it does not realise-although it might-is that it has flattened the main players, the small business people and the farmers. The oft asked question is: Why does the Government hate the farmers? It never bothers to answer that, and I think that is because the farmers do not vote for them and nor does the small business sector of the economy. To this end the Opposition has moved an amendment, which reads.

notes that this Government's so-called tax reforms invariably involve simply offsetting tax reductions in one area by tax increases in others, as witnessed in this Bill by the termination of the 5/3 depreciation arrangement to offset a reduction in the corporate tax rate;

The Government's attack on this sector, which I have outlined, continues by its increasing of the provisional tax uplift factor from 11 per cent to 12 per cent. The uplift factor is probably best known to those who are provisional taxpayers. It sets a percentage increase for the basis of calculating provisional tax by taxpayers who do not self-assess by seeking a variation of provisional tax on the basis of an estimate of income for the relevant years. The real point is that this tax increase was not mentioned in the Budget, that the Government has simply brought this tax amendments in to raise what is calculated to be an extra $100m. So in fact it is just another tax raising effort by stealth. The Opposition's amendment condemns outright this method of tax raising, and it reads:
notes that the Government continues its propensity for taxation by stealth by again unaccountably raising the provisional tax uplift factor;

This amendment Bill proposed by the Government and the style in which it has been introduced are all part of the Government's great tax grab, so aptly put by Herald journalist, Terry McCrann. This Government from its first day in office has been cheating and mugging the farmers, small business people and the householders of Australia. The Opposition's amendment has spelt out this position quite clearly. It notes that:
. . . this is the highest taxing Government in the post-war history of Australia.

Undoubtedly that is the way in which this Government will go down in history. Is it any wonder that the Government is so sensitive to the McCrann articles? Certainly the Government is very sensitive when seeking to explain its taxation laws and polices because it simply cannot defend them. These policies are hurting the PAYE taxpayer. For example, in 1983 a single income family on average weekly earnings had a marginal tax rate of 30 per cent. Today, that same family's marginal tax rate is 40 per cent. Another way of looking at the Government's tax record is that the income tax on individuals shows a 63.7 per cent increase, while inflation has risen by 43.5 per cent. They are both staggering figures.

Since the first day of this Government's wretched existence it has dragged an extra $8 billion per annum from ordinary taxpayers by way of bracket creep. Over two million taxpayers have been pushed into the top tax brackets, and it is estimated that a million more taxpayers will be pushed into the top tax bracket. That is how this Government has been funding its much-touted budget surplus-not through the proper discipline of cutting its own expenditure, but by increased taxes. Yet the Treasurer, working on the principle of `Tell them anything and they'll believe it', said on 11 October to the British-Australian Chamber of Commerce in London that the:
. . . move into surplus was not achieved as a result of revenue increases. It has come entirely from outlays reduction.

Just judging by the words uttered by the Treasurer, Australians have every right to be concerned that their much promised and much needed tax cuts will not be delivered. All we get from this Government is falsehoods. The people of Australia have further reason to doubt that tax cuts will ever be delivered when they hear the words of the Leader of the Senate, Senator Button, who said:
Some people have talked enormous figures in terms of tax cuts. I don't think they are affordable. I mean, we are really not in a position where we can indulge ourselves too much at the present time.

Senator Button and his colleagues on the Government benches have been indulging themselves with Australian taxpayers money for the past six years. Sadly, the much promised and much needed tax cuts, as we see from the words of Senator Button and the Treasurer, are in grave doubt because of this Government's incompetence in managing the economy and its utter unwillingness to cut its own expenditure. It has been unwilling to drop off its hangers-on who have leached the Budget and the Government and the Government has not the guts to drop them. We know from Senator Walsh, the Minister for Finance, that at least 200 programs could be eliminated without any worry. Why does the Government not do something for the Australian taxpayer, for the householder, for the family man? I know that Senator Tate is a decent Minister who cares for the family, but he never stands up and defends it. He is always being squashed and being put under the thumb of the left wing of the Labor Party; he is too frightened to stick up his head.

The inflation rate clearly shows the vulnerability into which the economy has lurched. The inflation rate which was estimated in the Budget to be 4.5 per cent is now running at 7.3 per cent and rising undoubtedly. Interest rates are well above what the Government wants or estimated and 90-day bills are running at 14 per cent or thereabouts, which is certainly too high. Home loan interest certainly has shot over the 14 to 15 per cent mark and the current account deficit is running at an annual rate of $13 billion-way above the Government's estimate of $9.5 billion, and adding to the foreign debt of $115 billion. Without doubt, all these events have placed the tax cuts in doubt. Certainly the $56 week needed to restore the ordinary Australian standard of living to what it was six years ago will never be achieved. Of course, people would have to have been pretty gullible to believe that they would ever get tax cuts, but as those cuts were promised, people had their hopes. However, those cuts are certainly now on the back burner. I feel very sad and sorry for the ordinary Australian taxpayer who has put his faith in this Government in one or two elections only to find that they have been let down each time.

In a short period of 15 years that country has moved from being a Third World country to being an industrial giant in South-East Asia and the world. It has come from nothing to be the world's third largest steel producer and third largest manufacturer of microchips. After a debate here the other day a comment was made to me by one of the Labor Ministers. He said, `They are lucky because they have just come into the industry. They are able to start afresh'.
