We need to export more, import less, improve our productivity . . .
It sounds familiar, does it not? He went on:
and yet all we get is talk, talk and committees. We must be the greatest saliva slingers on the planet.

The industries which keep this country afloat are mining, primary industry and, more recently, tourism. That is all we have. It says, `Do not worry about the inefficient ones. Let us go for the efficient ones and make them inefficient'. Fringe benefits tax is a good example. It was introduced to catch people in capital cities receiving payment in kind instead of wages. I do not disapprove of that. But whom does it hit? Quite unjustly, it hits-in another unintended consequence, I presume-mining, primary industry and tourism.

This Bill goes some way to rectifying the effect of fringe benefits tax on mining and primary industry. Under this legislation a lack of profit in its early years of operation will mean that it will not be able to depreciate its plant and equipment against future profits. I would be surprised if even this Government intended that that should occur. I ask it to restore the depreciation provisions to mining in that industry.

At the beginning of this speech I mentioned that I would talk about bracket creep. The section of the community which bears most of the brunt of the tax burden is the one-income family. I will also have a little to say on Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3), particularly the transfer of assets from companies or trusts to a spouse upon the breakdown of a marriage; and roll-over provisions on the termination of leases, licences, et cetera.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course these Bills are much wider ranging than the points I have mentioned. But these points mostly affect the agricultural and mining industries and small businesses around Australia. These Bills will put into effect the measures outlined in the May Economic Statement. Incidentally, they are more examples in a long line of amending Bills to implement this Government's modus operandi-that is, government by press release.

Depreciation changes probably have the greatest effect on primary industries. This Government has been hell-bent on removing any incentives that a succession of coalition governments offered primary industries to keep--

TALK.START.PARA: —It is called cleaning up rorts.

—That is all right. We put them on and the Government is cutting them off. We provided the incentives but the Government is cutting them off. Hopefully, some incentives will be kept so that some of the foreign income can be earned to enable the Government to pay off its bills. As I said, this Government is hell-bent on removing incentives. By doing so, the Government is denying primary industries the opportunity to keep up with technology.

SPEECH.PARA: Where a farmer could write off over three or five years a machine producing assessable income, such as a tractor or a combine harvester, whether it was built in Australia or it was a costly import, now, of course, we are to return to the practice of writing it off over a period defined in a schedule by the Commissioner of Taxation. This write-off schedule is more in keeping with the 1950s. I believe that the schedule was written at a time when there was less area under cultivation which resulted in less use of machines. This meant, of course, that the machines had a longer life. As I said, the schedule was probably drawn up in the 1950s or even the 1940s and, as far as I know, it has not been updated.

With increasing acreages being used to grow crops and with more land being cleared and harvested during the 1960s, 1970s and 1980s, the life of machines has declined. But, at the same time, the Government is increasing the write-off period. A major consequence of this is not only the removal of the incentive to purchase new plant and keep up with technology, but also a decrease in the supply of good used machinery for farmers who are not in a position to buy new machinery.

If honourable senators do not believe what I am saying, one has only to look at several cases in Western Australia where many machinery dealers are importing good used American machines. This may make good business sense to them, it may provide the cheaper version of the machines that farmers are looking for but, of course, there are inherent dangers. One of those dangers is the importation of noxious weeds from America that probably are not in Australia if the imported machines are not cleaned properly.

On top of that, the biggest tragedy is the loss of jobs in Australia both in the retailing of the less than new machines and the servicing of those machines as well. Machinery used by the mining and exploration industry has suffered the same fate with the removal of certain write-off conditions. One of the most farcical situations is the removal of the right to write off over five years storage facilities for hay, grain and fodder. We are talking about an agricultural sector that has gone through droughts and all sorts of ups and downs and disasters in the last 12 months. The Government has had to dip in and provide carry-on finance and even social welfare to build up income. Here we have this same government which encourages, and rightly so, the conservation of fodder and water, and it takes away the incentive for the farmers and pastoral owners to help themselves through the conservation of fodder, et cetera. The same goes for the storage of grain, especially in the eastern States. More and more grain is being kept on farms, especially in New South Wales. Because of the run down railway systems and the wheat handling that we had under the Unsworth Government, I suppose it is a logical practice. But it hardly seems logical to remove the incentive to build those facilities by the sorts of incentives that we had through depreciation.

One of the amazing side effects of the write-off provisions is the fact that each taxpayer has to elect, on a year by year basis, which of the two depreciation methods-prime cost or diminishing value-is to apply to that year. The method elected will continue to apply for the life of the plant throughout its depreciation life in the hands of that taxpayer. There is nothing wrong with that, but why must that basis of depreciation remain for the whole year? In other words, if one buys extra machines, in addition to one's first, unless I am wrong, I presume that every item of plant one buys that year has to be written off on the same basis.
I was waiting for a comment from the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh)-but obviously I shall not get one-as to whether I was right or wrong.

When one looks at the financial impact of this change in depreciation, one will see that there will be a revenue saving of $190m in 1989-90, $450m in 1990-91, $1,030m in 1991-92, and $1,650m in 1992-93. These may be admirable savings, but it will be at the expense of many jobs in Australia and the use of better machines, thus we shall miss out on technology that keeps us up with the rest of the world.

Last week Senator Maguire told us that these provisions for write-off and depreciation will be more than made up by the cut in the corporate tax from 49c in the dollar. I do not know where Senator Maguire gets his figures from but if a census were done of the agricultural sector throughout Australia, it would be found that very few people-this was pointed out by a previous speaker-work under an incorporated company system. A farmer is likely to buy more plant in a boom year when he is paying tax at a rate of 49c in the dollar.

I come to the elimination of section 26aaa. I commend the Government on this move because it will remove an anomaly. I spoke on this anomaly last year, when, during the market boom, many quick gains were made in some share deals, and many were lost on others. But the trouble was that under section 26aaa whereas share gains were taxed, share losses were not able to be written off against that. The only way that a share trader could claim losses at the time was to claim them against capital gains in other areas and in the future-and they may or may not be around.

TALK.START.PARA: —Classified as a share trader.

—If he is classified as a share trader-that is right. The fear I hold is that many taxpayers are locked into the law as it stood last year-in other words, after the crash and until this section 26aaa alteration. I think we will find taxpayers who are locked into that situation as the elimination of section 26aaa came into effect on 25 May.

SPEECH.PARA: I said earlier that I gave an example in this chamber last year of how a taxpayer could have finished the year with no profit or, indeed, a loss in share trading if it had gone as I have said. I hope that the Government is looking at this problem. This shift from taxing under section 26aaa and taxing under capital gains provisions will cost revenue income a mere $5m in 1988-89 and $30m in 1989-90. This is the extent to which the Treasury would have ripped off those taxpayers if that provision had not been changed. I commend the Government. To show that I knew what I was talking about on 21 April 1988, I have an extract of what I said then in a debate on matters of public interest and I seek leave to have that extract of my speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The extract read as follows-

I would now like to move onto a different matter, that is, the taxing of share profits under section 26aaa of the Income Tax Assessment Act. I will quote a brief passage in a letter to me from the Taxpayers Association of Western Australia. I will quote straight from the letter:

The Perth office have indicated that they are sympathetic to the view that short term speculative losses should be allowed as a deduction however, although they have had continuous liaison with Canberra, their efforts have been unsuccessful.

We understand that the Taxation Office are shortly to issue assessments to taxpayers whereby profits on disposal of property within 12 months are assessed under Section 26aaa and losses on disposal of property-
which includes shares-

within 12 months are treated as a capital loss. Take the simple example of a person on fairly average wages-a clerk somewhere, or a truck driver, a miner or something like that-on around $25,000. Under the pay as you earn (PAYE) system he is up for $6,682. But what if he made a $30,000 profit on one share transaction. Let us say he had a couple of thousand dollars to invest just before the share boom last year. A lot of people working at the mines or in solicitors and accountants' offices, got the bug and if they got on to a good issue they could quite easily have made such a profit-and I know some who did, although I am using the figure of $30,000 to make it easier. So this person bought these shares and then made a $30,000 profit. Then, of course, got the bug a bit more and decided to carry on in the market-and then lost that $30,000 in another share transaction. His effective balance after the dealings was nil. In other words, he made no money and he lost no money, so one would expect that at the end of the year when his tax bill came he would only need to pay tax according to his PAYE figure. But it does not work that way.

Under section 26aaa the Australian Taxation Office simply takes the $30,000 and adds it to his PAYE income, which makes a total of $55,000. The tax on that would be $19,801, using today's rates. We must add $687.50 for Medicare and $16,081 for provisional tax, giving a total of $36,569. If we deduct what he has already paid in PAYE tax, we are left with a net liability of $29,887.50.

Of course, not having any share profits as at 31 March next year-I would say that he would be scared right out of the market, thinking `I will stay on wages for the rest of my life; I am not going to do that any more'-he can then ask for a provisional readjustment and that provisional tax will be wiped off. In other words, his total tax bill, after having wiped out that $16,081, will; be $18,806. That is the bill he will be getting, and he will be getting that bill even though he made no profit on his transactions. One way or another, like it or not, he will have to foot the bill. I know that he has capital losses to wipe off against his capital gains, but a fellow of modest means, on $25,000 year or whatever, with a family, having been scared off after his first time in business or share trading will probably not be game to try anything like that again. He will never, unless he gets a capital gain somewhere by selling one of Grandma's paintings or something like that, get a chance to wipe that capital loss off, so he is left with this $18,806 tax bill to pay. Worse still, he might have borrowed $2,000 to buy those shares in the first place. I stress that he could be a very ordinary wage earner, such as a truck driver, an office worker or whatever you like. It could happen to anyone. As I said he could even have borrowed the money. So, I put that scenario forward as a very simple example of the problems people face, and on about 31 March next year dozens and dozens of these cases will crop up right around Australia. I implore the Government to take this matter on board and see that something is done.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I turn to the subject of mains electricity supply. Since 1980 the cost for extension of electricity supply to farm stations, remote areas, or whatever, used to be able to be written off in the first year of incurring that expense. This has been changed in the May mini-Budget. I find this totally unacceptable because I consider that electricity on a farm, station or whatever is the barest of necessities. Electricity is something that is certainly taken for granted in the cities. Why should country areas put up with less? As I said, that write off provision is to be done away with. I remind the Senate that it is no small cost to connect to the electricity grid supply anywhere in Australia, I presume. I know that one does not have to be very far away from the mains-probably only one kilometre to two kilometres-to have a bill of $7,000; any further away and the cost will soon increase to $15,000, and bills of $20,000 are quite common. Honourable senators should compare that with the city areas that get connected for next to nothing and people expect it for less cost.

SPEECH.PARA: This move is irresponsible and, as I have said, falls only on the people who live in remote areas. They are people, in the main, that this Government does not worry too much about because of the low population density. I remind the Senate that the 9 per cent of the Australian population who live in those areas produce 85 per cent of Australia's export income. One has to remember that once electricity mains are connected, though they may add value to the property, they are not realisable, they are not salable; in other words, they cannot be turned into cash tomorrow and be used as a tax rort.

I turn to fringe benefits tax as applied in remote areas. Here we have the Government finally getting the message of the special needs of remote areas. We told the Minister for Finance time and time again in the old place last year that people in remote areas had a special need. The Government was told how damaging the fringe benefit taxing provisions were to remote areas. It has finally seen some light; that is, that no-one goes into remote areas just because of the fringe benefits-for example, cheap housing. People go out there for the rewards that may come from working on mines or on farms, and so on. If an employer needs to fill a job in a remote area, he has got to supply housing. For that the employer was saddled with 49c in the dollar as the fringe benefit tax, although that was reduced by 0.6 per cent at that time.

I fully admit that when fringe benefits do not relate to the job, they should be taxed. There is no excuse. Let us consider school fees. If one lives in the city, whatever an employer may care to pay on behalf of his employee should be taxed. But when the benefit is job related, then I maintain that it should not gather any sort of tax. Of course, when we are in government we will address this problem.

Honourable senators such as those who spoke last week and who do not believe that these problems exist in those remote areas should go out into these areas and see the situation for themselves. This Bill addresses some of the injustices but some of the damage is irreparable. When this fringe benefits tax finally hit, many mining towns removed to the city the personnel who were not needed on the site on a continuous basis. They were then flown into and out of the site. That of course led to other problems in relation to the social fabric of those towns. Mostly the towns were left with men without their wives and, on the other side, women were left without their husbands. Eventually these social problems turned to problems for the Department of Social Security. The final injustice is that now many of the mining companies will not build remote area towns. Right from the word go, they will fly the workers, in and out, as happens with the diamond mine and some of the new gold mines. They will build only single men's quarters. As I have already said, this has social implications. In other words, the damage is already done. When we get into government we will do something about this.

I now come to the point of the uplifting of the add-on percentage for provisional tax. This Bill seeks to increase that added on figure from 11 per cent to 12 per cent. Eleven per cent was hefty enough even when inflation was running high. But this Government now claims that inflation is down to 7.3 per cent. This is nothing but a further hike to extract money out of the business community and into the Treasury ahead of time to fund its ever increasing social security bill which it has not had the courage to address. I will just give honourable senators inflation figures: In 1983-84 inflation it was at 6.9 per cent; in 1984-85 it was 4.3 per cent; in 1985-86 it was 8.4 per cent; in 1986-87 it was 9.3 per cent; and last year it was 7.3 per cent. In that period the add-on provision has been 11 per cent. Even with that downturn in inflation, the Government has sought to increase it. I know that I will be told that the Government expects business to increase, but it does not always do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is mostly because of farm incomes going up a great deal this year, as you should know very well.

—Yes, in the last couple of years they have gone up but before that they were going down. I know that we expect an increase every year in our turnover and, hopefully, our profit, but I think that is going slightly too high. On top of this we also have the quarterly payment system of provisional tax. This has been with us for quite a few years. That money is gradually going into the Treasury quicker and quicker. I maintain that the Government has absolutely no defence for increasing this provisional uplift. The financial impact of this section is an uplift in revenue of $105m in 1989. This is the amount of government grab but honourable senators should remember that this amount is taken out of the future. In other words the Government gets it ahead of time-even ahead of provisional tax. It then spends it and has to find another way of raising more money.

SPEECH.PARA: The ultimate in this Bill must be the latest saga in legislation by press release. This saga is bringing down legislation to cover a press release of three years ago. It has been pointed out by previous speakers what press release is about-it is the taxing of non-cash benefits. In other words, it accrues when one receives a benefit rather than cash. The Government decided to start taxing this from 1985 but it has taken three years to put the legislation into place. I do not understand why it has taken so long. Without having gone too deeply into the matter I believe that there was a certain amount of change along the line. I think that the Treasury was going for the ones who received either cash or kind but then, somewhere along the line, I am pretty sure it was changed. In other words, when a person won a trip to Japan, the people who gave that trip away as an incentive drive or something may have said that the trip could not be cashed. But since 1985 the Government has decided that if it is deemed to have cost a certain amount, tax is payable on it. Perhaps one may not even have taken the trip. I do not know how that would go. I would like to be told.

I would now like to turn briefly to the Taxation Amendment Bill (No. 3). A lot of work has been done on roll-over relief for leases, licences such as fishing licences, taxis, involuntary disposals, and assets transferred on the breakdown of marriage. Mr Acting Deputy President, you may remember how many time honourable senators from this side of the House have spoken on the matter of leases-pastoral or otherwise-which expired, and licences such as fishing licences that expired after September 1985, when the capital gains tax came in. Time and time again it was mentioned. Finally the Government had the good sense to take the advice which, as I said, mostly releated to pastoral leases and fishing licences. I presume taxi licences were included in that. The Government has decided that where there has not been a change of ownership since September 1985, when capital gains tax came in, it will be deemed not to have changed hands and will therefore be free of capital gains tax.

The Government also extended this to the breakdown of marriage. There is a very interesting case from Western Australia where a marriage broke up after 40 years and property was transferred from a trust. This property was not owned by the husband in his own right but went from the trust to the wife. The wife was not really interested-even by paying her husband back-in breaking up the business by demanding money out of it so she agreed to take property from a trust to herself. She did this instead of taking money out of that business which could have probably put the business on the rocks. Unfortunately, her marriage broke up between 20 September 1985 and 20 January or thereabouts of 1988-the date to which the Government said it would backdate these provisions. I understand that any property transferred from joint names or from the husband's name to the wife at any time after 1985 kept the status of non-capital gains. But when the income came from outside, in other words from a trust to the wife, the capital gains were lost. I cannot understand why the Government has not backdated it to 20 September 1985. I have heard of plenty of things used as taxation rorts but I have certainly never heard of a marriage breakup used as a taxation rort.

TALK.START.PARA: —It stops them getting married.

—I thought that it might help people to stay together. However, in this case it looks as though it is unfortunate if the breakup of a marriage occurred in that period. It is unfortunate for a marriage to break up at any time, let alone during that period. I understand an amendment to that clause will be proposed, and the Opposition will certainly support that.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, I point out the fiasco that must exist in the Department because the Attorney-General has brought in 280 amendments to his corporations package only 12 months or so after it was introduced. That is a sign either that the Government is arrogant and out of touch or that the Department is inefficient. I do not know where to lay the blame, but someone might help me in that regard. It may be an increasing incompetence in the way in which the Government watches how legislation is drafted. I do not know, it is the Government's responsibility. More and more amendments are being moved when a Bill has only just been passed. Unintended consequences are being dealt with by amendments time after time. Some contentious Bills have brought about this situation, mainly those dealing with fringe benefits tax and capital gains tax. Bills of such consequence have not been around for the past 10 or 15 years, and maybe their advent has been the reason for this situation. The Government decided to bring them in, and the Government is certainly responsible for the fiasco that exists there. If this situation continues we will still be sitting at Christmas time.

I support all the amendments that are to be moved by the coalition, especially those I have pointed out dealing with roll-over relief on the expiration of licences and pastoral leases, mining leases, et cetera. I will be making sure that an amendment is moved, if one has not already been moved, to provide for capital gains relief on the roll-over of funds on the breakup of a marriage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak in the cognate debate on the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill 1988, the Income Tax Amendment Bill 1988, the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1988 and the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1988. I propose to restrict my comments to the latter two taxation Bills which, inter alia, will seek to give effect to a number of tax measures announced by the Government in the May economic statement and also in the recent Budget. Such measures include the abolition of the five- or three-year accelerated depreciation provision; termination of section 26aaa, which applies to property sold within 12 months of acquisition; taxation of non-cash business benefits; and a number of amendments relating to the provision of fringe benefits.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to deal with the question of retrospectivity-or perhaps more correctly, in this case, legislation by media release which the Government has raised, I might say as no compliment, to an art form in the introduction of taxation legislation. Indeed, the practice has more recently infiltrated other areas of legislation introduced by the Labor Government. The Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill 1986 and last year's Broadcasting (Ownership and Control) Bill are two which come immediately to mind as having been introduced retrospectively.

This year's eleventh and twelfth reports of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills draw the attention of honourable senators to subclause 53 (19) of the No. 4 Bill, which seeks to amend the Income Tax Act to impose certain additional tax upon taxpayers from 20 June 1988. The Standing Committee notes that this was the date upon which a press release announcing the changes, together with a draft Bill, were released by the Treasurer. The Committee goes on to state:

. . . consistently argued over a period of several years that legislation made retrospective to the date of a Ministerial announcement is undesirable . . . The Committee note that, in the present case, the alteration to the law will be retrospective to the date of the issue of a media release which also coincided with the release of a draft Bill. The Committee observes that, despite the consultation process which has been followed by the Treasurer in preparing this Bill for submission to Parliament, time will pass (and has passed in the present case) between an announcement and a Bill's introduction.

The Committee has quite properly criticised the use by this Government of legislation by media release. Further, it is quite simply no answer to this charge for the Treasurer to respond that a draft Bill outlining the changes has been issued. As all honourable senators will be aware, draft Bills presented are rarely finally introduced into Parliament in their original form. Such Bills are often modified as a result of scrutiny by the Government, by industry, by the Opposition, and ultimately by Parliament. Accordingly the final Bill may have provisions of quite material content which have been substantially altered from the original draft. So it is quite wrong for any government to say that it presented a draft Bill and that gave some clear direction, some clear detail, some clear indication as to the purpose, intent and effect of the legislation.

We have seen the recently introduced National Companies and Securities Commission Amendment Bill 1988, in which an enormous number of amendments have been made and upon which if anybody sensibly tried to make judgments as to their commercial arrangements they would have found themselves in grave difficulty. It is absurd that the Government should put that as an argument, and it should be condemned for continuing to use announcements, whatever form they take, as the operative date for often very important and complex legislation; and taxation legislation particularly, which is of fundamental importance to everybody.
I am reminded of some comments I made in this Senate when speaking on the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Bill at the end of May 1986. I was moved to say then:
After an absolutely disgraceful display we now have before us legislation-
and I was referring then to the fringe benefits tax measure-

which will impose a tax which was first announced by the Treasurer on 19 September 1985-some eight months ago. The Treasurer has had eight months to prepare this legislation which is now before the Senate.

The legislation will impose a tax which is to apply from 1 July 1986-but seven weeks away. The Treasurer apparently believes that it is reasonable for him to take eight months to prepare this legislation but he then takes the view that taxpayers need only seven weeks to see the legislation before they begin to incur the liability, to be able to understand this complex legislation and to be in a position to pay the fringe benefits tax.

Nothing has changed since then. As I said then, the fringe benefits tax was introduced some eight months after Mr Keating's announcement of September 1985. Of course, the arrogance, disdain and disregard for ordinary citizens in that case pales into insignificance when we compare it with clauses 12 and 13 of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4). Those clauses propose to introduce a new section 21a into the Income Tax Assessment Act dealing with non-cash business benefits, the definition of which is given in proposed subsection 3.

TALK.START.PARA: —That would be a record, wouldn't it, 3 1/2 years?

—I would think that it is another first for this Government. I think that it is a record for this Government. However, given the mercurial heights to which it is able to ascend, I have no doubt that it will break that record in the near future. Basically, the non-cash business benefit definition means that property or services provided in a business relationship after 4 February 1985 will be taxed. That date, as Senator Messner pointed out, is almost four years ago. The explanatory memorandum to the Bill confirms this at page 14. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: The new section will apply to non-cash benefits provided after 4 February 1985 . . .
Immediately following that sentence, as if it is some sort of justification, moral explanation or virtue in nice cute brackets it is stated:
(the date of announcement).

Apparently, that is some sort of vindication. Almost four years after the date of announcement of changes to legislation the Bill to implement those changes was finally introduced into the Parliament. It seems that the Government decided that it needed this provision after the 1980 decision of the Full Federal Court in the case of the Federal Commissioner of Taxation v. Cooke and Sherden. In that case a sales incentive scheme providing non-transferable, non-convertible, overseas trips to soft drink vendors was held to be not subject to tax. On that occasion the court, quite properly within the confines and interpretation of the law at that time, decided that non-cash benefits could be taxable only if they were converted to cash.

For the moment, I make no judgment as to the wisdom of the legislation itself. However, I pass judgment on the gross unfairness and the high-handedness displayed by this Government in expecting taxpayers to plan their employment and businesses around legislation that will not be introduced for four years. One can ask, reasonably: Is it proper, is it morally acceptable, in today's society that governments can issue, by way of decree, bland pronouncements when, implicit in those pronouncements, as we now know, is the caveat that legislation will not be introduced for four years? Should individual taxpayers be expected to know the full force and effect upon them of such legislation? They are expected to be able to equip themselves, to adapt and, in some way, so arrange their affairs in compliance with legislation to be introduced in four years time, which will carry with it-almost without exception, given this Government-an additional tax liability. How is a taxpayer expected to know the content of a proposed law from some vague ministerial announcement which gives no details except that at some time in the future legislation will be introduced? Surely, during this time the Australian Taxation Office has been duly assessing the tax returns of taxpayers who, notwithstanding the February 1985 announcement, have been receiving non-cash business benefits from their principal suppliers or manufacturers.

I have not inquired of the Taxation Office, but I assume that it has been assessing on the law as it stands now and not on some pontificating pronouncement by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) as to what he intends in the event that Parliament agrees to his legislative process. I assume that as a result of this legislation, many thousands of tax returns previously assessed in accordance with the prevailing law will have to be re-assessed to take account of the new-found presumptions of cash convertibility to which non-cash business benefits have become subject.

So one can assume that those who received an annual non-cash benefit as a result of their endeavours will now have to calculate a cashed-out value for that benefit and pay tax on it for four years. Accordingly, those taxpayers who previously paid their taxes quite properly will be subject in the near future to debit assessments for tax which suddenly they find themselves owing. Surely even the Government can see the unfairness of that. I see that Senator Reynolds nods in agreement. Nobody could disagree with that principle. Nobody could argue that there is anything fair about giving somebody, four years later, a tax assessment based on a provision which at the time of the return was not in the Income Tax Assessment Act. Surely Senator McKiernan, as a man of fairness, would have stood up in the Caucus and objected to that. We ask of the Australian people that they pay their share of taxation but, prior to this Government, there used to be fundamental principles in taxation law in this country-that is, the principles of fairness, equity and clarity. The average taxpayer, the average John Citizen in the community, should be able reasonably to understand what his liability is. We now have a government with capricious disregard for taxpayers. It is hell-bent in its pursuit of collecting every cent of tax it can, in whatever way it can, totally ignoring decency and fairness which it cries for itself when it introduces diabolical taxation legislation.

Many taxpayers may not even have been aware that the non-cash business benefits they were receiving for work performed over the last four years were eventually to become subject to income tax. This is because in many cases ministerial announcements do not seep through to such people. I would think that the average car salesman who has won a trip to Hawaii because he sold more cars than anybody else in the neighbourhood, Western Australia or wherever, would be hardly likely to scan the financial pages every day to see whether there is some new pro- nouncement by the Treasurer of which he ought to be aware and conscious and to take that into consideration when he sits down to do his taxation return. I hardly imagine that such people read business digests so they can be quite certain that nothing is going to come along, unsuspecting as they are, and knock them over four years later. I am sure that those people do not set aside contingency amounts in the event that the Treasurer will retrospectively introduce new legislation four years later. Yet this Government expects taxpayers to show enthusiasm for its tax reform.

I would go further and suggest that it is not unreasonable to expect that those taxpayers who were aware of the proposed changes might have imagined and perhaps quite reasonably concluded, after the expiration of four years, when there is no statute on the books and they have not heard from their corner accountant that they are likely to owe tax at a new level, that this was one of these statements or promises from the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) which has diminished and disappeared in the mirage of confused politics and that the Government has not proceeded with its proposal. It is these sorts of actions and this sort of conduct by the Hawke Government which has made a mockery of both the parliamentary process and the rule of law itself.

The Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills has similarly been concerned over the last five or so years-it is interesting that it has been concerned for so long-about what has been seen as the practice of the Australian Taxation Office of resorting to legislation by media release as a matter of course when making changes to the taxation laws. The Committee commented extensively on this question of retrospective legislation in its 1986-87 annual report. The Committee considered that except in one or perhaps two very restricted circumstances, legislation by media release should not be used by the Government when enacting laws. At page 12 of the report the Committee stated:

. . . the practice of `legislation by press release' carries with it the assumption that citizens should arrange their affairs in accordance with announcements made by the Executive rather than in accordance with the laws. . .
It is almost as if Mr Keating thinks he is a pope and he is making some ex cathedra statement that suddenly becomes law. The Committee went on:

It treats the passage of the necessary retrospective legislation `ratifying' the announcement as a pure formality. It places the Parliament in the invidious position of either agreeing to the legislation without significant amendment or bearing the odium of overturning the arrangements which many people may have made in reliance on the ministerial announcement. Moreover, quite apart from the debilitating effect of the practice of the Parliament, it leaves the law in a state of uncertainty. Persons such as lawyers and accountants who must advise their clients on the law are compelled to study the terms of the press release in an attempt to ascertain what the law is.

Is that a reasonable way of doing business? Is that the way one would buy a motor car, a house or a refrigerator? Of course it is not. This Government puts itself above the law when it deals with other people's taxation. As the Committee quite properly notes, the legislation may differ significantly from the terms of the announcement, or the Senate may refuse to pass the legislation. In respect of the latter, I can only imagine some cute scenario in the future where the Australian Democrats, by dint of some rare aberration, agree with the Opposition and choose to amend or reject legislation. It is also the case that on almost all occasions where the Government adopts the modus operandi of government by media release, that the retrospectivity acts in favour of the Government and to the detriment of the taxpayer. On my calculations, over the last 5 1/2 years the Government, particularly in respect of tax legislation, has introduced respective legislation on at least 17 occasions that I am aware of. I have no doubt that on a more diligent examination, somebody could find other occasions. These Bills comprise the major pieces of taxation legislation introduced by the Government, such as the bottom of the harbour legislation, the fringe benefits tax, the capital gains tax and dividend imputation legislation, which retrospectively denied the inter-corporate dividend rebate in certain circumstances. But they are all fundamental pieces of legislation which have significantly changed the individual's taxation responsibilities. On all but two of those 17 occasions, of which I am aware, the legislation has operated exclusively for the pecuniary benefit of the Government. On the other two occasions where there was some retrospective benefit for the community, it also operated in favour of the Government. For the record, they were the Income Tax (International Agreements) Amendment Bill 1983 and the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1983. Of course, this reinforces the public perception of the Hawke Government running a record revenue raising operation, a government which enacts retrospective legislation to squeeze as much money out of predominantly middle class Australia as it possibly can.

In this regard honourable senators may have received correspondence from constituents concerning clause 46 of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1988. This clause will extend the roll-over relief from the capital gains tax to assets transferred by a company or a trust pursuant to a Family Court order or a maintenance agreement. Previously, such relief applied only to the direct transfer of assets between spouses. Consequently, since 20 September 1985, the indirect transfer of assets to a beneficial spouse has been subject to a capital gains tax upon sale. The constituents who have contacted me have requested that action be taken to have this provision backdated so as to operate from 20 September 1985-not, I would have thought, an unreasonable proposition. Obviously these constituents perceive discrimination. The Government will introduce retrospective legislation to raise revenue, but, of course, it will refrain from backdating legislation where it means a benefit to taxpayers and some cost, however modest it might be, to revenue. In the instant case there is perhaps a valid reason why clause 46 is not backdated. In the cases before the Family Court between September 1985 and 20 January 1988, it is to be hoped that in determining what is fair and equitable in terms of a settlement between the parties, the courts took into account that the transferee of this class of assets would be subject to a future capital gains tax liability, and that would have been accommodated in terms of the court's deliberations. Nonetheless, I suggest that the public perception of this Government is quite properly one of an unfair revenue raiser, and that perception is well justified.

I have commented many times in this place on the record tax grab perpetrated by this Government on the Australian taxpayer and, further, that this Government undertakes legislation by media release as a matter of administrative course. In most cases there have been no extenuating circumstances. Revenue would not have been lost if such a course had not been taken. It is simply a matter of norm and form for this Government now to conduct itself the way it does. I would suggest that the unfairness of this Government is no more starkly shown than in the length of time it has taken to cure the anomaly contained in section 26aaa. Honourable senators would be aware that this section provides that short term sales, that is, within 12 months, of assets other than trading stock, are to be included in assessable income. Of course, this includes the sale of property being the principal place of residence for a taxpayer unless, for example, the sale was caused by the taxpayer changing employment. Despite the advent of the capital gains tax legislation since September 1985, for some reason, known only to this Government, section 26aaa has continued to apply for the short term sales of a taxpayer's home. Finally, it was announced in conjunction with this year's May economic statement that section 26aaa would no longer apply to the sale of property or an interest in property occurring after 25 May 1988. Accordingly, any sale within 12 months is now to be subject to the capital gains tax rules. Under the capital gains tax, of course, an exemption exists for a sale of a taxpayer's principal place of residence. Taxpayers are entitled, however, to ask why it has taken so long to correct this anomaly. Why has this Government been so slow?

A purchaser of a home to be used as the principal place of residence may, for any number of reasons, need to sell that dwelling prior to the expiration of 12 months. Yet if the taxpayer does so, he is immediately put to disadvantage compared to the person who is able to hold a residence for more than 12 months. A change in family circumstances, financial hardship or even dissatisfaction with the purchase may necessitate a sale of the home within the 12-month period. Owing to the unwarranted effects of section 26aaa, however, the taxpayer has been unable to do so without facing the penalty of taxation. It has taken this Government three years to rectify that fault. It is interesting how with a wave of the wand and by the issue of a press statement this Government can find a way of closing what it perceives to be tax loopholes, but when it comes to correcting a wrong, an anomaly, a difficulty or disadvantage to a taxpayer it takes the Government a great deal of time to act. I suspect that is a result of the priorities of this Government and the agenda it has set for itself.

On a final note, I refer to a matter upon which I have previously touched in this place. It concerns the effect of inflation and its taxation implications for the depreciation of plant and equipment. I interpose that the underlying problem of Australia's economy is the distortion in terms of capital investment and savings compared with consumption. If one looks at the levels of consumption in Australia compared with the rest of the Western world, at the levels of capital investment and capital savings compared with countries such as Japan and Korea, one can see why we are at such a significant disadvantage.

Honourable senators will be aware that the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) will terminate the general accelerated depreciation provisions which have previously allowed plant to be written off over five or three years. The problem arises when the company accounts for the depreciation allowances in its books. Under the current accounting practice companies are required to record assets in their books at the prices for which they were purchased-hence the term historic cost. A deduction is allowed for depreciation of the asset so that, in theory, by the time the asset has come to the end of its usable life the company will have been able to put away sufficient funds to maintain the intitial value of the capital intact. Of course, anything earned by the company after deduction of expenses and depreciation is a profit and quite rightly taxable. The effect of inflation, however, is completely ignored so that at the end of the depreciation period-say, 10 years-it may cost the company an extra 60 per cent to purchase the same piece of equipment. Accordingly, with no allowance for inflation, the actual profit received by the company is far less than that which is shown. Indeed, a loss may in fact be made. I see that my time has run out in this debate, but I want to conclude by saying that the great tragedy for this country, for the community and for individuals is this Government's total lack of regard for taxpayers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the few remaining minutes of debate tonight on the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) and Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3), I shall commence my contribution on these further taxation amendment Bills which have been introduced by the Government. We are debating these Bills during a period of massive tax increases. Thus, the first Opposition amendment is in terms that the Senate notes that

SPEECH.PARA: . . . this is the highest taxing government in the post-war history of Australia.
We are further debating these Bills in an environment of increased inequality and increased injustice within our taxation system.

When I was a student of taxation law it used to be said that a good tax system could be tested against whether it is simple, equitable and efficient. No-one would say that our taxation system in this country is simple, it having had literally thousands of pages of additional tax law added since the Hawke Government came to power. The test of whether it is equitable-in other words, whether those who can afford to pay more do and those who can afford to pay less pay less-has similarly fallen down, as I shall demonstrate in a moment or two. The third question as to whether the system is efficient, whether one is not disadvantaged by the type of tax entity one becomes, has also, I regret, failed the test. I intend to look at a few of these tax facts of life into which these Bills are to be set.

I remind honourable senators that since 1980-81 tax paid by Australian people has more than doubled. In 1981 it was just over $40 billion; in 1987-88 it was $92 billion-a massive increase going far beyond inflation. The personal tax rate in some instances is now higher than the corporate rate. That in itself introduces distortions, with inducements to taxpayers to alter their taxation vehicle to attain the advantages that are provided to it by government in that form. The gap between average weekly earnings and the highest marginal rate of tax is ever decreasing. In other words, more average weekly earners are paying the highest marginal rates of tax. The number of taxpayers in the 40 per cent income tax bracket is now over 2.9 million. In other words, 40.6 per cent of Australians in the pay as you earn category are now into that 40 per cent income tax bracket. Income tax as a percentage of average weekly earnings has increased from 17.6 per cent in February 1983 to 21 per cent in February 1988.

I put this matter to the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, on the day before the Budget. I asked him whether he was aware of the fact that when his Government came to power the taxpayer on average weekly earnings was paying 17.6 per cent in tax and is now paying 21 per cent, an increase of 3.4 per cent. The Minister was not prepared to answer that question, so presumably he was unaware. I asked the Minister whether he was also aware that a taxpayer on five times average weekly earnings was paying 48.5 per cent and is now paying 43.7 per cent, a drop of 4.8 per cent. In other words, a taxpayer on high earnings is now paying a lesser percentage of his income in taxation. Again, the Minister was not prepared to answer that question. Since the Hawke Government came to power those who are not as well off are paying more tax, whereas those who are better off in the community, the well off in the community, are paying less tax. That is a matter of which the community should be aware.

A further setting in which we must put these taxation Bills, and which is related to the matters I have just mentioned, is the incredible effect of bracket creep on taxation revenue. It is now said by accountants and economists that each year there is now about $8 billion extra in revenue as a result simply of bracket creep-individuals' taxation rates moving into higher brackets purely through the effects of inflation. This was put vividly to the Australian people in a series of articles written by the well known financial journalist Terry McCrann and published in the Melbourne Herald. Those articles commenced on 17 October this year, a very short time ago. Terry McCrann clearly brought to the attention of the Australian people how they were suffering at the expense of this Government's policy of allowing bracket creep more and more to affect what is left over after the payment of tax.

I asked for the reason behind the statement, `The Australian Taxation Office is keen to determine just how full and free access can be taken'. The answer was:

A reading of that article reveals that the quotation is not in fact attributable to the ATO's Mr Conwell (Deputy Commissioner, Melbourne), but is an assertion of the journalists themselves. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me at the outset apologise to the Government for not letting it know that I was going to speak on the adjournment. It was not my intention to do so earlier. The matter that I want to raise, with the indulgence of the Senate, relates to the Olympic Games that have just passed. I chose not to say anything at the time not because it was not material but out of taste. I want to touch on the matter of Zola Budd, and at least to record what happened to her as distinct from other athletes from around the world.

SPEECH.PARA: On 20 June 1987, Zola Budd, a British citizen with a British passport, returned to her birthplace of South Africa. During her period in that country she visited a cross-country course Brakpan, a small South African mining town in the Transvaal. In the course of that cross-country race, Zola Budd, in a tracksuit and wearing joggers, trotted not on but across the course, not in the race but alongside competing athletes to give them some encouragement and heart. That conduct was followed by the International Amateur Athletic Federation (IAAF) Board ordering the British Amateur Athletic Board to suspend her. Lawyers for the British Amateur Athletic Board advised the Board that if Miss Budd took the Board to court the case would be overturned, she would be reinstated and there would be very considerable costs to the Board. However, as a result of black African pressure and threats of other English athletes being precluded from the world cross-country championships in New Zealand later that year, Zola Budd generously withdrew to ensure that in no way would those athletes be prejudiced. I might say that the New Zealand Government's conduct was absolutely disgraceful.

When the International Amateur Athletic Federation met in mid-April this year, 11 members favoured Budd's suspension and only Britain, the United States of America and Germany opposed it. The proposal was that she be suspended for 12 months. The effect of that would have been to preclude her from the world cross-country championships in New Zealand and also from the Seoul Olympics. The hypocrisy of this debate is to be demonstrated by Australia's different standards. The South Australian Labor Government, for example, with the warm and smiling approval of the Federal Government, embraced all the drivers competing in the world formula one motor racing grand prix fresh from their circuits in South Africa, welcoming them to Adelaide. There was no suggestion that any of those drivers would be banned or criticised or condemned; they were welcomed into Adelaide. Alan Jones came to Adelaide for his first race as a national hero, fresh from victories in South Africa. There was no criticism of Alan Jones or of any of the other drivers.

When Pat Cash required some points to get himself up the scale to compete in the grand prix tennis tournament he went to South Africa to compete. All he needed was a few points. He was not there for the glory or for the money; he simply needed the grand prix points to get himself into the championships, the final, the big stakes. What was said and what was done? Bob Hawke said of his mate-he loves to call all these winners `mate'-that he was disappointed with him. What has been said of Greg Norman? What has been said of any other Australian athlete who has gone to South Africa? Absolutely nothing. Zola Budd's sin, of course, is that she is white and she was born in South Africa.

Let me turn to the hypocrisy which pervades sport administration overseas. One of the prime movers to have Zola Budd banned from athletics was a Dr Primo Nebiolo, the 64-year-old President of both the International Amateur Athletic Federation and the Italian Athletics Federation. Dr Nebiolo aspires to be elected to the International Olympic Committee. He understands that that takes the black vote. We hear much rage and indignation from Dr Nebiolo about Zola Budd, yet at home in the Rome world championships there was a conspiracy by Italian officials, who abused their privileged positions of adjudication. It resulted in cheating. This cheating obtained a medal for Giovanni Evangelista with a fictitious registered jump. I believe that there is no greater sin in sport than to cheat, except to be an official who allows the cheating. An official is given the trust of all the competitors and all the other nations.

While the IAAF, of which Dr Nebiolo is President, found nothing untoward in its investigation of the incident, it finally led to the resignation of the Italian federation secretary, Mr Barra. Not a word was said when the same Mr Barra, in his role as assistant to the International Amateur Athletic Federation, took his seat in the council meeting in London to discuss the Budd disqualification. I would have thought that by any measure Mr Barra and Dr Nebiolo should have resigned.

Perhaps I ought to conclude on Dr Nebiolo by recalling that in 1973, in the European Cup semi-final in Oslo, Britain displaced Italy for a place. On that day the start of the 800 metres was held up for over an hour when Italian officials and athletes angrily invaded the track following the disqualification of their runner for two false starts. After what has been described in the media as undignified scuffles, Mr Barra and others were led by police from the track. Later in the day Dr Nebiolo was scheduled to make a medal presentation. However, still sulking and still enraged by the disqualification of an athlete for two false starts, he refused to present the medal. The Italian athletes boycotted the official banquet that evening.

We might ask ourselves: who was the Italian athlete about whom there was such an uproar? It was Mr Marcello Fiasconaro. It was his European 400 metres silver medal which he won in August 1971 that brought tears of joy to Dr Nebiolo, even though he had never set foot in Italy earlier than a month prior to the race. In fact, he could not speak a word of Italian. That was natural enough because he was born, grew up, trained, was coached and still lived in South Africa. Zola Budd's sin is that she was born white and she was born in South Africa. Non-whites from South Africa are able to compete overseas, where whites are not.

I am sure that those of us who take an interest in sport would know of Sydney Maree, the coloured South African who is now a United States citizen, who frequently visits South Africa, has coaching clinics in South Africa, presents trophies in South Africa, receives trophies in South Africa and who, by definition of the charge laid against Zola Budd, participates in South Africa. Yet there has not been a word of criticism; not a moment of utterance. As one journalist put it, `Zola Budd has been psychologically necklaced for being a 17-year-old spindly little girl who was born in the Transvaal and not somewhere else'. The ignominious indifference, sacrificing the innocent to satisfy the guilty, is an expedient that has fluttered fitfully throughout human history and has now been elevated, as one journalist said recently, `to an art form'.

One might ask: what has this girl done to deserve what she got? How has she sinned more than those athletes from Romania, the Soviet Union, Afghanistan and Nicaragua? One could go through all the left wing, undemocratic dictatorships. We see no objection, for instance, to those beautiful little gymnasts from Bulgaria, Romania or the Soviet Union who display their ability and their talents at the Olympic Games. Yet, if we see the way that there is discrimination in those countries-some of it has been raised in the last day or two by Senator Baden Teague-and we see what has happened in Afghanistan, we then ask: what is the moral incompatibility which allows us to discriminate against one athlete and not others? It seems to me that black Africans have had enormous influence. Yet if we go through the list of black African countries that participate in the Olympic Games we find that there are very few which are democracies.

This poor little girl has been hounded out of the love of her life, not because she has broken any rules, not because of her political views, not for her sins, not that in any way she is responsible for any misconduct, the breaking of rules or whatever. She has been penalised, discriminated against and driven out of her sport, which has cost enormous amounts of money, simply because she is a white South African. She has now retired and gone back to live in South Africa, I understand. If one looked at her recent performances one would see how her times started to extend and her competitive spirit was obviously snuffed out. We as a Parliament and we as a country did not stand by her; we supported that conduct and allowed it to happen. I think that is an indictment upon all of us.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

ANSWER.PARA: The Prime Minister has supplied the following answers to the honourable senator's questions:

In 1987 Greek authorities offered an exhibition of antiquities, including some treasures from the tombs of King Philip of Macedon and his son Alexander the Great, to Australia as a Bicentennial gesture.

The offer was welcomed by Australian authorities both because it reflected the importance the Government of Greece attached to Greek-Australian relations, a view reciprocated by the Australian Government, and because the exhibition itself was seen as culturally significant.

There was never at any time an attempt to ``derail'' the exhibition. Indeed the exhibition has been warmly welcomed by the Government. Nor did the Government insist that the term Macedonia not be used in connection with the exhibition.

In accordance with a Government decision taken in 1986 about bicentennial projects proposed by other Governments and having significance for bi-lateral relations, my Department on my instructions asked the Bicentennial Authority on 10 October to provide funds to support the exhibition.
The Authority's Chairman, Mr Kirk, immediately agreed to provide $950,000, exercising his authority to commit up to $1m without consulting his board.

I am confident that Australians generally will welcome this magnificent exhibition as a generous gesture from the Government of Greece and am surprised that the Opposition is now apparently opposed to it.
The funds contributed by the Authority will not be taken away from the proposed Bicentennial Youth Foundation, details of and funding for which have yet to be settled.

I am advised by the Australian Bicentennial Authority that the Sydney Symphony Orchestra applied on 2 September 1986 for funding for its tour of North America. The Authority's decision not to fund the Orchestra was taken in the normal way after considering other, competing, requests. The Orchestra was advised of the Authority's decision on 15 October 1986.
